ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Arson reward; notice; exceptions. 
(a)  Offer. The city shall pay a maximum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) as a reward to any person furnishing information leading to the arrest and indictment of any person guilty of arson within the city limits. Not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) will be paid for information leading to the arrest and indictment of one (1) or more persons guilty of arson in connection with any one (1) fire, and when information is given by more than one (1) person leading to the arrest and indictment of any person guilty of arson, then the reward of up to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) will be prorated among the persons giving such information. The reward shall be paid by the city out of any available funds belonging to the city, and such reward shall be determined by the fire marshal. 
(b)  Reward notice. The fire marshal is authorized and instructed to provide signs notifying the public of any reward authorized by this section. The signs shall be posted at various locations open to the public and all incendiary fire locations. Such signs shall be eight and one-half (81/2) inches by eleven (11) inches in size and shall read as follows: 
REWARD 
The City of Rosenberg, Texas, will pay a maximum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) as reward to any person furnishing information leading to the arrest and indictment of any person or persons guilty of arson within the city limits of the City of Rosenberg. A maximum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) will be paid for information leading to the arrest and indictment of one (1) or more persons guilty of arson in connection with any one (1) fire, and when information is given by more than one (1) person leading to the arrest and indictment of any person or persons guilty of arson, then the reward of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) will be prorated among the persons giving such information. 
(c)  Persons excepted. No person employed by the city, the state or any county thereof whose duty it is to detect violations of the law or make arrests in connection therewith shall be entitled to any reward for information leading to the arrest and indictment of any person guilty of arson. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-24), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-2. - Disposal of trash, paper and dangerous accumulations in fire zone. 
    All trash, paper and dangerous accumulations of such materials which may create a fire hazard within any fire zone of the city shall be collected by the city regularly and disposed of legally and properly. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-28), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-3. - Explosives storage. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any building, warehouse or other structure within the city for the storage of gunpowder in bulk, dynamite, nitroglycerine or other explosives. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-29), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-4. - Fireworks. 
(a)  Definition. For the purpose of this section, fireworks shall mean any combustible or explosive composition or any substance or combination of substances or any article prepared for the purpose of producing a visible or an audible effect by combustion, explosion, deflagration or detonation, including blank cartridges, toy pistols, toy cannons, toy canes or toy guns in which explosives are used; the type of balloons which require fire underneath to propel the same; firecrackers, torpedoes, sky rockets, Roman candles, sparklers, or other devices of like construction; and any devices containing any explosive substances. The term fireworks shall not include paper caps containing not in excess of an average twenty-five hundredths (0.25) of a grain of explosive content per cap manufactured in accordance with the interstate commerce commission regulations for packing and shipping as provided therein and such toy pistols, toy canes, toy guns or other devices which use such caps, the sale and use of which shall be permitted at all times. 
(b)  Applicability. This section shall apply to fireworks as defined in subsection (a) of this section, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Exceptions. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit any wholesaler, dealer, or jobber to transport fireworks in accordance with the interstate commerce commission regulations regarding the transportation of explosives and other dangerous articles by motor, rail, and water, provided that the fireworks are to be shipped directly out of the corporate limits of the city, or to prohibit the use of fireworks by railroads or other transportation agencies for signal purposes or elimination, nor to prohibit the possession or use of flares or rockets for the military, police, or emergency purposes by others. 
(d)  Manufacturing prohibited. The manufacture of fireworks is prohibited within the corporate limits of the city. 
(e)  Possession, sale or use. Except as provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to possess, store, offer for sale, sell at retail, or use or explode any fireworks within the corporate limits and within the area immediately adjacent and contiguous to such corporate limits and extending for a distance outside the city for a total of five thousand (5,000) feet, and it shall be unlawful to do or perform any act in violation of this subsection within such five-thousand-foot area contiguous to the corporate limits and outside the city, provided that this subsection shall not apply within any portion of such five-thousand-foot area which is contained within the territory of any other municipal corporation. 
(f)  Permit for displays. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the application for a permit to be issued by the city fire marshal for the use of fireworks for public or private display when all of the provisions of NFPA 1123, Public Display of Fireworks, including all subsequent amendments thereto, as published by the National Fire Protection Association are met and after such necessary permits have been issued by the fire marshal. Every such use or display shall be handled by a competent operator approved by the fire marshal and shall be of such character and so located, discharged or fired so as not to be hazardous to property or endanger any person. 
(g)  Removal of fireworks in violation. The fire marshal shall seize, take, remove, or cause to be removed, at the expense of the owner, all stocks of fireworks offered or exposed for sale, stored, possessed or held in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 89-49, § 1, 8-15-89) 
State Law reference- Regulating fireworks and fireworks display, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2154.001 et seq. 
Sec. 11-5. - False fire alarms. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully make a false alarm of a fire, bomb or any other emergency. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-31), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-6. - Maintaining fire extinguishing/alarm system. 
    All fire extinguishing systems, standpipe systems, fire alarm or detection systems, portable or fixed fire extinguishers and other fire protection systems or appliances required by the Standard Fire Prevention Code, Standard Building Code, Life Safety Code or any other city ordinance or otherwise installed shall be maintained or annually inspected by a firm possessing a current certificate of registration with the state fire marshal's office. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-22), 8-15-89) 
Secs. 11-7-11-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 11-26. - Designated city department; primary mission. 
(a)  The fire department is hereby declared and designated as the duly authorized fire department of the city. 
(b)  The primary mission of the fire department is to provide a range of programs designed to protect the lives and property of the inhabitants in and around the city from emergencies or dangerous conditions caused by either man or nature. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-1), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-27. - Fire chief-Appointment; term. 
(a)  Office created; appointment. The office of fire chief of the city is hereby created. The fire chief shall be appointed by the city manager, with ratification by the city council. 
(b)  Term. The fire chief shall hold office subject to termination by the city manager for just cause as defined by the city's personnel policies and procedures manual. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-2), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-28. - Same-Duties. 
(a)  Chief administrator. The fire chief shall serve as the chief administrator of the fire department, including both volunteer and career personnel. 
(b)  Equipment. The fire chief shall be responsible to the city manager for the safe and proper use of the city's firefighting equipment. The fire chief shall ensure that such equipment is at all times in proper operating condition and shall report to the city manager concerning the condition of the equipment, as the city manager may require. 
(c)  Report of violations. The fire chief shall report to the city manager any violation of any rules or regulations by any fireman or other person. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-3), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-29. - Career firemen. 
(a)  Subject to the approval of the city manager, the fire chief shall appoint such assistants from among the fire department's career firemen as he may deem necessary to perform the duties of the fire department and of his office. 
(b)  The career members of the fire department shall be governed by the city's personnel policies and procedures manual and the fire department standard operating procedure handbook. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-4), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-30. - Volunteer firemen-Total membership. 
    The fire department shall include the number of volunteer firemen determined by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-5), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-31. - Same-Compensation. 
    Volunteer members of the fire department shall be compensated in an amount and upon the terms established by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-6), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-32. - Same-Governance; bylaws. 
    The volunteer members of the fire department shall be governed by bylaws adopted from time to time by a majority of such volunteer members with the approval of the fire chief and the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-7), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-33. - Same-Meetings; officers. 
(a)  Meetings. The volunteer members of the fire department shall meet at the time and place designated by the fire chief. 
(b)  Secretary. The volunteer members of the fire department shall elect a secretary to serve a one-year term of office. The secretary shall maintain accurate records of the attendance at meetings and shall maintain accurate minutes of the business transacted at such meetings. 
(c)  Treasurer. The volunteer members of the fire department shall elect a treasurer to serve a one-year term of office. The treasurer shall receive and disburse all funds of the volunteer members of the fire department and shall keep accurate records therefor. No funds shall be disbursed by the treasurer unless such disbursement has been authorized by a majority vote of the volunteer members of the fire department. No check shall be issued by the treasurer without at least two (2) authorized signatures thereon, one (1) of which may be the signature of the treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-8), 8-15-89) 
Secs. 11-34-11-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE MARSHAL; INVESTIGATORS; INVESTIGATIONS AND INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 11-51. - Fire marshal's appointment; qualifications; responsibilities. 
(a)  Office created. The office of fire marshal is hereby created. The fire marshal shall be appointed by the city manager, with ratification by the city council. 
(b)  Qualifications. The fire marshal shall hold at least the intermediate certification in arson investigation and the intermediate inspection certificate from the Texas Commission on Fire Protection Personnel Standards and Education and at least an intermediate certificate from the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement Officers Standards and Education. 
(c)  Term. The fire marshal shall hold office subject to termination by the city manager for just cause as defined by the personnel policies and procedures manual. 
(d)  Responsibilities. The fire marshal shall be responsible for enforcing all city, state and federal laws as they pertain to arson, fire prevention, assisting firefighters in public awareness programs, inspecting new and existing buildings and structures for potentially dangerous conditions relating to fire and reviewing construction and engineering plans for potentially dangerous conditions relating to fire prior to commencement of construction. Subject to approval of the city manager, the fire marshal shall appoint such assistants as he may deem necessary to carry out the duties of the fire marshal's office. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-9), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-52. - Fire and arson investigators. 
(a)  Creation. An auxiliary fire investigation team, known as the fire and arson investigators, is hereby created. 
(b)  Supervision by fire marshal. The fire and arson investigators shall be under the direct supervision of the fire marshal. However, qualified, paid firefighters may be used as fire and arson investigators with the approval of the fire chief or, in his absence, the officers in charge of a specific fire scene. 
(c)  Qualifications. All fire and arson investigators shall be licensed peace officers of the state and hold at least a basic fire and arson investigators' certificate issued by the Texas Commission on Fire Protection Personnel Standards and Education. A copy of the certification attesting to the qualifications will be made a part of the permanent personnel file. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-10), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-53. - Investigation of fires; record. 
(a)  Required when loss occurs. The fire marshal shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring within the city in which property has been destroyed or damaged, particularly whether such fires were incendiary or accidental. 
(b)  Commencement of investigation. Such investigation shall commence as soon as the fire and arson investigator assigned to the fire by the fire marshal can arrive on the scene of the fire. The fire officer shall notify the fire marshal or a fire and arson investigator as soon as possible after the fire has been discovered. 
(c)  Records; required information. The fire marshal shall maintain records of all fires, together with all facts, statistics and circumstances, including the origin of the fire and the amount of the loss, which are revealed by the investigation required by this section or by state or federal law. The fire marshal's office is responsible for the collection, tabulation and storage of all incident reports, arson investigation records and files, inspection records and public fire safety education records, including all forms which must be submitted to the uniform crime reporting bureau at the headquarters of the state department of public safety in Austin, Texas and to the fire marshal's office of the state board of insurance. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-11), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-54. - Arrest of offenders; evidence delivered to prosecutor. 
(a)  Evidence of crime; arrest and charge. When, in his opinion, sufficient evidence exists to charge any person with the crime of arson, attempt to commit arson, conspiracy to defraud or criminal conduct in connection with any fire or with a violation of this chapter, the fire marshal shall cause such person to be lawfully arrested and charged with such offense. 
(b)  Duty to give all evidence to prosecutor. The fire marshal shall furnish to the proper prosecuting attorney all relevant evidence, together with the names of witnesses and all of the relevant information known by him, including a copy of all relevant testimony taken in the investigation of the fire in question. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-12), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-55. - Right of entry-Site of fire and adjoining property. 
    The fire marshal and the fire and arson investigators shall have the authority to enter and examine any building, structure or premises where any fire has occurred or any other building, structure or premises adjoining or near the site of the fire at all reasonable hours whenever, in the fire marshal's opinion, such examination is necessary and reasonable. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-13), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-56. - Same-Other buildings. 
    The fire marshal and the fire and arson investigators are authorized hereby to enter and examine any building, structure or premises within the city at all reasonable hours, whether or not a fire has occurred at such site or at an adjoining or nearby site, whenever, in the fire marshal's opinion, such examination is necessary to ensure the safety of all occupants. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-14), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-57. - Examination of mercantile, manufacturing and public structures. 
    At least once every calendar quarter, the fire marshal may enter upon and make or cause to be entered upon and made a thorough examination of all mercantile, manufacturing and public buildings and structures, together with the premises belonging thereto. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-15), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-58. - Ordering removal or remedy-General conditions warranting. 
    Whenever the fire marshal shall find that any building, structure or other premises, because of disrepair, age, dilapidation or any other reason, is unduly susceptible to fire and that such building, structure or other premises is so situated as to endanger another building, structure or property or is so occupied that fire would endanger persons or property therein, he shall order the building or structure removed or the conditions causing undue susceptibility to fire remedied. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-16), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-59. - Same-Specific dangerous or hazardous conditions. 
    Whenever the fire marshal finds any condition which may be dangerous in character or likely to cause or promote fire or create conditions dangerous to firemen or other persons or finds any violation of the Standard Building Code, National Electrical Code, Life Safety Code, Standard Fire Prevention Code or National Fire Codes or any code or ordinance adopted by the city and amendments thereto, he shall order the condition removed or remedied. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-17), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-60. - Same-Compliance; appeal; investigation and decision. 
(a)  Compliance. The owner or occupant of any building, structure or premises which is the subject of an order of the fire marshal pursuant to section 11-58 or 11-59 of this article shall comply with the terms of the order immediately upon receipt thereof. 
(b)  Appeal. An owner or occupant may appeal an order of the fire marshal pursuant to section 11-58 or 11-59 of this article to the city manager within ten (10) business days of receipt thereof. 
(c)  Investigation; decision. The city manager shall investigate the basis for the appeal and, unless the city manager revokes the order, such order shall remain in full force and effect and shall be complied with by the owner or occupant immediately upon the city manager's resolution of the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-18), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-61. - Maintaining building conducive to fire-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or occupant to keep or maintain any building, structure or other premises which, because of disrepair, age, dilapidation or any other reason, is especially susceptible to fire and which is so situated as to endanger another building, structure or property or which is so occupied that fire would endanger persons or property therein. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-19), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-62. - Same-Each day separate offense. 
    Each day's maintenance of any of the conditions prohibited in section 11-61 shall be a distinct and separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-20), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-63. - Same-Prosecutions; notice; failure to comply. 
    No prosecution shall be brought under section 11-61 until an order provided for in section 11-58 or 11-59 shall be given and the party notified shall fail or refuse to comply with the same in accordance with section 11-60. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-21), 8-15-89) 
Sec. 11-64. - Mutual aid assistance. 
    The fire marshal's office is hereby authorized to provide the assistance of the city's regularly employed fire and arson investigators to any municipality or county requesting such assistance, through an officer authorized to declare a state of civil emergency in such municipality or county, when such officer considers additional fire and arson investigators necessary to protect health, life, and property in such other municipality or county because of disaster, riot, threat of concealed explosives or unlawful assembly characterized by force and violence or the threat of force and violation by three (3) or more persons acting together or without lawful authority. Contemplating assistance authorized in accordance with provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Ch. 362, the city will maintain mutual aid agreements with each city in the county and with the county itself. 
(Ord. No. 89-50, § 1(9-23), 8-15-89) 
Secs. 11-65-11-80. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - COST RECOVERY FOR EMERGENCY SERVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, adopted July 3, 2007, repealed former Art. VI, §§ 11-115-11-121, and enacted provisions designated as a new Art. VI to read as herein set out in §§ 11-115-11-120. Former Art. VI pertained to hazardous materials incident. See also the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 11-115. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency medical incident shall mean any event, occurrence, incident or occasion that is immediately threatening to the life, safety, and health of a person. 
    Emergency services shall mean services provided by the Rosenberg Fire Department or other city department, as a result of a fire, rescue, emergency medical incident, or hazardous materials incident. 
    Fire shall mean the phenomenon of combustion manifested in light, flame, and heat; or the presence of smoke due to smoldering materials. 
    Hazardous materials shall mean any material substances, whether liquid, gas or solids, that are classified by other law as hazardous or may become hazardous in combination with other substances and/or such materials that by their nature in reaction or combination become hazardous or dangerous to property or persons. Hazardous materials shall be further defined as any substances or materials in a quantity or form which, in the determination of the Fire Chief of the City of Rosenberg or his authorized representative, pose a risk to persons, property or the environment and shall include, but not be limited to, such substances as explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum products, poisons, compressed or liquefied gases, etiologic (biologic) agents, oxidizers, corrosives, carcinogens, cryogens and organic peroxides. 
    Hazardous materials incident shall mean any event, occurrence, incident or occasion when the Rosenberg Fire Department or other city department is called, summoned or requested to provide fire fighting services or containment services or any other related services which are designed to remove the hazardous material, contain it or to be present while third parties or other agencies contain, remove or manage the hazardous material. 
    Nonresident shall mean any person living outside the service area of the City of Rosenberg, including, but not limited to, visitors and persons commuting or traveling through the service area. 
    Property shall mean any personal or real property. 
    Rescue shall mean any response by the Rosenberg Fire Department or other city department to aid, save, or remove somebody or something from a dangerous or harmful situation. 
    Service area shall mean areas within the corporate limits of the City of Rosenberg, and other areas that the City of Rosenberg has entered into an agreement to provide fire protection services or emergency medical services to such area. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 11-116. - Authority to assess cost. 
    It shall be the policy of the City of Rosenberg that the city shall recover all costs incurred by the Rosenberg Fire Department or other city department in providing emergency services for nonresidents or property located outside the city's service area. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 11-117. - Payment of cost. 
    The Fire Chief of the City of Rosenberg and the Director of Finance of the City of Rosenberg are each authorized to jointly bill, collect or initiate such proceedings or to cause such billing or collections to be initiated by third parties under contract with the city to the extent as permitted by law to collect as a debt owning to the city monies from any person or other entity that receives emergency services resulting from a response, or who owns the property that receives the emergency services resulting from a response, when such response involves emergency services for a nonresident or for property located outside the city's service area. In the event that other city equipment or personnel from other departments of the City of Rosenberg are used to assist the City of Rosenberg Fire Department or EMS, those departments shall submit a detailed report to the fire chief or director of finance so that the costs incurred by such department are included in the billing submitted for payment for emergency services provided. The fees associated with the response of other departments shall include labor costs for on-duty and off-duty personnel, equipment costs for use of city owned or rented equipment used in a response, and any supplies or materials that are utilized in a response. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 11-118. - Recovery fees to be established. 
    All fees shall be assessed based upon the actual cost incurred by the city in the performance of any act, duty or function. The cost assessed may be adjusted from time to time, upon approval by the city council, as shall be necessary to fully secure reimbursement to the city. In addition, the city shall be reimbursed for any loss or damage to equipment that might be sustained while providing any emergency services as herein provided. 
    The fees set forth on the "Fee Schedule" listed as Attachment "A" Fire Fee List, Attachment "B" First Responder EMS Fee List, and Attachment "C" Other Fee List attached hereto and incorporated herein, is hereby approved and authorized to be collected by virtue of this article. The city will seek reimbursement primarily from the insurance companies of those parties or entities that received emergency services. If no insurance coverage is available for emergency services rendered, the fire chief or the director of finance may bill the individual or entity directly for those emergency services rendered. 
    No fee shall be charged for emergency services rendered to a resident of the city, a resident's property, or the owner or occupant of real property within the service area of the city; with the exception of emergency services provided as a result of illegal activities, according to the laws and statues of the State of Texas and/or the City of Rosenberg, of such resident, owner or occupant. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 11-119. - Liens upon property, interest and attorney's fees. 
    In order to ensure the payment of all costs owed to the city as a result of providing emergency services, the city shall have the right to establish a lien to the extent that may be permitted by law upon the property that receives the services resulting from a response. The city may enforce its lien(s) to the extent that the same are permitted under the laws of the State of Texas. In addition, the city shall recover all costs, attorney's fees and interest up to the maximum amount permitted by law against any person or other entity who shall fail or refuse to pay such amounts and monies as shall be billed and charged by the city for emergency services rendered. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 7-3-07) 
Sec. 11-120. - City council to determine disputes. 
    In the event, upon notice, any person or other entity shall contest, dispute or refuse to pay or otherwise challenge the accuracy, sufficiency or amount of any charge assessed by the city as a result of providing emergency services, such issues shall be finally determined by the city council. If any person or other entity shall be aggrieved, contest, or dispute any charge or assessment made under the provisions of this article, or the collection thereof, such person or entity shall appeal the same by filing an appeal in writing within thirty (30) days after receipt of the first bill or statement assessing such charge. If an appeal shall be filed, the city council shall meet in open session and shall hear and determine the objection filed and will make such ruling and determination as shall be appropriate in light of the facts, evidence and circumstances duly presented. The decision by the city council shall be final, binding and conclusive as to all such appeals that may be properly filed. In the event an appeal shall not be timely filed, the same shall be rejected and the charge or assessment shall be considered final and binding. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 7-3-07)

Chapter 13 - FOOD AND FOOD SERVICES[1]

Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of Ordinance No. 2000-43, adopted Oct. 3, 2000, repealed the former Arts. I-III, §§ 13-1-13-131, and enacted a new Art. I, § 13-1-13-13 as set out herein. The former Arts. I-III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from §§ 10-42, 10-43 and 10-45 of the 1960 Code; Ord. No. 90-55, § 2, adopted Sept. 4, 1990; Ord. No. 94-10, §§ 1-5, adopted June 21, 1994; and Ord. No. 98-32, §§ 1-3, adopted Oct. 20, 1997. 
Charter reference- Authority to inspect and regulate public places serving and handling foods and places producing meat and dairy products, § 4.06(d(2), (4)). 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 11; health, sanitation and nuisances, Ch. 14; rodent control, § 14-50; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 16; utilities, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Authority to inspect dairies, slaughter pens and slaughterhouses and prohibit nuisances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 215.072, 217.042; health certificate requirement, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 438.031 et seq.; meat inspection, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 433.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Adoption of Texas Food Establishment Rules. 
    The City of Rosenberg adopts by reference the provisions of the current rules or rules as amended by the Texas Board of Health found in 25 Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 229, Sections 161 through 171 and 173 through 175 regarding the regulation of food establishments within the City of Rosenberg. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00) 
Sec. 13-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms used in this chapter shall have the meanings as hereinafter provided, and such other definitions as herein provided in this Code shall be applicable to this article to the extent that no other definition is provided: 
    Administrator means the city employee designated by the city manager to administer these regulations. 
    Authorized agent or employee means the employees of the City of Rosenberg. 
    Food establishment means a food service establishment, retail food store, mobile food unit, and/or a roadside food vendor. 
    Food handling administrator means the employee or agency designated by the city manager to administer the inspection and licensing of the handling of food by mobile food establishment owners, operators or their employees. 
    Ice cream truck means a motor vehicle in which ice cream, popsicles, ice sherbets or other frozen desserts of any kind are carried for the purpose of retail sale on the streets of the city. 
    Mobile food establishment means a vehicle mounted food establishment that is readily moveable. 
    Municipality of Rosenberg shall be understood to mean and refer to the City of Rosenberg, Texas, a home rule municipality located in Fort Bend County, Texas. 
    Regulatory authority means such persons as shall be appointed from time to time by the city manager of the City of Rosenberg to perform such duties, responsibilities and obligations as provided for under this article and shall further include the chief of police of the City of Rosenberg, all officers duly appointed by the chief of police, the fire chief of the City of Rosenberg, fire marshal and all fire officers duly appointed by the fire chief. 
    State rules shall mean the state rules found at 25 Texas Administrative Code, Chapter 229, Section 161 through 171 and Sections 173 through 175, as amended. Rules as therein promulgated are hereby designated and shall be known as the Texas Food Establishment Rules. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00; Ord. No. 2016-18 , § 1, 6-7-16) 
Sec. 13-3. - Permits and exemptions. 
    A person may not operate a food establishment without a permit issued by the City of Rosenberg. Permits are not transferable from one (1) person to another, except as otherwise permitted by this article. Additionally, permits are not transferable from one (1) location to another location, except for mobile food establishments as permitted by Article II of this chapter. A valid permit must be posted in or on every food establishment regulated by this article. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00; Ord. No. 2016-18 , § 1, 6-7-16) 
Sec. 13-4. - Application for permit and fees. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a food establishment must make a written application for a permit on forms provided by the City of Rosenberg. The application must contain the name and address of each applicant, the location and type of the proposed food establishment and the applicable fee. An incomplete application will not be accepted. Failure to provide all required information or falsifying the information required may result in denial or revocation of the permit. Renewals of permits are required on an annual basis and the same information is required for the renewal permit as for an initial permit. 
(b)  Prior to the approval of an initial permit or the renewal of an existing permit, the City of Rosenberg shall inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with state laws and rules. A food establishment that does not comply with state laws and rules will be denied a permit or the renewal of a permit. 
(c)  The following fees shall apply to the issuance of any permit or authority under the terms of this article. 
(1)  For the issuance of an original food dealer's permit for food processing and food service establishments and each renewal thereof, the person requesting the permit shall pay to the City of Rosenberg a permit for one (1) complete year from the date of issuance. 
(2)  Permit fees shall be determined by the number of persons employed full time or part time by the food processing or food service establishment except to the extent as may be otherwise provided. 
(3)  Any permit issued hereunder that shall become lost, mutilated or otherwise misplaced, shall be replaced by the city upon the payment of a fee of twenty dollars ($20.00). 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00) 
Sec. 13-5. - Health inspection fees. 
(a)  At the time of issuance of an original food dealer's permit for food processing and food service establishments and each renewal thereof, the person requesting the permit shall pay to the health officer a permit fee as provided for in a schedule of fees established by resolution of the city council. Such permit fee shall be for one (1) complete year from the date of issuance, and shall be determined by the total number of persons employed full time or part time by the food processing or food service establishment. 
(b)  Re-inspection fee. When the city determines that the operation of an establishment has repeated or serious violations, such that upholding the public health and welfare requires a scheduled re-inspection to confirm timely abatement of the violations, a fee will be imposed by the city on the operator to partially defray the cost for a follow-up inspection. Such re-inspection fee shall be provided for in a schedule of fees established by resolution of the city council. The owner must pay the re-inspection fee prior to receiving another inspection to confirm abatement. 
(c)  Late payment of permit fee. When the city determines that the payment of an annual or renewal permit fee is delinquent, a late payment fee shall be charged to the owner of the food processing or food service establishment. Such late payment fee shall be provided for in a schedule of fees established by resolution of the city council. The owner must pay the late payment fee prior to receiving a food dealer's permit. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00; Ord. 2003-46, § 1, 12-2-03; Ord. No. 2010-16, § 4, 8-17-10) 
Sec. 13-6. - Plan review. 
(a)  Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling or conversion shall be submitted to the City of Rosenberg for review before work is begun. Extensive remodeling means that twenty (20) percent or greater of the area of the food establishment is to be remodeled. The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, equipment arrangement, mechanical plans and construction of materials of work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The plans and specifications may be approved by the City of Rosenberg if they meet the requirements of the rules adopted by this article. The approved plans and specifications must be followed at all times in construction, remodeling or conversion. 
(b)  Failure by anyone to follow the approved plans and specifications and to construct the facility in accordance with the approved plans and specifications will result in a permit denial, suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00) 
Sec. 13-7. - Suspension of permit. 
(a)  The City of Rosenberg may, without warning, notice or hearing, suspend any permit to operate a food service establishment if the operation of the food establishment constitutes an imminent hazard to the public health, safety and well-being. Suspension shall be effective immediately upon the issuance of the notice of suspension and a copy of such notice shall be handled in accordance with the terms of this article. When a permit is suspended, food operations shall immediately cease. 
(b)  Whenever a permit is suspended, the holder of the permit shall be afforded an opportunity for a hearing if timely requested by the permit holder by filing a letter or other writing with the city secretary of the City of Rosenberg requesting a hearing within twenty (20) days of the receipt of the notice. The hearing must be requested and the letter or other writing requesting a hearing must be received by the city secretary before the expiration of the twenty-day period as herein provided. If no written request for hearing is properly filed with the city secretary as herein provided, the suspension shall be deemed final and sustained. The City of Rosenberg reserves to itself the right to end any suspension at any time if the reasons for the suspension no longer exist. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00) 
Sec. 13-8. - Remedies. 
(a)  Penalty. The penalty upon conviction for violation of this article shall be as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. 
(b)  Injunctions. The regulatory authority or health officer may seek to enjoin violators of these rules. 
Sec. 13-9. - Examination, condemnation of food. 
    Food may be examined or sampled by the health officer as often as necessary for enforcement of this article. The health officer may, upon written notice to the owner or person in charge specifying with particularity the reasons therefor, place a hold order on any food which it believes is in violation of subsection (a) of rule 229.163 of the rules cited in section 13-1 or any other provision of this article. The health officer shall tag, label, or otherwise identify any food subject to the hold order. No food subject to a hold order shall be used, served, or moved from the establishment. The health officer shall permit storage of the food under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health, in which case immediate destruction shall be ordered and accomplished. The hold order shall state that a request for hearing may be filed within ten (10) days and that if no hearing is requested the food shall be destroyed. A hearing shall be held if so requested, and on the basis of evidence produced at that hearing, the hold order may be vacated, or the owner or person in charge of the food may be directed by written order to denature or destroy such food or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00) 
Sec. 13-10. - Grading of food service establishments. 
(a)  Placard to be displayed; exception. Every food service establishment in the city, or its police jurisdiction, shall display, in a place and within such time as designated by the health officer, a placard approved by the health officer stating the grade received at the time of the most recent inspection of the establishment, provided, that temporary food service establishments shall not be subject to grading. 
(b)  Grades-listed. The grades of food service establishments shall be as follows: 
(1)  Grade A. An establishment having a demerit score of not more than ten (10). 
(2)  Grade B. An establishment having a demerit score of more than ten (10) but not more than twenty (20). 
(3)  Grade C. An establishment having a demerit score of more than twenty (20) but not more than forty (40). 
(4)  Posting of grade after inspection; notice issued. Immediately following each inspection, the health officer shall post the appropriate grade based upon the inspection findings, and shall issue an appropriate notice in accordance with the provisions of this Code. 
(5)  Second violation; penalties. Notwithstanding the grade criteria established in subsection (2) above, whenever a second consecutive violation of any item of two (2) or four (4) demerit points is discovered, the permit may be suspended, or in lieu thereof, the establishment shall be downgraded to the next lower grade. 
(6)  Reinspection after downgrading; additional inspections. The permit holder or operator of any establishment, the grade of which has been lowered, may at any time request an inspection for the purpose of regrading the establishment. Within ten (10) days following receipt of a request including a signed statement that the conditions responsible for the lowering of the grade have, in the applicant's opinion, been corrected, the health officer shall make an inspection, and thereafter as many additional inspections as he/she may deem necessary in order to be assured that the applicant is complying with the higher grade requirements. There shall be a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each such reinspection; and, if the findings indicate compliance, the health officer shall award the higher grade. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00) 
Sec. 13-11. - Revocation of permit. 
    The City of Rosenberg may, after proper opportunity for hearing, revoke a permit for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of these rules or for interference with the City of Rosenberg or any appointed officer of the City of Rosenberg who may be performing duties as imposed by this article. Prior to revocation, the City of Rosenberg will notify the holder of the permit or the person in charge, in writing, at the address indicated on the permit for such notice, of the reason for which the permit is subject to revocation and that the permit shall be finally revoked at the end of twenty (20) days following the mailing of required notice unless a written request for hearing is filed with the city secretary of the City of Rosenberg within such twenty-day period. A written request for hearing shall not be deemed filed unless properly received by the city secretary of the City of Rosenberg within the twenty (20) day period as herein set out. If no request for hearing is made within the time as herein provided, the revocation of the permit becomes final and is not subject to appeal. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00) 
Sec. 13-12. - Administrative process. 
(a)  A notice as required herein is properly served when it is either delivered to the holder of the permit or person in charge or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the permit holder as set out on the permit or application for the permit. A copy of the notice as well as the return receipt requested card, if received, or certification of delivery shall be filed in the records of the offices of the City of Rosenberg. 
(b)  The hearing as herein provided shall be conducted by the City of Rosenberg at a time and place designated by the city manager. The city manager shall be further authorized to appoint a hearing officer to conduct the hearing and to make recommendation to the city manager as to the final disposition of the matter. The city manager shall make such final disposition as shall be appropriate from the recommendation of the hearing officer. Based upon the record of the evidence of such hearing, the city manager of the City of Rosenberg may make findings of fact and such decision as shall be appropriate and may sustain, modify or rescind any notice or order duly considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing decision shall be furnished to the holder of the permit by the city manager. No appeal shall be taken from the decision of the city manager and the city manager's decision shall be final and valid in all things. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-3-00) 
Sec. 13-13. - Violation. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of these rules and any person who is the permit holder or otherwise operates a food service establishment that does not comply with the requirements of this article or the requirements of any officer duly appointed hereunder to administer this article or any police officer of the City of Rosenberg shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. Punishment shall be fixed for violation to the maximum extent as time to time provided for by law and otherwise provided for in this Code. In addition to the remedies as herein provided, the City of Rosenberg may at any time seek such injunctive relief as shall be necessary to insure compliance with the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2000-43, §§ 1, 2, 10-03-00) 
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE FOOD COURTS AND MOBILE FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 13-14. - Scope. 
    This article shall regulate all mobile food establishments operating within the city's corporate limits. 
( Ord. No. 2016-18 , § 1, 6-7-16) 
Sec. 13-15. - Permit requirements. 
(a)  No person shall operate a mobile food establishment who does not possess a valid, current mobile food establishment permit. 
(b)  A person seeking a mobile food establishment permit shall make application on a form provided by the administrator, and shall provide all of the information listed in subsections (1)-(7) as part of the application: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner and/or operator; 
(2)  If the applicant represents a corporation, association or partnership, the names and addresses of the officers or partners; 
(3)  The name under which the food vending operation will be operated; 
(4)  A description of the type of food or the specific foods to be vended; 
(5)  A description of the vehicle to be used in the mobile food vending operation along with the license or registration and vehicle identification number of the vehicle; 
(6)  Except ice cream trucks, the locations within the city where the mobile food establishment will operate. Should such locations not yet be established, an updated list of locations shall be provided to the health department at the inspection date; and 
(7)  An original written instrument, executed by each real property owner, verifying that the mobile food establishment is authorized to operate at such location or locations. A no objection letter from each real property owner may suffice until such instrument may be provided. Original written instruments shall be provided to the city at the scheduled inspection date. Should the mobile food establishment acquire additional locations, an updated list shall be provided to the health department along with written permission from the property owner. 
(c)  Upon receiving a completed application for a mobile food court permit or mobile food establishment permit, the administrator may make appropriate inspections of the location, food, equipment, vehicle and other reasonable inspections concerned and shall issue a permit only if: 
(1)  The application complies with subsection (b); and 
(2)  Any inspection reveals compliance with the applicable requirements of all federal and state statutes and regulations, and city ordinances governing the proposed mobile food establishment operation. 
(d)  Mobile food establishment fees shall be provided for in a schedule of fees established by resolution of the city council. Additional fees may be required by the food handling administrator for a food handling license. 
(e)  All funds collected for permits under the provisions of this article shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(f)  Mobile food establishment permits shall be valid for only one (1) year from the date of issuance unless sooner suspended or revoked. 
(g)  Such permits shall be issued on the earliest date of submission of the completed application. 
(h)  Mobile food establishment permits shall not be transferred or assigned and shall be considered revoked should the character of the food vending operation be changed from that specified in the permit. 
(i)  Every mobile food establishment permit shall be renewed each year in like manner as the original permit application. 
(j)  Mobile food establishment permits shall be valid for special events. 
(k)  Mobile food establishments during recovery from a declared natural disaster shall be regulated as follows: 
(1)  Applicant may apply immediately following a declared natural disaster and upon approval, may set up for six (6) to eighteen (18) months, depending on severity of the disaster, as determined by the city manager or designee. 
(2)  Applicant must submit all the information required in subsection (b) and must follow all the subject regulations of this section as to location and rules excluding allowable times and storage on site. 
(3)  Applicant will be permitted to set up overnight for operation the following day. All items shall be enclosed or secured at property at the applicant's cost and liability. 
(4)  The following items will be allowed during recovery from a declared natural disaster: 
a.  Goods and services: Laundry, food, charitable activities, generators, mattresses, landscaping, retail goods, internet and wireless services. 
b.  Any other items not listed that may be related will be determined by the city manager or designee. 
( Ord. No. 2016-18 , § 1, 6-7-16) 
Sec. 13-16. - Operation requirements and restrictions for mobile food establishments. 
    Mobile food establishments shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Mobile food establishments shall comply with all sanitation and construction regulations as outlined in TAC § 229.169 of the Texas Food Establishment Rules, as amended. 
(2)  The issuing, suspension and revocation of licenses for the handling of food by mobile food establishment owners, operators or their employees shall be regulated by the food handling administrator. 
(3)  In order to ensure equal treatment of all mobile food establishment permit holders, variances from this article will not be granted. 
(4)  Except for ice cream trucks, mobile food establishments are prohibited from operating on public rights-of-way. 
(5)  A permitted mobile food establishment may operate at construction sites. 
(6)  Mobile food establishments, including ice cream trucks, may operate on private property provided: 
a.  The mobile food establishment permit holder has filed with the health department written permission of the property owner for the operation of the mobile food establishment to be provided at the time of inspection; and 
b.  The applicant provides the original written instrument or no objection letter verifying that the mobile food establishment is authorized to operate at such location or locations as required in section 13-15(b)(7). 
(7)  Any properly permitted mobile food establishment may operate in a location in or immediately adjacent to city-sponsored civic events. 
(8)  May not use structures that are not intended for mobile food establishments. Examples of acceptable vehicles include, but are not limited to, vehicles equipped with serving windows, merchandise display equipment, kitchen preparation areas, and advertisement display section. Approved structures must adhere to the following: 
a.  No cracked windows; 
b.  No visible rust or disrepair; 
c.  No emission of noxious gases, odors, and/or fumes. 
(9)  Portable fire extinguishers shall be provided. A minimum 2-A; 10-BC multi-purpose fire extinguisher shall be currently inspected and tagged by a licensed technician. 
(10)  Mobile food establishments shall have a Type 1 hood installed at or above all commercial cooking appliances and domestic cooking appliances which include flat grills, fryers, char grills, and pits used for commercial purposes that produce grease vapors. Type 1 hood systems shall be installed with an approved and inspected fire suppression system. A Type K fire extinguisher is also a requirement in the installation of a fire suppression system. 
(11)  Should the mobile food establishment provide its own seating with the intent to function as anything other than a to-go service, a written instrument allowing the patrons of the mobile food establishment to utilize their restroom facilities will be required upon application. 
(12)  Mobile food establishments are not allowed to provide food or beverage to the public within residential neighborhoods, with the exception of construction sites, special events. Properly permitted ice cream trucks are allowed within residential neighborhoods if compliant with subsection (k) below. 
(13)  Ice cream trucks may stop on public streets or rights-of-way provided such stops: 
a.  Are not in or within fifty (50) feet of an intersection; 
b.  Not an area prohibited to the standing or parking of vehicles; 
c.  All items are vended from the curbside of the vehicle or the rear of the vehicle; and 
d.  The ice cream truck is vending in a safe manner. 
(14)  Mobile food establishment inspections are conducted at the City of Rosenberg Permit Office. An appointment will be made for a specific day-date-time. Missed appointments will result in a re-inspection fee. No inspections are conducted off site. 
( Ord. No. 2016-18 , § 1, 6-7-16) 
Chapter 14 - HEALTH, SANITATION AND NUISANCES[1]

I-III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1960, §§ 11-22, 11-27, 12-4, 12-10-12-25, 12-27, 12-33 and 12-34; Ord. No. 91-27, § 1, adopted July 16, 1991; Ord. No. 92-03, §§ 2 and 3, adopted Jan. 21, 1992; and Ord. No. 94-08, § 4, adopted April 19, 1994.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Applicability. 
    This chapter relating to the definitions and prohibitions of any nuisance shall apply to the corporate limits and within the area immediately adjacent and contiguous to such corporate limits and extending for a distance outside the city for a total of five thousand (5,000) feet, and it shall be unlawful to do or perform any act in violation of this chapter within such five-thousand-foot area contiguous to the corporate limits and outside the city, provided that this chapter shall not apply within any portion of such five-thousand-foot area which is contained within the territory of any other municipal corporation. 
Sec. 14-2. - Complaints by individuals. 
    All complaints concerning the violation of any health or sanitary regulations shall be made to the city. The city shall make an inspection of the matters complained of and if such matters complained of are found in violation of any state or city health or sanitary laws, rules or regulations, the city shall immediately give the notice if required and as provided for in this chapter and shall proceed to have the matters complained of corrected. 
(Ord. No. 2001-12, § 1, 3-20-01) 
Secs. 14-3-14-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCE ABATEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Maintenance of pens for animals, § 4-92; dangerous buildings, § 6-271 et seq.; removal of certain debris required, § 6-301; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 11; food and food services, Ch. 13; sanitation code for retail food store establishments adopted, § 13-1. 

Sec. 14-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms and phrases, when used in this chapter shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Brush means scrub vegetation; and covered with scrub vegetation; or a dense growth and undergrowth. 
    Brushwood means the wood of small branches when cut or broken; or a thicket composed of shrubs and small trees. 
    Building shall mean the structure, whether public or private, that is adapted for occupancy or transaction of business, for rendering of professional service, for amusement, for the display, sale or storage of goods, wares, or merchandise, or for the performance of work or labor, including hotels, apartment buildings, office buildings, public buildings, stores, theaters, markets, restaurants, grain elevators, warehouses, workshops, factories, sheds, barns and other structures on premises used for business purposes. 
    Bushy means covered, thick with brush or brushwood. 
    Carrion means the dead and putrefying flesh of any animal, fowl or fish. 
    Impure or unwholesome matter means a putrescible or nonputrescible condition, object or matter which tends, may or could produce injury, death or disease to human beings. 
    Junk means old iron, glass, paper, cordage, or other waste that may be treated so as to be used again in some form; secondhand, worn or discarded articles of any kind having little or no commercial value; something without intrinsic value; to abandon or to get rid of as no longer of value or use. 
    Neighborhood shall mean a platted subdivision property, or contiguous to and within three hundred (300) feet of a platted subdivision. 
    Objectionable, unsightly or unsanitary vegetation or matter means any matter, condition, or object which is or should be objectionable unsightly, or unsanitary to a person of ordinary sensitivities. 
    Occupant shall mean the individual, partnership, corporation, or business entity that uses or occupies any building or part or fraction thereof, whether the actual owner or tenant. In the case of vacant business buildings or vacant portions thereof, the owner, agent or custodian shall have the responsibility as occupant. 
    Owner shall mean the actual owner, agent or custodian of the property or building, whether individual, partnership, corporation, trust, or any other organized entity. 
    Platted subdivision means a subdivision that has its approved or unapproved plat recorded with the county clerk of the county in which the subdivision is located. 
    Premises means all privately owned property, including vacant land or a building designed or used for residential, commercial, business, industrial, or religious purposes. The term includes a yard, ground, walk, driveway, fence, porch, steps, or other structure appurtenant to the property. 
    Refuse means trash, debris, rubble, stone or other material left over in buildings or broken from ruined buildings. 
    Trash means something worth relatively little or no value; junk; rubbish; something in a crumbled or broken condition en masse; and woody or vegetable matter fallen or strewn on the ground. 
    Waste product means debris resulting from a process (as a manufacturer) that is of no further use of the system producing it. 
    Weed means an introduced plant growing in the ground that is or has been in cultivation usually to the detriment of the crop or to the disfigurement of the place; an economically useless plant; a plant of unsightly appearance; one (1) of wild or rank growth; a tree or shrub of low economic value that tends to grow freely and by its presence to exclude or retard more valuable plants; wild growth usually in the nature of rank grass or undergrowth. 
Sec. 14-27. - Prohibited accumulations; litter; weeds; duty of property owner, occupant. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property, occupied or unoccupied, within the corporate limits of the city to permit or allow any filth, carrion, rubbish, junk, trash, waste products, brush and refuse, impure or unwholesome matter of any kind, or objectionable, unsightly or unsanitary matter of whatever nature to accumulate or remain thereon. Such accumulations and conditions are hereby declared a public nuisance, the prompt abatement of which is a public necessity. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, deposit or sweep any of the matter prohibited in subsection (a) of this section into, upon or along any drain, gutter, alley, sidewalk, street, parkway, right-of-way, or vacant lot, or upon any public or private premises within the corporate limits of the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, keep, store, or accumulate refuse, including newspapers, abandoned vehicles, refrigerators, stoves, furniture, tires, and cans, on premises in a neighborhood for ten (10) days or more, unless the refuse or object is completely enclosed in a building, or is not visible from a public street. 
Sec. 14-28. - Premises harmful to health. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, suffer, allow, permit, or maintain a premises in a manner that creates an unsanitary condition likely to attract or harbor mosquitoes, rodents, vermin, or disease-carrying pests. 
Sec. 14-29. - Limitation of height of grass and weeds. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, claiming, occupying or having supervision or control of any real property, occupied or unoccupied, within the corporate limits of the city to permit weeds, grass, brush or any objectionable or unsightly vegetation to grow to a greater height than twelve (12) inches, ("vegetation"). It shall be the duty of such person to keep the area from the line of his property to the back of the curbline next adjacent to it, if there is a curbline, and if not, then to the centerline of the adjacent unpaved street, or to the edge of the pavement of a paved but uncurbed street, free and clear of the matter referred to above. All vegetation not regularly cultivated and which exceeds twelve (12) inches in height shall be presumed to be objectionable and shall be kept mowed the same as provided in this section. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any person owning, claiming, occupying, or having supervision or control of any real property referred to in this section to remove, cut, correct, drain, and/or fill all prohibited matter or conditions and to cut and remove all weeds, brush, and other objectionable or unsightly vegetation as often as may be necessary to comply with this section, and to use every precaution to prevent the same from occurring or growing on such premises. 
(c)  Exemptions: 
(1)  Heavily wooded acreage preventing the operation of mowing machines. 
(2)  Farming or pasture acreage classified on the tax rolls of the central appraisal district as "agricultural exempt" and properly maintained for active agricultural use. Notwithstanding anything in this exemption to the contrary: 
a.  The subject property shall maintain a clearance of vegetation of at least one hundred (100) feet from any adjacent occupied building, school, athletic field, arena, park or playground in conformity with all other provisions of section 11-29. 
b.  The subject property shall maintain a clearance of vegetation of a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet from the back of curb or paved surface, regardless of right-of-way width, between an improved street right-of-way and the cultivated rows in conformity with the provisions of this section. This area may contain turn rows (that area where agricultural equipment maneuvers or turns outside of the main cultivated fields), however such turn rows shall be maintained in conformity with the other provisions of this section. 
(3)  Exemptions, as defined in subsections (1) or (2) of this subsection may be denied or suspended, if in the opinion of the planning director, conditions exist that may be detrimental to health, safety or welfare of the community. 
(Ord. No. 2003-18, § 1, 4-30-03) 
Sec. 14-30. - Inspection. 
    The director of public works, or his designated representatives, shall have the authority to inspect any property within the city limits of the city, at any reasonable time in order to make a thorough examination thereof for the purpose of determining whether or not any of such unsanitary conditions mentioned herein exist, subject, however, to the restrictions against such inspection and entry of private residence or private property for said inspection as provided by laws of the State of Texas. The director of public works, or his designee, is designated as the code enforcement official for the purpose of being issued a search warrant, as may be required, pursuant to Section 18.05 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. 
Sec. 14-31. - Notice to abate, service. 
(a)  Generally. If the owner of any real property fails or refuses to comply with this article, and the city manager, or his designee, receives information of the existence of any property in violation of this article, he or his designee assigned such responsibility, shall serve the owner of the property with a written notice informing the owner of such condition and directing that action be taken to bring the property into compliance within seven (7) days. 
(b)  Service of notice on owner or occupant. The notice authorized by this section shall be given personally to the owner or occupant or both in writing or by letter mailed "certified mail return receipt requested" or equivalent addressed to the owner at the owner's address as recorded in the appraisal district records of the appraisal district in which the property is located and to the occupant at the mailing address of the subject property. If personal service cannot be obtained and the owner is not an individual, then the notice shall be served upon the persons designated under applicable law for service of process on a non-individual or non-resident. 
(c)  Service of notice by publication; contents. If personal service of the notice cannot be obtained, service may be given by publication, at least once, in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, addressed to the owner or if the owner is not known, "To the owner of (legal description of the property involved)." The notice shall give the legal description of the property, state the condition which constitutes a violation of this section, and shall state that upon failure of the owner to rectify the situation within seven (7) days of the date the notice is mailed, published or posted, a complaint may be filed in the municipal court of the city for violation of this article, stating the penalties for violation. In addition, the notice shall advise that the city may do the work or make the improvements required or pay for the work done or improvements made and charge the owner for the expense involved, and upon failure of the owner to pay the city for such expense, fix a lien on the property for the expense involved as provided in this article. 
(d)  Notice by posting; contents. In addition to publication in a local newspaper, notice may be served by posting said notice on or near the front door of each building on the property to which the violation relates; or by posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the property to which the violation relates, if the property contains no buildings. Any notice posted on the property shall be on a placard and shall have the same contents as provided in (c) above. 
(e)  Notice returned as "refused" or "unclaimed." In the event a notice is mailed to a property owner in accordance with this article and the United States Postal Service returns the notice as "refused" or "unclaimed," the validity of the notice is not affected, and the notice is considered as delivered. 
(f)  Additional notice, not required. In a notice provided under this section, the city may inform the owner by regular mail and a posting on the property that if the owner commits another violation of the same kind or nature that poses a danger to the public health and safety on or before the one (1) year anniversary of the date of the notice, the city without further notice may correct the violation at the owner's expense and assess the expense against the property. If a violation covered by a notice under this section occurs within the one-year period, and the city has not been informed in writing by the owner of an ownership change, then the city without notice may take any action permitted in this article and assess expenses against the property. 
Sec. 14-32. - Unlawful noncompliance; filing of complaint; fines. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or tenant of any land within the city to fail to have any weeds, grass, brush or rubbish mowed, cut, removed, or otherwise fail to bring property into compliance with the standards set forth in this article within seven (7) days after notice is mailed or published, directing that such standards be met; the city manager or his designee assigned such duties shall, whenever a violation is found, file a complaint with the municipal court; and the prosecutor of the municipal court assigned such duties shall prosecute the case, and upon conviction for violation of this article the owner shall be fined in accordance with section 1-13 of this Code. 
Sec. 14-33. - Abatement by city; payment of costs by owner; lien imposed for nonpayment. 
(a)  In addition to the remedy provided for in section 14-32, the city may also cause the work necessary to bring any property into compliance with this article to be done if the owner fails either to do such work or cause the work to be done within seven (7) days from receipt of notice or publication, and to charge the owner for the costs incurred by the city. A statement of the costs incurred by the city to abate such condition shall be mailed to the owner of such premises, if the owner and mailing address are known, and if not known, may be published in the official newspaper designated by the city for notice or other local newspaper having at least weekly issues. The statement shall demand payment within thirty (30) days from the date of receipt or publication. 
(b)  In addition to all costs for equipment, manpower and other related expenses, a minimum fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each lot, adjacent lots under common ownership, or tract of land is hereby established for all associated administrative functions as may be required. 
(c)  If the statement of the costs served or published pursuant to this section is not paid within such period, the director of finance may file with the county clerk a statement of the expenses incurred to abate and correct such condition on the premises, to be filed in the deed records, and such statement shall be and the city shall have a privileged lien upon the lot, parcel, or tract of land upon which such expenses were incurred, second only to tax liens and liens for street improvements, together with ten (10) percent interest per annum on the delinquent amount from the date such payment was due. For any such expenditures and interest, as aforesaid, suit may be instituted and foreclosure had in the name of the city; and the statement so made, as aforesaid, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended in any such work. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 2-20-01; Ord. No. 2001-12, § 1, 3-20-01) 
Secs. 14-34-14-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RODENT CONTROL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Dangerous buildings, § 6-271 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; food and food services, Ch. 13; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 16; manufactured housing, mobile homes and travel trailers and parks, Ch. 17; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 24; subdivisions, Ch. 25; utilities, Ch. 29. 

Sec. 14-50. - Harborage and infestation prevention. 
(a)  All buildings and related structures shall be maintained free from insect and rodent harborage and infestation. 
(b)  The grounds, premises, and area where a building is situated shall be maintained free of all accumulations of debris which may provide rodent harborage or breeding places for flies, mosquitoes and other pests. 
(c)  Storage areas shall be so maintained as to prevent rodent harborage. 
(d)  The growth of brush, weeds and grass shall be controlled to prevent harborage of ticks, chiggers and other noxious insects. Open areas shall be maintained free of heavy undergrowth of any description as provided herein. 
Sec. 14-51. - Garbage and refuse containers. 
    Within the city limits all garbage or refuse consisting of waste animal or vegetable matter and all small dead animals upon which vermin may feed shall be placed and stored until collected in covered containers constructed of galvanized iron, tin, plastic, rubber or other suitable material, including plastic garbage bags. It is further declared unlawful for any person to dump or place on any premises, land or waterway any dead animals or any waste vegetable or animal matter of any kind. 
Sec. 14-52. - Dumping on lots and alleys. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place, leave, dump, or permit to accumulate any garbage, rubbish or trash in any building or on any premises, improved or vacant, or on any open lot or alley in the city so that same shall or may afford food or harborage for rodents. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, 2-20-01; Ord. No. 2001-12, § 1, 3-20-01) 
Secs. 14-53-14-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ABANDONED ICEBOXES, REFRIGERATORS 

Sec. 14-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Abandon shall mean the throwing away on vacant property, junk heaps, trash piles or debris accumulations of the icebox or refrigerator or any other act which at common law would constitute an abandonment of personal property. 
    Dangerous exposure shall mean the placing of an icebox or refrigerator not in use in a garage, barn, outbuilding, porch, yard, lot or other portion of premises where children at play may come upon it and be attracted to it. 
(Code 1960, § 15-41) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-82. - Declaration of nuisance. 
    The abandonment or dangerous exposure of any icebox or refrigerator with its door, or doors, in normal latching or locking condition is declared to be a public nuisance and a serious menace to life because of the danger of children entering such an icebox or refrigerator, becoming locked therein and suffocating. 
(Code 1960, § 15-42) 
Sec. 14-83. - Removing, dismantling doors and locks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon or dangerously expose or cause or permit to be abandoned or dangerously exposed any icebox or refrigerator unless the door or doors have been removed from such icebox or refrigerator or unless the latch or lock holding each door shut is dismantled or removed so that the door may be opened from within by simply pushing on it. Jamming or obstructing the lock or latch shall not be a sufficient compliance herewith, but the same must be removed or dismantled so that accidental latching or locking is impossible. 
(Code 1960, § 15-43) 
Sec. 14-84. - Persons responsible. 
    The duties imposed by this article are imposed on the owner of the icebox or refrigerator in abandoning it and the owner or any occupant of premises where a dangerous exposure occurs. This article shall be liberally construed to effect the remedy intended and prevent loss of children's lives. 
(Code 1960, § 15-44) 
Sec. 14-85. - Penalty. 
    In addition to any penalty provided by law, the maintenance of a public nuisance as provided in this article or in permitting or allowing such public nuisance to exist shall be abated pursuant to section 14-60 et seq. Each day that such nuisance shall continue after the time for abatement shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1960, § 15-45) 
Secs. 14-86-14-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NOISE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 93-14, § 1, adopted September 21, 1993, is treated as having repealed former Art. IV, §§ 14-91 and 14-92, relative to noise, and enacted a new Art. IV, §§ 14-91-14-100, to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Art. IV derived from Code 1960, §§ 15-17 and 15-18. Article IV was renumbered as Art. V in the republication of this volume. 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 4; pets disturbing the peace declared nuisances, § 4-3; railroad whistles, sirens and bells restricted, § 28-184. 

Sec. 14-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this article, unless the context of their usage clearly indicates another meaning: 
    Daytime hours shall mean the hours between 7:00 a.m. on one (1) day and 10:00 p.m. the same day. 
    dB(A) shall mean the intensity of a sound expressed in decibels read from a calibrated sound level meter utilizing the A-level weighing scale and the slow meter response, as specified by the American National Standards Institute. 
    Emergency shall mean any occurrence or set of circumstances involving actual or imminent physical trauma or property damage or loss which demands immediate action. 
    Emergency work shall mean any work performed for the purpose of preventing or alleviating the physical trauma or property damage threatened or caused by an emergency, or which is otherwise necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a fire, accident or natural disaster, or which is required to protect persons or property from exposure to danger, or which is required to restore public utilities.
