    Whenever by the provisions of this chapter the chief of police or a police officer of the city is authorized to retain a defendant in custody, he may place him in jail or any other place where he can be safely kept. 
(Code 1960, § 6-7) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.015. 
Sec. 19-6. - Authority to issue citations to appear in municipal court. 
(a)  City Manager. The City Manager, or his authorized representative as designated in writing, shall have the power to issue one (1) or more citations to any person. This authority shall be limited to situations where the City Manager or his representative has probable cause to believe that the person is criminally responsible for any offense which the City has a duty to enforce or responsibility for. 
(b)  Animal control officer(s). The animal control officer(s) shall have the power to issue one (1) or more citations to any person. This authority shall be limited to situations where the animal control officer has probable cause to believe that the person is criminally responsible for any offense defined in Chapter 4 of this Code and other ordinances of the city relating to animals and fowl which the animal control officer has a duty to enforce or responsibility for. 
(c)  Fire marshal. The fire marshal, or his authorized representatives as designated in writing, including any fire and arson investigators, shall have the power to issue one (1) or more citations to any person. This authority shall be limited to situations where the fire marshal or his representative has probable cause to believe that the person is criminally responsible for any offense which the fire department has a duty to enforce or responsibility for. 
(d)  Citation-Contents. Such citation shall contain written notice of the time and place the person must appear in the municipal court, the name and address of the person charged, and the offense charged which is within the jurisdiction of the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 93-02, § 1, 4-21-93; Ord. No. 94-17, § 1, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 2006-35, § 1, 11-7-06) 
Cross reference- Authority of animal control officer, city police officer or other agent of the city to issue citation for any animals taken into a city park, § 4-10(c). 
State Law reference- Authority of peace officers to issue citation for Class C misdemeanor, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 14.06(b). 
Sec. 19-7. - Jury fees. 
    A person who responds to the process of the municipal court and who either serves on a jury or is excused by the municipal court for any cause after his voir dire examination, shall be entitled to compensation of six dollars ($6.00) for each day or fraction of each day served as a juror or in attendance in court. Such fee shall be payable out of the city treasury. 
(Ord. No. 93-11, § 2, 8-3-93) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 93-11, § 2, adopted August 3, 1993, added a new § 19-6, pertaining to jury fees. Ord. No. 93-02, § 1, adopted April 21, 1993, had previously added § 19-6, relative to authority to issue citations to appear in municipal court. To avoid duplication, the most recent addition has been renumbered § 19-7 at the editor's discretion. 
State Law reference- Pay of jurors, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 104.001 and V.T.C.A., Government Code § 61.001. 
Sec. 19-8. - Notice upon failure to appear. 
    When any person who has failed to appear in the municipal court of the city as provided in a citation as set forth in section 19-6 hereof, fails to appear before said court at the time and place in said citation specified, the clerk of said court, upon the direction of the judge thereof, shall cause written notice to be personally served on such person or mailed to such person at the address given in said citation. The written notice shall advise such person to appear before said municipal court at a time and place specified therein, at least ten (10) days subsequent to the date such notice is mailed or personally served, to answer the charges which such person was cited to appear and answer and for violating such citation. Such notice shall warn the person to whom it is addressed that such person is subject to fine on the original charge plus additional fines for violation of the citation and for failure to obey the notice. If the notice is not obeyed, an officer will be sent to arrest such person. If notice is mailed by U.S. certified mail, the return receipt, showing delivery of such notice to the address given in such citation, shall be prima facie evidence of the receipt thereof by the person to whom it was addressed. 
(Ord. No. 94-17, § 3, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 2006-35, § 2, 11-7-06) 
Sec. 19-9. - Failure to obey notice. 
    Any person failing to obey any such notice shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), regardless of the disposition of the charge on which such person was originally cited, and regardless of the disposition of any charge for failing to appear in court pursuant to a citation. 
(Ord. No. 94-17, § 4, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 2006-35, § 3, 11-7-06) 
Sec. 19-10. - Penalty for failing to appear. 
    Any person failing to appear in the municipal court at the time set out in such citation shall be deemed guilty of failing to appear, regardless of the disposition of the charges upon which such person was originally cited, and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 94-17, § 2, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 2006-35, § 4, 11-7-06) 
Secs. 19-11-19-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COURT COSTS, FEES AND FINES 

Sec. 19-31. - Conformity with state law. 
    The rules of procedure and evidence in the trial of a case in municipal court and costs and fees chargeable as costs shall follow and conform to the rules and provisions set out in the Code of Criminal Procedure of the State of Texas for justice courts. 
(Code 1960, § 6-39) 
State Law reference- Fines, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 45.046. 
Sec. 19-32. - Application of state law to judgment, executions and fine collections; payment; committed to city jail; credit; use of county jail. 
(a)  Judgments, executions and collection of fines. The provisions in regard to judgments, executions, and the collection of fines, as prescribed by Vernon's Ann. C.C.P., shall apply to the judgments, executions and collection of fines in the municipal courts, the judge having in regard to such matters all the powers of a justice of the peace. 
(b)  Payment. All fines and costs assessed against defendant shall be paid to the judge or clerk of the court. The judge may direct the defendant to pay the entire fine and costs immediately, at some later date, or in installments at designated intervals. 
(c)  City jail. Upon failure to do so the defendant shall be committed to the custody of the chief of police and imprisoned in the city jail pending the payment of the fine and costs or the satisfaction thereof by serving the required time in jail. However, no person may be imprisoned because he or she cannot pay the full amount of the fines and costs. 
(d)  Credit for time served. A prisoner serving his fine out in jail will be given the same credit for time served on the fine as provided for in cases in the justice courts. 
(e)  Use of county jail. Upon agreement of the council with the commissioners' court, any jail time of a prisoner may be served at the county jail. 
(Code 1960, § 6-44; Ord. No. 93-11, § 3, 8-3-93) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Arts. 45.041, 45.046. 
Sec. 19-33. - Collection of special expenses-Failure to maintain financial responsibility. 
(a)  The city's municipal court is hereby authorized to collect two (2) special expenses, in addition to other taxable court costs, for services performed in certain cases involving the failure to properly maintain financial responsibility, defined by Section 601.072 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(b)  The first special expense as authorized by subsection (a) hereof shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00), which fee shall be charged to a defendant convicted of failure to maintain financial responsibility, and ten (10) percent of which may be retained by the city as a fee for collection services rendered by the court, and ninety (90) percent of which shall be remitted to the comptroller of public accounts for the state, on or before the last day of the month following each calendar quarter. 
(Code 1960, § 6-45.1(a), (b)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 45.203. 
Sec. 19-34. - Same-Case dismissed due to actions by defendant after date of alleged offense. 
(a)  The city's municipal court is hereby authorized to collect a special expense for services performed in cases in which the laws of the state require that the case be dismissed because of actions by the defendant, as described in subsection (b) hereof, after the date of the alleged offense. 
(b)  Such special expense as authorized by subsection (a) hereof shall be collected only in cases in which the defendant complies with the requirements imposed by the municipal court as authorized by Sections 543.102-503.104 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(c)  Such special expense as authorized by subsection (a) hereof in cases described in subsection (b) hereof shall be ten dollars ($10.00), which amount is hereby determined by city council to represent the actual expenses to be incurred for the municipal court's services. 
(Code 1960, § 6-45.2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 45.203. 
Sec. 19-35. - Same-Failure to appear; violation of promise to appear. 
(a)  Special expense collection authorized. The city's municipal court is hereby authorized to collect in addition to other taxable costs, a special expense for the issuance and service of a warrant of arrest for an offense under Section 38.11, Penal Code, or under Section 543.009, Compliance with or Violation of Promise to Appear, Texas Transportation Code; and the special expenses described in Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 17.04 dealing with the requisites of a personal bond and a special expense for the issuance and service of a warrant of arrest, after due notice. 
(b)  Payment. Such special expenses as authorized by subsection (a) hereof shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00), which amount shall be paid into the city treasury for the use and benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 93-11, § 4, 8-3-93) 
State Law reference- Authority to collect fines and special expenses, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 45.203. 
Sec. 19-36. - Municipal court building security fund. 
(a)  The clerk of the municipal court of the city, in accordance with Article 102.017 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, is hereby authorized and directed to collect from every person convicted of a misdemeanor offense in the municipal court of the city an additional three dollars ($3.00) security fee as cost of court. 
(b)  The director of finance of the city, in accordance with subsection (d) of Article 102.017 is hereby directed and authorized to establish a municipal court building security fund and to provide for the use of money in said funds, upon authorization and direction by the city council for all purposes permitted by law, including, but not limited to those currently enumerated under Article 102.017, to-wit: 
(1)  The purchase or repair of X-ray machines and conveying systems; 
(2)  Handheld metal detectors; 
(3)  Walkthrough metal detectors; 
(4)  Identification cards and systems; 
(5)  Electronic locking and surveillance equipment; 
(6)  Bailiffs, deputy sheriffs, deputy constables, or contract security personnel during times when they are providing appropriate security services; 
(7)  Signage; 
(8)  Confiscated weapon inventory and tracking systems; or 
(9)  Lock, chains, or other security hardware. 
(Ord. No. 97-37, § 1, 10-7-97) 
Sec. 19-37. - Municipal court technology fund fee assessed. 
    The clerk of the municipal court of the city, in accordance with Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. Art. 102.0172, is hereby authorized and directed to establish a municipal court technology fund and is further hereby authorized and directed to collect an additional four-dollar fee, as a cost of court, from every person convicted of a misdemeanor in the municipal court of the city. 
    The fee shall be assessed against any person duly convicted where a sentence is imposed, the person is placed in community supervision, including deferred adjudication, or the court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
    The clerk of the municipal court shall collect the cost and pay to the director of finance of the city the amount of money as herein provided to be deposited into a fund known as the municipal court technology fund. 
    In accordance with law, the fund designated herein may be used to purchase technology enhancements for the municipal court of the city including, but not limited to, computer systems, computer network, computer hardware, computer software, imaging systems, electronic kiosks, electronic ticket writers and docket management systems. 
    The municipal court technology fund shall be administered as a part of the budget of the city in accordance with the decisions made by the city council in accordance therewith. The fee as herein imposed shall be collected on any cases that are commenced after the first day of September 1999 and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 99-39, § 1, 8-17-99) 
Sec. 19-38. - Collecting delinquent fines, fees and other debts. 
    In accordance with Article 103.0031 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure, there shall be imposed an additional fee of thirty (30) percent on all debts and accounts receivable, i.e.: fines, fees, restitution, other debts, and costs that are more than sixty (60) days past due and have been referred to an attorney for collection. 
    The collecting of delinquent fines, fees and other debts shall be administered as a part of the budget of the city in accordance with the decisions made by the city council in accordance therewith. 
    The fee as herein imposed shall be collected on any cases that are commenced and disposed of in accordance with the provisions of this section and applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 2004-10, § 1, 6-15-04) 
Sec. 19-39. - Municipal court juvenile case manager fund established and fee assessed. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a municipal court juvenile case manager fund (the "fund"), pursuant to Article 102.0174, Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  The Municipal Court of the City of Rosenberg, Texas (the "municipal court") is hereby authorized and directed to assess a municipal court juvenile case manager fee (the "fee") in the amount of five dollars ($5.00) against all defendants convicted of a misdemeanor offense in the Municipal Court on or after January 1, 2006. Each misdemeanor conviction shall be subject to a separate assessment of the fee. 
(c)  A person shall be considered convicted if: (1) a sentence is imposed on the person; (2) the person is placed on community supervision, including deferred adjudication community supervision; or (3) the court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(d)  The municipal court clerk is hereby authorized and directed to collect the fee and to pay the same to the director of finance of the city for deposit into the fund. 
(e)  The fund shall be used only for the purposes of financing the salary and benefits of a juvenile case manager employed under Article 45.056 of the Texas Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(f)  The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the city council of the city. 
(g)  The court may waive the imposition and collection of the fee in cases of financial hardship. 
(Ord. No. 2005-23, § 1, 11-1-05) 
Chapter 20 - OIL AND GAS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; taxation, Ch. 26. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Purpose and intent of chapter. 
(a)  The purpose and intent of this chapter, in order to protect the public health, peace, safety and welfare of the city and its residents, is to establish reasonable and uniform limitations, safeguards and controls for drilling, completion and production operations associated with the exploration and production of oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances within the corporate limits of the city. The provisions set forth in this chapter shall be considered as minimum requirements and should not relieve any person from any duty imposed by laws of the city, state or the United States and no one shall at any time be relieved of their duty to use reasonable care and take reasonable precautions for the safeguard of people and the protection of property rights and to avoid unnecessary interference with property and property interests. 
(b)  All regulations as herein provided shall be cumulative of and in addition to such regulations and requirements as may be imposed by other laws, either state or national; and nothing herein shall in any way be interpreted to be providing for the modification and/or change of existing law. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Acidize means to treat a subsurface stratum using a chemical reaction with acid, to remove scale, corrosion or other impediments to flow, and/or to increase the flow capacity of the stratum. 
    Artificial production shall mean the raising to the surface of the earth, by means other than natural flow, of crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids. 
    Blowout preventers means a series of several valves installed on the wellhead of a gas or oil well to prevent the escape of pressure either in the annular space between the casing and drill pipe or in open hole during drilling or completion operations. 
    Building shall mean any structure used or intended for supporting or sheltering any use or occupancy. The term building shall be construed as if followed by the words "or portions thereof." 
    Casing means steel pipe placed in an oil or gas well as drilling progresses to prevent the wall of the hole from caving in during drilling, and to provide a means of extracting petroleum if the well is productive. 
    Cementing means the application of a liquid slurry of cement and water to various points inside or outside the casing; used to provide a protective sheath around the casing, to segregate the producing formation, and to prevent the migration of undesirable fluids. 
    City shall mean the municipality of Rosenberg, Texas, its departments, boards, elected officers and officials. 
    City council shall mean the governing body of the city. 
    City manager shall mean the chief administrative officer of the city. 
    City secretary shall mean the duly qualified and sworn secretary of the city. 
    Completion means the operations associated with preparing and bringing a well into production. 
    Conductor pipe means a short string of large diameter casing used to keep the top of the wellbore open and to provide a means of conveying the up-flowing drilling fluid from the wellbore to the mud pit. 
    Deleterious substance shall mean any chemical, salt water or oil field brine, waste oil, waste emulsified oil, basic sediment, mud or injurious substances produced or used in the drilling, completion, development, producing, transporting, refining and/or processing of crude oil, condensate, natural gas or natural gas liquids. 
    Development well means a well drilled in a field known to be productive of hydrocarbons; often used to complete a pattern of production. 
    Drill-stem test means a method of gathering data on the potential productivity of a formation before installing casing in a well; usually involves the recovery of formation fluids either in the drillstring or at the surface. 
    Enhanced recovery shall mean an operation by which fluid or energy is introduced into a reservoir productive of crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids for the purpose of facilitating the recovery of crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids therefrom. 
    Exploratory well means any well drilled to a depth greater than the existing fresh water strata, as determined by the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission, for the purpose of securing geological or other information which may be obtained by penetrating the earth with a drill bit, coring equipment, and similar tools. Includes what is commonly referred to in the industry as "slim hole tests" or "core hole tests" and the like. 
    Fire marshal shall mean the duly qualified fire marshal or fire chief of the city. 
    Flow lines shall mean all pipelines starting from a particular well and connected to oil and gas production facilities installed to collect, separate, process, and/or store the crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids produced from the well, or pipelines connected to or between the equipment comprising the oil and gas production facilities. 
    Fracturing means a method of stimulating production by increasing the permeability of the formation. Using high hydraulic pressure, a fluid containing a proppant such as sand, glass beads or aluminum pellets is pumped into the formation causing a fracture to form. When the pressure is released, the fracture closes, trapping the proppant, which provides an artificial flowpath for reservoir fluids. 
    Gas well means any well: 
(1)  Which produces natural gas not associated or blended with crude petroleum oil at the time of production; 
(2)  Which produces more than one hundred thousand (100,000) cubic feet of natural gas to each barrel of crude petroleum oil from the same producing horizon; or 
(3)  Which produces natural gas from a formation or producing horizon productive of gas only encountered in a wellbore through which crude petroleum oil also produces hydrocarbon liquids, a part of which is formed by a condensation from a gas phase and a part of which is crude petroleum oil, shall be classified as a gas well unless there is produced one (1) barrel or more of crude petroleum oil per one hundred thousand (100,000) cubic feet of natural gas; and that the term "crude petroleum oil" shall not be construed to mean any liquid hydrocarbon mixture or portion thereof which is not in the liquid phase in the reservoir, removed from the reservoir in such liquid phase, and obtained at the surface as such. 
    Gathering system shall mean all pipelines operated as incident to the development and operation of oil and/or gas fields and secondary recovery projects. 
    Highway shall mean the entire width between the boundary line of every road publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular traffic. Even though not covered by pavement, highway shall also be understood to mean the distance between the right-of-way lines established on a survey or plat of the roadways. 
    Mayor shall mean the chief elected official of the city. 
    Motor vehicle shall mean any automobile, truck, truck-tractor, trailer or semi-trailer or any motor bus or any self-propelled vehicle not operated or driven upon fixed rails or tracks. 
    Mud means the liquid circulated through the well bore during rotary drilling operations to bring cuttings to the surface, cool and lubricate the bit and drill stem and to protect against a blowout by holding back subsurface pressure. A complex liquid mixture including chemicals, reactive solids, and inert solids. 
    Natural production shall mean the rising to the surface of the earth, by natural flow, of crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids. 
    Oil and gas inspector shall mean that person designated by the city manager of the city to enforce the provisions of this chapter, or such authorized representative of said person. 
    Oil well means any well which produces one (1) barrel or more crude petroleum oil to each one hundred thousand (100,000) cubic feet of natural gas. 
    Operator means a person, acting for himself or as an agent for others and designated to the Railroad Commission of Texas as the one who has the primary responsibility for the physical operation and control of a well and for complying with the rules and regulations of the commission in any and all acts subject to the jurisdiction of the commission. The operator shall be the person or entity listed on the commission form P-4 as operator of the well or property in question. 
    Permittee shall mean any person to whom a permit is issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Person shall mean any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, trust, cooperative or other type of organization. 
    Pollution shall mean the contamination or other alteration of the physical, chemical or biological properties of any natural waters of the city, or such discharge of any liquid, gaseous or solid substance into any water of the city as will or is likely to create a nuisance or render such water harmful, detrimental or injurious to public health, safety or welfare to domestic, commercial, industrial, agricultural, recreational or other beneficial uses; or to livestock or aquatic life. Pollution shall also be understood to mean contamination of any ground, surface or area of natural vegetation, as well as the ground thereunder. 
    Public building shall mean all buildings used or designed and intended to be used for such purposes as deliberation, entertainment, amusement, health care, education, as well as other buildings where the public shall be invited for the purposes of economic commerce or activity. 
    Reservoir means a subsurface, porous, permeable rock body in which oil and/or gas are stored. Most reservoir rocks are carbonates, sandstones or a combination of these. Hydrocarbon reservoirs contain oil, condensate, natural gas, natural gas liquids and/or saltwater, as well as contaminants such as nitrogen, carbon dioxide, sulfur in various forms and inert gases. 
    Right-of-way is expressly limited to all public streets or other public property within the city. 
    Salt water, as used in this chapter, means any water containing more than five hundred (500) milligrams per liter chlorides. 
    Seismic activity means any activity, operation or work using acoustic energy to evaluate subsurface strata. Includes all operations incident to and associated with said activity, including the surveying, drilling of boreholes, initiation of acoustic energy from sources including but not limited to explosives, vibroseis, and dropping of weights, and the recording of seismic data obtained therefrom. 
    Seismic survey means the area over which seismic activity is performed. 
    State shall mean the State of Texas, its branches, departments, agencies, boards or officers thereof. 
    Street shall mean the entire distance between the right-of-way line of any street, highway, sidewalk, alley, avenue, recessed parking area or any other public right-of-way, including the entire right-of-way. 
    Structure shall mean that which is built or constructed. The term structure shall be construed as if followed by the words or portion thereof. 
    Surface casing means the first string of casing after the conductor pipe that is set in a well, varying in length from a few hundred to several thousand feet. The primary function is to protect the freshwater bearing strata penetrated by a well, but also to provide a reliable means of controlling the well during drilling operations. 
    Treatable water or fresh water shall mean any surface and subsurface water in its natural state, which may or may not require treatment to be used for human consumption and contains less than ten thousand (10,000) parts per million total dissolved solids and/or five thousand (5,000) parts per million chlorides. 
    Truck line pipeline shall mean common carrier pipelines and other main pipelines not included in the definition of gathering lines, expressly including their rights-of-way as defined and established by instruments of records in the office of the County Clerk of Fort Bend County, Texas. 
    Water or waters of the city shall mean all streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, irrigation systems, drainage systems, and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface and underground, natural or artificial, public or private, which are contained within, flow through or border upon the city or any portion thereof. 
    Well shall mean, unless specifically qualified, any hole or holes, bore or bores, of any depth, for the purpose of producing and recovering any crude oil, condensate, natural gas, minerals or liquefied matter including fresh or salt water, or for the injection or disposal of any of the foregoing. 
    Well site shall mean the surface location of any intended well and the area occupied by all production facilities, pipelines, gathering system connections and any other equipment, dikes, and fencing incident to the drilling, completion and/or production of a well as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-3. - Oil and gas inspector. 
(a)  The city manager shall from time to time appoint a person who shall be the oil and gas inspector. The oil and gas inspector shall have the authority to issue any orders or directives required to carry out the intent and purpose of this chapter and its particular provisions. Failure of any person to comply with any such order or directive shall constitute a violation of this Code. The oil and gas inspector shall further have the authority to enter and inspect any premises covered by the provisions of this chapter to determine compliance with the provisions of this chapter and all applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards or directives of the state. Failure of any person to permit access to the oil and gas inspector shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(b)  The oil and gas inspector shall have the authority to request and receive any records, documents or other tangible items necessary to determine compliance with the terms and provisions of this Code. Any such documents received by the oil and gas inspector shall, to the extent that may be from time to time permitted by applicable law, remain confidential and at no time shall such records become a part of the records of the city, nor shall the same be copied, but shall as quickly as possible be returned to the owner thereof as soon as practicable. The failure of any person to submit the documents as herein provided shall be a violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-4. - Technical analysis. 
    The city manager shall have the authority from time to time to obtain the opinion and recommendation of a qualified geologist and/or petroleum engineer, or such other professional as shall be necessary to examine any application filed under the provisions of this chapter, to furnish the city manager oversight reports, to supervise surface pipe installation and to conduct and supervise such tests and measurements as shall be necessary to determine compliance with the terms and provisions of this chapter. All costs incurred by the city in obtaining such reports, evaluations and/or making such investigations shall be charged against the permit holder or other person seeking authority hereunder, and payment of said fees and costs shall be required as a permit fee or authorization fee for the applicant or entity to conduct further oil and gas or related activity in the city. Failure to pay to the city such costs as billed and reported to the applicant shall constitute grounds for the suspension of all permits or authorities previously issued and outstanding, and no new authority or right shall be granted until such costs and fees shall be fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-5. - Permit required. 
    It shall be an offense for any person to drill, operate or maintain any oil or gas well within the city limits of the city or to work upon or to assist in any way in such work unless the necessary permits have been approved pursuant to the terms and conditions of this chapter. Each day any work shall be performed in violation of this provision shall be a separate offense and a separate violation of this Code and shall be punished in accordance with the provisions hereof. In addition, any separate act of oil or gas activity defined herein shall be considered a separate and distinct offense whether or not the same occurred on the same or separate day from any other activity which shall form the basis for a violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-6. - Application for permit. 
(a)  The city shall from time to time prescribe and provide a form for a permit application and a form for the required consent of the several property owners owning property within five hundred (500) feet of the proposed well. The applicant shall complete the required form; however, failure by the city to prescribe or provide a form shall not relieve the applicant of compliance with a requirement to submit an application and an application should be submitted in any written format providing the information as herein required. 
(b)  A permit under this article shall be issued only to the designated operator of the oil and gas leasehold interest, and every applicant for such permit shall, at least twenty (20) days prior to the proposed commencement of such work, file with the city secretary a written application addressed to the city council for such permit. Such written application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, phone number and organizational structure of the applicant. 
(2)  The name and address of each owner of a royalty, overriding or working interest in the oil and gas lease, or unit if multiple leases are to be pooled, under which such well is to be drilled or work is to be done. 
(3)  The exact physical location of such proposed well and a street address or a descriptive general location easily identifiable by the public. 
(4)  If such proposed well is to be drilled and operated under a written pooling agreement of several leasehold estates, such area to be pooled shall be set forth and described as approved by the Railroad Commission of Texas. An approved Railroad Commission of Texas form P-12 shall be provided to the oil and gas inspector evidencing such pooling authority. 
(5)  That the owners of the surface area, exclusive of streets and alleys, located within five hundred (500) feet of the well location, including the drillsite surface owner, have all consented in writing to the drilling of such well at such location, or if they have not, a statement as to the reason for their objection or an indication of inaction. In the event the written permission of the surface owners as provided for herein cannot be obtained, no permit shall be issued. However, if the surface owner(s) as provided herein and in subsection 20-26(a) below shall rescind their written permission for the location of a well permitted pursuant to this chapter after said well has been lawfully permitted as provided for herein, said permit shall remain valid as long as applicant continues to be an operator in good standing with the city and all other regulatory bodies. Conflicts arising pursuant to this section and subsection 20-26(a) below, after such time as a permit shall be issued pursuant to this chapter shall be considered conflicts between the parties so involved and not affecting the status of any permit approved and issued by the city pursuant to this chapter prior to such dispute. The city shall at no time be called upon to resolve or settle any disputes or disagreements, and all parties must resort to arbitration and or other claims processes with private counsel as the facts would indicate or the parties may require. 
(6)  That the operator of the leasehold interests and persons in charge of the drilling, operation, maintenance and work of such proposed well are familiar with the ordinances of the city as contained in the Code of Ordinances of the city, as well as all other applicable law and will abide by the provisions thereof, and shall further abide by all other applicable laws of the State of Texas or of the United States. 
(7)  Each application shall be accompanied with a payment of a seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) fee which shall be payable to the director of finance of the City of Rosenberg which shall pay for the permit fee and the first (1st) year operation fee. 
(8)  A statement indicating the source of water to be used for drilling purposes. No fresh water well may be drilled for oil and gas drilling, completion or production purposes within the city. 
(9)  A statement indicating the exact manner of transporting the produced crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids to market in the event the permitted well is completed as a producer. 
(10)  A statement indicating the handling and loading procedures, transportation methods and disposal location to be used for wastewater, drilling mud, lubricants, lumber, trash and all other expendable products to be used during drilling, completion and production operations. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-7. - Exhibits to application. 
    In addition to the information as herein provided, each applicant shall attach to its applications the following exhibits: 
(1)  Exhibit A. A drillsite title opinion, including all run sheets generated for its preparation, prepared by an attorney licensed by the state. Said drillsite title opinion shall, at a minimum reflect the name, address and legal description of all owners of interest in real property immediately adjoining or situated within five hundred (500) feet of the lease upon which the well is to be drilled, or the unit boundary if the well is to be drilled as a unit well pursuant to subsection 20-6(b)(5) above. 
(2)  Exhibit B. A plat with detailed, scaled dimensions of the proposed well location, lot and property lines within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of such well site, with a notation or reference thereon to the surface owner of all such property as reflected in Exhibit A. 
(3)  Exhibit C. A dimensioned drawing of the proposed well site reflecting proposed well, location of drilling rig, motors, tanks and other principal equipment to be used in the drilling, completion, production, maintenance, operation and other work of such well with reference being made to property lines and structures (nature of structures being noted) located within five hundred (500) feet of such well site. 
(4)  Exhibit D. Railroad Commission of Texas form W-1 with plat, copy of the approved Railroad Commission of Texas drilling permit received by applicant and a copy of the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission form 0051 ("depth of usable quality ground water to be protected") showing depth of fresh water to be protected. 
(5)  Exhibit E. A copy of the planned flow line and alternate flow lines from the well facilities to the gas and/or oil gathering system. 
(6)  Exhibit F. A drilling and completion prognosis for the proposed well, including but not limited to the following: 
a.  Total depth, hole sizes for each casing setting depth and drilling contractor, contact name, address and phone number. 
b.  Drilling mud program, mud contractor, contact name, address and phone number. 
c.  Setting depth, size, weight in lb./ft. and API Grade of the conductor, surface, protective (if any) and production casing (if any). 
d.  Cementing procedures for each casing string including API Class, additive(s), and density in lbs./gal. and calculated twelve (12) and twenty-four (24) hour compressive strengths. Also, cementing contractor, contact name, address and phone number. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-8. - Bond. 
(a)  Every applicant for a permit under this article at the time of filing of this application shall submit a corporate surety bond in favor of the city in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) executed by the applicant and a corporate surety authorized to do business within the State of Texas subject to approval by the city manager. The required bond shall be payable to the order of the City of Rosenberg on demand and upon presentation of an order of the city council, finding and determining that an event of default has occurred and that damage has been sustained. Said bond shall be obtained and valid for each well operated by applicant and shall be conditioned that the applicant shall: 
(1)  Pay the city and discharge any liability imposed by law upon it, on account of injury to property, private or public, or person, including death, received or suffered by the city or any person resulting directly or indirectly, however remote, from the drilling, operation, maintenance, abandonment, plugging or in any other work related to such well. 
(2)  Defend the city and hold it free and harmless of all judgments, fees and expenses incident thereto, from any and all claims and causes of action arising out of the granting of such permit and the drilling, operation, maintenance, abandonment and plugging of such well. 
(3)  Pay all fees and sums due the city hereunder and comply with and abide by the ordinances of the city and all laws of the United States of America and the State of Texas, and should the applicant fail to do so, to pay all costs and expenses incident thereto, whether such failure to comply with such laws and ordinances has resulted in any damage to the city or others, and if so, pay the expenses and costs of correcting such condition created by such failure and all damages resulting therefrom. 
(b)  The city council may at any time increase or reduce the amount of each bond required as shall be necessary upon examination of the facts and circumstances relating to the proposed activity. 
(c)  In lieu of the bond as herein required, the applicant may submit a continuing irrevocable letter of credit in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) issued by a bank authorized to do business in the State of Texas. Said letter of credit shall be subject to the approval of city manager. Said letter of credit shall be issued on the basis that the applicant shall perform all conditions imposed pursuant to the terms of this Code and upon the terms and conditions as herein set out. 
(d)  Every well drilled in the city shall be covered by a corporate surety bond or letter of credit as provided herein for the entire life of the well plus twelve (12) months after abandonment and plugging. In the event bonds or letters of credit are issued on an annual basis, they shall be renewed and such bonds and letters of credit shall contain provisions that after the expiration of the term for which such bonds or letters of credit are issued, they shall cover acts and omissions which occurred during the term for which such bonds or letters of credit were issued. 
(e)  In case any bond or letter of credit required herein shall lapse or become void for any reason whatsoever, the permit issued under the terms of this article shall immediately become inoperative and void until a new bond or letter of credit shall be provided and filed with the city secretary of the city or the existing bond or letter of credit reinstated in full force, and the city manager shall have the power and authority to suspend any permit on any well that is not covered by such bond or letter of credit and to shut down the operation of such well until complete compliance with the terms and provisions herein shall occur. 
(f)  All bonds or letters of credit shall be approved by the city manager or the designee of the city manager and endorsed thereon. The city attorney shall approve all bonds or letters of credit as to form. 
(g)  All bonds or letters of credit required herein shall be in addition to any bonds, letters of credit or other financial instruments required by any other state or federal jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-9. - Liability insurance. 
(a)  Before a permit shall be issued under this provision, the applicant shall file with the city secretary a certificate of insurance which shall be issued by a company licensed and authorized to do business in the State of Texas and shall provide public liability insurance coverage for each operation required in the conduct of such work. Such insurance policy shall be in the amount of at least one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) insuring the applicant and the city against all claims or causes of action made against either or both applicant and city for damages to persons or property arising out of the drilling, completion maintenance, operation, production or other work done with respect to such proposed oil and gas well. Insurance provided pursuant to this section shall be issued on an occurrence form and shall include, as a minimum the following coverages: 
(1)  General aggregate limit ..... $1,000,000.00 
(2)  Completed operations aggregate limit ..... 1,000,000.00 
(3)  Personal injury limit ..... 1,000,000.00 
(4)  Each occurrence ..... 1,000,000.00 
    Insurance coverages shall include, at a minimum: 
(1)  Premises/operations. 
(2)  Products/completed operations. 
(3)  Personal injury. 
(4)  Fire damage legal liability. 
(5)  Broad form property damage liability. 
(6)  Underground resources and equipment. 
(7)  Seepage and pollution (minimum 30 day discovery/90 day reporting). 
(8)  Blanket waiver of subrogation. 
(9)  Blanket additional insured. 
(10)  Sudden and accidental pollution. 
(b)  Such policy cannot be canceled until thirty (30) days written notice of such cancellation is given to the city secretary by the issuing insurance company, and such policy shall carry an endorsement of actual notice to the city of any changes therein given to the city secretary by the issuing company. 
(c)  Such insurance policy shall be approved by the city manager and the city attorney as to form and as to the issuing insurance company and endorsed thereon. 
(d)  Such insurance policy shall be issued for the use and benefit and protection of the city and for the use and benefit and protection of any person who may suffer injury either to his/her person or property by reason of an accident or omission or negligence of any person, agents or servants, engaged in such work. If such policy is approved by the city manager, it shall remain in force and effect during the term of all oil and gas activity contemplated under the terms and provisions of this chapter or until a substitute policy shall be approved in accordance with the procedures set out herein. 
(e)  All insurance policy or policies shall provide that they may not be canceled without written notice to the city secretary by the issuing insurance company at least thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of such cancellation. In the event said policy or policies are canceled, the permit granted under this chapter shall immediately terminate without any action on the part of the city and the applicant/permittee's rights to operate under said permit shall cease until the applicant/permittee files additional insurance as required herein. Any attempt to operate without adequate and appropriate insurance coverage shall be a violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-10. - Operator's extra expense insurance. 
    Before a permit shall be issued under this provision, the applicant shall file with the city secretary a certificate of insurance which shall be issued by a company licensed and authorized to do business in the State of Texas which shall provide operator's extra expense insurance coverage, also known as "blowout insurance." Such insurance policy shall be in the amount of at least ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00) insuring the applicant and the city against all claims or causes of action made against either or both applicant and city for damages to persons or property arising out of the drilling, completion maintenance, operation, production or other work done with respect to such proposed oil and gas well. Insurance provided pursuant to this section shall be issued on an occurrence form and shall include, as a minimum the following coverages: 
(1)  Control of well. 
(2)  Underground blowout. 
(3)  Pollution. 
(4)  Deliberate well firing. 
(5)  Farmout and farming clauses. 
(6)  Contingent joint venture liability. 
(7)  Turnkey endorsement. 
(8)  Punitive damages clause. 
(9)  Blanket waiver of subrogation. 
(10)  Blanket additional insured in lieu of operator's extra expense insurance as herein required, the applicant may submit a continuing irrevocable letter of credit in the amount of ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00) issued by a bank authorized to do business in the State of Texas. Said letter of credit shall be subject to the approval of the city manager. Said letter of credit shall be issued on the basis that the applicant shall perform all conditions imposed pursuant to the terms of this Code and upon the terms and conditions as specifically set out in this section 20-10. The irrevocable letter of credit submitted by applicant in lieu of operator's extra expense insurance as required by this section 20-10 shall be in addition to, and not considered a substitute for the corporate surety bond required by section 20-8 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-11. - Notice to be published; public hearing to be held. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application, bond and insurance certificate under this article, the city council shall cause a notice of such application to be published in three (3) consecutive issues of an official newspaper of the city printed and having a general circulation within the city. The notice shall state the name of the applicant, the proposed location of the well, a reasonable description of the activity sought to be permitted and the date and place of the hearing of the city council on such application, at which time and place such application shall be considered. Applicant shall pay all costs associated with said filing in the official newspaper of the city. 
(b)  To the extent practicable, a hearing on the application may be held at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the city council after the date of the last publication of such notice. Upon hearing such application, the city council may authorize the city secretary to issue a permit for drilling, operation and maintenance of a well; provided, however, the city council shall not be required to approve a permit when the city council finds and determines that such approval is not in the best interests of the residents, citizens and inhabitants of the city. No decision by the city council to disapprove an application for a permit shall at any time be subject to appeal or review before any other authority, it being the intention of the city council to be the body having exclusive control over permits and the issuance thereof. 
(c)  The city council shall have the power and reserves the authority to refuse any application for a permit where, by reason of the location of the proposed well and the character and value of the permanent improvements in its vicinity, and the use to which the land and surroundings are adapted for civic or other purposes, or for other reasons the city council considers, such proposed well, based upon the facts and circumstances of the application and all relevant facts relating thereto, is likely to result in a hazard to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(d)  When a permit shall have been issued, the same shall terminate and become inoperative without any action on the part of the city council unless within one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of issuance the actual drilling of a well or wells has been commenced; and after drilling of a well has commenced, the cessation for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days of drilling operations, or the cessation of production of oil and gas from the well after production shall have commenced, shall operate to terminate and cancel the permit and the well shall be considered as abandoned for the purposes of this article. It shall be unlawful thereafter to continue the operation or drilling of such well without the issuance of another permit. The requirement herein for drilling shall mean the placing of a drilling rig capable of drilling to the total depth permitted and approved by the Railroad Commission of Texas on the permitted location and the actual act of placing a bit into the ground attached to an appropriate drill string, initiation of drilling procedures and operations, and the continuous drilling of said well to the permitted depth. The mere act of storing equipment, supplies or materials on-site, including the setting up in preparation for drilling, shall not be deemed drilling herein. 
(e)  When a permit is issued under the terms of this chapter, it shall: 
(1)  Incorporate by reference all the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Incorporate by reference all the provisions of applicable state law and the rules, regulations and standards adopted in accordance therewith relating to the protection of person, animals and natural resources. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-12. - Refusal of permit; cancellation of application and a conditional permit. 
(a)  If the permit be refused, or if the applicant notifies the city secretary in writing that it does not elect to accept the permit as tendered and wishes to withdraw its application, or if the bonds, insurance or letter of credit of the applicant are not approved, then upon the happening of any of said events, the cash fee filed with the application shall be refunded to the applicant, except that there shall be retained therefrom by the city an amount not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) as a processing fee. 
(b)  The city council may impose such conditions, limitations and/or requirements as deemed necessary and desirable to preserve the health, safety and welfare of the residents, citizens and inhabitants of the city on the issuance of any permit which if so prescribed shall become a part of the permit and shall be complied with as a condition precedent to the continuing validity of any permit issued hereunder. In the event the applicant shall refuse to accept a permit because of conditions imposed by the city council, the cash fee filed with the application shall be refunded to the applicant, except an amount not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) which shall be retained by the city as a processing fee. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-13. - Renewal fees. 
    Every applicant who has been granted a permit as provided for in this article shall pay to the director of finance of the city at least thirty (30) days before the anniversary date of the expiration of such permit an amount equal to one-half (1/2) of the permit fee in such amount as the same may be set and/or determined by the city council for renewal of the annual permit. The remaining one-half (1/2) of the permit fee shall be paid at such time as the permit shall be renewed. Annually, at such time that permittee renews its permit and pays the annual renewal fee, permittee shall submit to the oil and gas inspector the following: 
(1)  Spill prevention control and contingency plan ("SPCC Plan") for each facility as prepared for and required by the U.S. Clean Water Act as amended. Said SPCC Plan shall be complete and executed by a licensed professional engineer as required by the applicable provisions of the U.S. Clean Water Act. 
(2)  Texas Community Right-To-Know Act ("TCRA") Tier II filings as required by the Texas Department of Health for each facility for which permittee is applying for an operating permit. 
(3)  Updated emergency contact list for permittee, operator and contractors. 
(4)  Railroad Commission of Texas form P-5. 
(5)  Railroad Commission of Texas form P-4 for each facility if the purchaser of crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids has changed from the filing made by permittee in the previous year. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-14. - Release of bonds and insurance on abandonment or sale of well. 
    Upon the abandonment or sale of any operating well, the city secretary will release certificates of insurance and bonds only upon the presentation of new certificates presented by the purchaser of said well or wells. A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per well will be charged as a processing fee. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-15. - Order to cease operations. 
(a)  The oil and gas inspector shall have the power at any time to order the cessation of operations. If the oil and gas inspector shall determine that operations shall cease, said inspector shall provide a notice to show cause to the operator of said well and shall deliver the original to the city manager who shall set a hearing to be held not longer than twenty-four (24) hours after the issuance of said order by the oil and gas inspector. The order issued by the oil and gas inspector shall be final and valid as of the date of issuance and the hearing as herein provided shall occur within the period as herein provided. 
(b)  The city manager shall determine if proper cause exists, and if not, shall order the permitted activity to resume without delay. If the city manager determines that proper cause does exist for order to cease activity, then the city manager shall make whatever ruling is proper to assure rectification of the cause of any peril. Such ruling and compliance with the permit by the permittee shall not be construed to absolve the permittee of any liability for any violation of this chapter or for any damage caused as a result thereof. 
(c)  The city manager may designate a hearing officer to conduct such hearings. 
(d)  Any person aggrieved by any order of the city manager may request a hearing before the city council, and the city council shall proceed as hereinafter provided. Prior to a hearing before the city council, all relevant documents and exhibits made a part of any prior hearing shall be delivered to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-16. - Appeals. 
    Any permittee aggrieved by any order, directive or ruling issued by the oil and gas inspector or by any ruling by the city manager may appeal the same to the city council which shall hear the matter at a meeting of the city council to occur not more than thirty (30) days from the date the appeal shall be filed. Any persons seeking to appeal as herein provided shall file a notice of appeal with the city secretary and such appeal shall not stay the enforcement of any provisions of this chapter. The city council, upon hearing the matter, shall consider the facts and evidence presented at the hearing and shall, upon the completion of all proceedings, enter a final and binding order which shall not be appealable to any other body or tribunal. Any appeal to the city council from action taken shall be commenced by filing with the city secretary a notice of appeal in writing within ten (10) days from the date of complaint of the order or decision. Failure to commence an appeal timely shall render the prior decision of either the oil and gas inspector or the city manager final and binding and not subject to appeal or other proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-17. - Seismic activities. 
    It shall be an offense for any person or party to conduct any seismic activities within the city limits without first obtaining the necessary seismic permit as required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-18. - Application for seismic permit. 
(a)  The city shall prescribe and provide a form for a seismic permit application and a form for the required consent of all property owners owning property within five hundred (500) feet of the proposed seismic survey. The applicant shall complete the required forms; however, failure by the city to prescribe or provide a form shall not relieve the applicant of compliance with a requirement to submit an application and an application should be submitted in any written format providing the information as herein required. 
(b)  A permit under this article shall be issued only to the designated operator of the oil and gas leasehold interest, and every applicant for such permit shall, at least twenty (20) days prior to the proposed commencement of such work, file with the city secretary a written application addressed to the city council for such permit. Such written application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, phone number and organizational structure of the applicant. 
(2)  The name and address of each owner of a mineral, royalty or working interest in the lands comprising the proposed seismic survey under which the applicant has been granted authority to conduct said seismic survey. 
(3)  The exact physical location of the proposed seismic survey and a descriptive general location including streets, subdivisions and known landmarks easily identifiable by the public. 
(4)  Evidence that the owners of the surface area, exclusive of streets and alleys, within five hundred (500) feet of all lands comprising the proposed seismic survey have consented in writing to the proposed seismic survey, or if they have not, a statement as to the reason for their objection or an indication of inaction. 
(5)  That the applicant and the owners of the leasehold interests, options or rights are familiar with the ordinances of the city as contained in the Code of Ordinances of the city, as well as all other applicable law and will abide by the provisions thereof, and shall further abide by all other applicable laws of the State of Texas or of the United States. 
(6)  Each application shall be accompanied with a payment of a three thousand five hundred dollar ($3,500.00) fee which shall be payable to the director of finance of the City of Rosenberg which shall pay for the seismic permit fee which shall be valid for one (1) year. 
(7)  A statement indicating that explosives will not be used during the seismic survey operations. Explosives are illegal within the city limits. 
(8)  A statement indicating the exact manner in which the proposed seismic survey is to be conducted. This statement should present the order and the length of time required for each line that will be surveyed, laid out, shot, picked up and remediated. It shall also present the overall time schedule for the proposed seismic survey from initial field surveying through site remediation. 
(9)  A statement indicating the energy source to be used in the conducting of the seismic survey. 
(10)  A statement indicating the handling and loading procedures, transportation methods and disposal location to be used for wastewater, lumber, trash and all other expendable products to be used during the proposed seismic operations. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-19. - Exhibits to seismic application. 
    In addition to the information as herein provided, each applicant shall attach to its applications the following exhibits: 
(1)  Exhibit A: A survey title opinion including all run sheets generated for its preparation, prepared by an attorney licensed by the state and which was relied upon by applicant to notify and to obtain the permission of the surface owners required in subsection 20-6(b)(2) and (6) above. Said survey title opinion shall, at a minimum reflect the name, address and legal description of all owners of interest in real property immediately adjoining or situated within five hundred (500) feet of the proposed seismic survey. 
(2)  Exhibit B: A plat with detailed, scaled dimensions of all proposed survey lines in the seismic survey. All lot and property lines within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of the proposed seismic survey shall be included with a notation or reference thereon to the surface owner of all such property as reflected in exhibit A of this section. 
(3)  Exhibit C: The name, address and phone number of the geophysical contractor to be used for the proposed seismic survey. 
(4)  Exhibit D: The permittee shall identify the maximum length, width and weight of any motor vehicles and the maximum weight of the load to be carried by any motor vehicles to be used in traveling to and from the seismic survey area. The permittee shall include a complete list of the proposed routes to and from the well site for all motor vehicles to be used to travel to and from the well site. Such list shall identify any and all highways within the limits of the city, including public streets and roadways, proposed to be used by such motor vehicles in traveling to and from the seismic survey area. This exhibit shall also identify all locations where motor vehicles to be used in conducting the seismic survey will exit any of the city roadways for use off road. All such roadway exits shall identify the means proposed by the applicant for the building of exits from the city roadways including the proposed installation of culverts, bridges, cattleguards, fences and gates necessary to safely allow motor vehicles associated with the seismic survey operations to access off road work sites without hindering or blocking the natural drainage in such areas. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-20. - Bond. 
    Every applicant for a seismic permit under this article shall submit a corporate surety bond in favor of the city as provided for in section 20-8 above. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-21. - Liability insurance. 
    Every applicant for a seismic permit under this article shall file with the city secretary a certificate of insurance which shall be issued by a company licensed and authorized to do business in the State of Texas and shall provide public liability insurance coverage for each operation required in the conduct all work associated with proposed seismic survey as provided for in section 20-9 above. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-22. - Notice to be published; public hearing to be held. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a seismic permit, bond and insurance certificate as provided for under this article, the city council shall cause a notice of such application to be published in three (3) consecutive issues of an official newspaper of the city printed and having a general circulation within the city. The notice shall state the name of the applicant, the proposed location of the seismic survey, a reasonable description of the activity sought to be permitted and the date and place of the hearing of the city council on such application, at which time and place such application shall be considered. Applicant shall pay all costs associated with said filing in the official newspaper of the city. 
(b)  To the extent practicable, a hearing on the application may be held at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the city council after the date of the last publication of such notice. Upon hearing such application, the city council may authorize the city secretary to issue a permit for the conducting of a seismic survey as proposed by applicant; provided, however, the city council shall not be required to approve a permit when the city council finds and determines that such approval is not in the best interests of the residents, citizens and inhabitants of the city. No decision by the city council to disapprove an application for a permit shall at any time be subject to appeal or review before any other authority, it being the intention of the city council to be the body having exclusive control over permits and the issuance thereof. 
(c)  The city council shall have the power and reserves the authority to refuse any application for a permit where, by reason of the location of the proposed seismic survey and the character and value of the permanent improvements in its vicinity, and the use to which the land and surroundings are adapted for civic or other purposes, or for other reasons the city council considers, such proposed seismic survey, based upon the facts and circumstances of the application and all relevant facts relating thereto, is likely to result in a hazard to the public health, safety and welfare. 
(d)  When a permit is issued under the terms of this chapter, it shall: 
(1)  Incorporate by reference all the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Incorporate by reference all the provisions of applicable state law and the rules, regulations and standards adopted in accordance therewith relating to the protection of person, animals and natural resources. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 20-23-20-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPERATION AND EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 20-26. - Well site location. 
(a)  No well site shall be located or shall any tank batteries, well facilities or equipment be located and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location unless the owners of all of the surface area, exclusive of streets and alleys, within five hundred (500) feet of the proposed well, including the surface owner of the drillsite tract, shall have consented in writing to the drilling of such well at such location or the city council finds that the failure of the applicant to obtain written consent is not based upon neglect by the applicant. The distance shall be calculated from the closest proposed edge of the wellsite location in Exhibit C provided by applicant in subsection 20-7(3) above, to the closest exterior point of the dwelling or other subject building. In the event that applicant cannot obtain the consent of the surface owner(s) as provided for herein, the city shall not issue a permit until such time that written permission by the parties required by this section have been obtained by applicant. 
(b)  No well site shall be located or shall any tank batteries, well facilities or equipment be located and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location which is located in a residential subdivision platted of record, nor nearer than two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet to any public building, church, public park, store or place of business. The distance shall be calculated from the well bore, tank batteries, well facilities or equipment closest to the residential subdivision to the closest exterior point of the lot or tract of land currently in use for a public building or religious building. 
(c)  No well site shall be located or shall any tank batteries, well facilities or equipment and no permit shall be issued for any wells to be drilled at any location which is closer than five thousand (5,000) feet to any residence or lot used for residential purposes, unless applicant has obtained the written permission of all surface owners within said five thousand (5,000) foot radius of the proposed wellbore. The distance shall be calculated from the well bore, tank batteries, well facilities or equipment closest to the residence or lot used for residential purposes to the closest exterior point of a lot in residential use. In the event permission is rescinded by a surface owner(s) after the issuance of a permit pursuant to this chapter, the permit shall continue in force and effect as if such permission had not been rescinded as long as applicant remains an operator in good standing with the city and other regulatory agencies. 
(d)  No well site shall be located and no permit shall be issued for any wells to be drilled at any location which is nearer than one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet to any private fresh water well that has not been abandoned. Additionally, no well site shall be located and no permit shall be issued for any wells to be drilled at any location which is nearer than two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet to any municipal water well. The city manager with the consent of the city council shall have the power from time to time to designate sites for future water well development and drilling. The provisions and restrictions as herein set out shall be equally applicable to an existing well as well as a site so designated by the action of the city manager with the consent and permission of the city council. The distances provided for in this section shall be calculated from the well bore of the proposed well to the fresh water well bore. In the event of conflict in this provision with any statute, rule or requirement of the Texas Natural Resource Conservation Commission, it is the intent of the city council that the more restrictive provision shall control. 
(e)  The provisions of this section shall also apply to any dwellings, public buildings under construction and to any fresh water wells being drilled on the date the application for a permit is filed with the oil and gas inspector. 
(f)  The application of the provisions of this section and this Code, as they may relate to a proposed well, shall be determined by examining the existing uses of the surrounding property as of the date an application for a permit is filed with the oil and gas inspector. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-27. - Location of wells in streets and alleys; blocking or closing. 
    No well site shall be located and no permit shall be issued for any well to be drilled at any location which is within the right-of-way boundaries of any streets or alleys of the city. No street or alley shall be blocked, encumbered or closed in any drilling or production operation except upon the written approval as granted by the city council, or in the case of an emergency situation with written approval of the oil and gas inspector, and then only temporarily. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-28. - Determination of routes to well site. 
(a)  At least twenty (20) days prior to the actual commencement of any operations at the well site, the permittee shall notify the oil and gas inspector in writing of the proposed date for commencement of drilling operations. Such notification shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The permittee shall identify the maximum length, width and weight of any motor vehicles and the maximum weight of the load to be carried by any motor vehicles to be used in traveling to and from the well site. 
(2)  The permittee shall submit a complete list of the proposed routes to and from the well site for all motor vehicles to be used to travel to and from the well site. Such list shall identify any and all highways within the limits of the city, including public streets and roadways, proposed to be used by such motor vehicles in traveling to and from the well site. 
(b)  The oil and gas inspector shall be authorized at any time to require any additional information, which is deemed necessary to evaluate the proposed routes. 
(c)  The oil and gas inspector shall, as promptly as practicable after receipt of the completed application and all other required information, review the information submitted by the permittee. Following review of such information, the oil and gas inspector shall prepare a written order which either approves or disapproves the routes to and from the well site as proposed by said permittee. If the oil and gas inspector disapproves of all or part of the proposed routes, then such inspector shall designate alternate routes which are acceptable to the city. During all drilling and production activities for the particular well, all motor vehicles used by any person to travel to and from the well site shall be restricted to the highways approved by the oil and gas inspector as appropriate routes to and from the well site. The oil and gas inspector shall have the power and authority at any time to amend the order designating routes to and from the well site upon his/her own initiative or upon application by the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-29. - Drilling equipment. 
(a)  All drilling, reentry, completion and production operations at any oil and gas well within the city limits shall be conducted in accordance with the best available technology. All casing, valves, blowout preventers, drilling fluids, tubing, bradenhead, Christmas trees and wellhead connections shall be of the type and quality consistent with the best available technology. The setting and cementing of casing and running of drill stem tests shall be performed in a manner and at all times consistent with the best available technology. All persons engaged in drilling or production operations shall observe and follow the recommendations or regulations of the American Petroleum Institute and the Railroad Commission of Texas, except in those instances that are specifically addressed by this chapter or otherwise provided for by law. 
(b)  Blowout prevention equipment shall be used on all wells being drilled, worked over, or in which tubing is being changed. Wells being drilled shall have at least three (3) hydraulically operated blowout preventers installed and these blowout preventers shall meet, at the minimum, the American Petroleum Institute recommendation for class 3M blowout preventers. Wells being drilled shall also have a kill line, choke line and choke manifold, which meet the recommendations of the American Petroleum Institute for class 3M blowout prevention equipment. In no case shall blowout preventers, choke manifold(s), and associated well control equipment be used that is not rated for the pressures that could be reasonably expected by a prudent operator during the drilling, completion or workover operations on any well in the city. The oil and gas inspector shall have the authority to require the installation and use of higher pressure rated well control equipment, if in his sole opinion, the equipment in use or to be used by the operator of any well in the city is insufficient for a potential well control problem. All well control equipment shall be tested to full working pressure upon installation, and thereafter, tested to full working pressure not less than weekly. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-30. - Surface casing. 
(a)  All oil and gas wells in the city shall be cased and casing cemented from the top of such well hole to a depth not less than that required by the oil and gas inspector to protect all fresh water zones penetrated by said wells. Such casing, commonly referred to as surface pipe, shall be set and cemented as aforesaid prior to drilling such well beyond the depth of such surface pipe. A copy of all openhole and cased hole logs associated with the drilling of the surface casing hole and the running, cementing and testing of the surface casing shall be filed with the oil and gas inspector. 
(b)  The permittee shall notify the city manager at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to running the surface casing for the purpose of permitting the oil and gas inspector or other authorized representatives of the city to inspect such pipe on the wellsite location. At least four (4) hours and not more than eight (8) hours before commencing the running and cementing of the surface casing, the oil and gas inspector shall be notified thereof in order that a representative of the city may observe such procedure.
