No pipe shall be used unless approved by the city manager or other authorized representative of the city and the cementing of such pipe shall be done in the presence of such representative and approved by such representative. The running, cementing and testing of all surface casing shall be done in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  Surface casing shall be set a minimum depth of that required by the Texas Natural Resources Conservation Commission on form 0051. The permittee shall notify the oil and gas inspector at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to running the surface casing for the purpose of allowing the oil and gas inspector, or other authorized representative(s) of the city to inspect such casing on the wellsite location. Surface casing must be new and at a minimum API grade J or K with a minimum burst pressure rating of two thousand nine hundred (2,900) psig. The surface casing shall have a centralizer in the middle of the shoe joint, a centralizer on the top of the second joint of casing and centralizers no more than two hundred (200) feet apart above the second centralizer. Surface casing shall have a guide shoe installed on the bottom of the first joint of casing and float collar shall be installed within ninety (90) feet of the guide shoe to prevent the backflow of cement through the casing. No cement baskets may be installed on the surface casing. 
(2)  The cement to be used to cement the surface casing shall be API Class C, or equivalent, and tested prior to pumping to a minimum compressive strength of at least five hundred (500) psig in eight (8) hours and fifteen hundred (1,500) psig in twenty-four (24) hours. The results of the compressive strength testing shall be provided to the oil and gas inspector at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the pumping of the surface casing cement. 
(3)  At least four (4) hours prior to commencing the cementing of the surface casing, the oil and gas inspector shall be notified in order that a representative of the city may observe such cementing operation. Surface casing shall be cemented by to the surface by normal displacement practices. If cement is not circulated to the surface, the existing cement shall not be over displaced and a plug of cement shall be left in the bottom of the casing string to be drilled out once the surface casing cement is set. The remaining open hole behind the surface casing shall be cemented by running a tubing string between the conductor string and the surface pipe until the top of the primary cement is tagged. The remaining uncemented annular space shall then be cemented until good cement is circulated to the surface. The surface casing shall not be disturbed in any way until the cement has set for a minimum of eight (8) hours, or as long as required to for the cement to reach a minimum compressive strength of five hundred (500) psig based upon the test results of the actual cement slurry(s). The oil and gas inspector may require log(s) to be run to determine the top of good cement, if in the oil and gas inspector's opinion, the possibility exists that the fresh water zones so cemented have not been adequately cemented. 
(4)  Within thirty (30) days of completion or plugging of the well, permittee shall file with the oil and gas inspector a Railroad Commission of Texas form W-15, properly completed and signed by the cementing company, for the surface casing cement operation. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-31. - Pits. 
    Steel mud or circulating pits shall be used. Such pits and contents shall be removed from the premises and the drilling site within sixty (60) days after completion of the well. No earthen pits shall be allowed unless small and temporary. All such earthen pits must be lined and approved in writing by the oil and gas inspector. Catch basin pits shall be used only for the purpose of catching any deleterious substance runoff and shall be no greater than three hundred twenty (320) cubic feet. Emergency pits shall be emptied as soon as the emergency is over and all such pits shall be emptied and then leveled within fifteen (15) days after completion of the well. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-32. - Noise and other nuisances. 
    All drilling and production operations shall be conducted in such a manner as to eliminate, as much as possible, dust, noise, vibration or noxious odors, and shall be in accordance with the best available technology incident to exploration for, drilling for and production of oil, gas and other hydrocarbon substances. Proven technological improvements in exploration, drilling and production methods shall be adopted as they become available, if capable of reducing factors of nuisance and annoyance. State-of-the-art baffles and sound arresters must be used if the noise being emitted from any operations is greater than the prevailing noise in or adjacent to the area being used for oil and gas permitted operations. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-33. - Fire prevention. 
    All permittees under the provisions of this chapter shall maintain adequate firefighting apparatus and supplies at the well site at all times during drilling and production operations. Adequate firefighting apparatus and supplies shall include, but shall not be limited to, all of the following: 
(1)  During drilling operations, the permittee shall provide a minimum of four (4) portable fire extinguishers, the size, rating, distribution and maintenance of which shall be in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association Standard No. 10, entitled Portable Fire Extinguishers, and National Fire Protection Association Standard No. 30, entitled Flammable Liquids Code. 
(2)  Sources of ignition. In locations where flammable vapors may be present, precautions shall be taken to prevent ignition by eliminating or controlling sources of ignition. Sources of ignition may include open flames, lightning, smoking, cutting and welding, hot surfaces, frictional heat, sparks (static, electrical and mechanical) spontaneous ignition, chemical and physical-chemical reactions and radiant heat. National Fire Protection Association Standard No. 77, Recommended Practice of Static Electricity, and National Fire Protection Association Standard No. 78, Lightning Protection Code, and National Fire Protection Association Standard No. 70, provide information on such protection. 
(3)  The permittee shall protect all hazardous materials and/or special hazards at the well site in accordance with applicable National Fire Protection Association standards and all other applicable codes adopted by the city. 
(4)  The permittee shall also comply with such other requirements which the oil and gas inspector or the city fire marshal may prescribe for the particular well. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-34. - Disposal of mud. 
    The disposal of drilling mud shall be by transporting the mud to a state-licensed disposal site and permittee shall provide the city with a receipt issued by such state-licensed disposal site. The mud may not be buried in an earthen pit, pumped down the well bore or down the annulus of a well, nor spread on the surface of the ground within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-35. - Affidavit upon completion of well. 
    Upon completion of the well, the operator shall certify by affidavit that the well has been set according to good engineering practices. The affidavit shall stipulate the number of sacks of cement, the class of cement, blended materials, weight of cement in pounds per gallon, cement displacement pressure, final pumping pressure and whether check valves (float shoes, float collar) held the pressure. Commencement and completion times of such operation shall be stipulated. All variances to the drilling and completion prognosis submitted to the oil and gas inspector in subsection 20-17(7) shall be noted. The affidavit shall include, as attachments: 
(1)  Railroad Commission of Texas form(s) W-15 properly completed by a cementing service company for each casing string set and cemented and signed by both the operator and the cementing service company. 
(2)  A Railroad Commission of Texas form W-12 providing the inclination profile of the well and all directional surveys if run. 
(3)  A Railroad Commission of Texas form W-3 if the well was plugged and abandoned or a Railroad Commission of Texas form G-1 (gas well) or Railroad Commission of Texas form W-2 (oil well) if the well was completed as a producing well. 
(4)  Said affidavit and attachments shall be submitted to the oil and gas inspector within thirty (30) days of abandonment or completion of the well. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-36. - Open hole formation or drill stem testing. 
(a)  All open hole drill stem testing shall be done only during daylight hours, with a minimum of four (4) hours advance notification thereof to the oil and gas inspector to enable said inspector to be present during such testing. 
(b)  All open hole drill stem testing shall be done into a test separator equipped with a liquid line to a steel tank(s) and with a gas flare line equipped with an electronic ignition device. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-37. - Fracturing and acidizing. 
    In the event an oil or gas, injection, disposal or service well requires acidizing, fracturing, frac packing or any other stimulation or sand control procedure requiring the use of chemicals, fluids or proppants not used in the normal course of well completion or production operations, a procedure prognosis shall be submitted to the oil and gas inspector at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to said operation. Said prognosis shall provide the chemicals and proppants to be used, the amount of each chemical and proppant size, the surface treating pressure(s) anticipated that said chemicals and proppants will be pumped and the amount of treating equipment planned to be on-site during said operation. The oil and gas inspector shall have the right to restrict the type or amount of chemicals used or restrict the amount of equipment if in his sole opinion that the health, safety or comfort of the residents of the city could be compromised by the originally planned operation. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-38. - Swabbing, bailing and purging wells. 
(a)  In swabbing, bailing or purging a well, all deleterious substances removed from the bore hole shall be flowed into or placed in steel tanks, and no substances shall be permitted to pollute any surface or subsurface fresh waters. The permittee and operator shall also comply with all other provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  No well shall be swabbed before a lubricator has been installed on the casing or tree of a well above all outlets or flow line from the well. The lubricator shall not be less in diameter than the flow casing and equipped with a stuffing box on the top. The total inside length of the lubricator shall not be less than five (5) feet more than the total length of the swab assembly and turn back on the swab line. All equipment and parts of the lubricator shall be of a type designed and tested to withstand a pressure of three thousand (3,000) psig. All lubricators shall be tested to full working pressure, either in a test tank prior to being brought out to location or on location after being installed on the well to be swabbed, bailed or purged. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-39. - Rupture in surface or production casing. 
(a)  In the event a rupture, break or opening occurs in the surface or production casing, the permittee or the operator or drilling contractor shall promptly report the incident to the oil and gas inspector. The permittee shall take immediate action to repair such casing and provide to the oil and gas inspector the procedure to be taken to correct the rupture. The oil and gas inspector shall witness all repairs undertaken by permittee under the section. 
(b)  If in the sole opinion of the oil and gas inspector, permittee or permittee's designated representative is not adequately or timely working to correct the casing rupture, the oil and gas inspector may employ, engage or otherwise contract with a third party well control contractor to make, supervise or coordinate said repairs. All costs associated with the engagement of such third party contractors shall be borne by the permittee. The city shall have a valid lien against the interest in the well of the operator, permittee and all working interest owners who have voluntarily joined in the drilling of such well to secure payment of any expenditure so made by the city pursuant to this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-40. - Depositing oil products. 
    No person shall deposit, drain or divert into or upon any public highway, street, alley, drainage ditch, storm drain, sewer, gutter, paving, creek, river, lake or lagoon, any oil or oily liquid with petroleum content or any mud, rotary mud, sand, water or salt water, or in any manner permit by seepage, overflow or otherwise, any of such substances to escape from any property owned, leased or controlled by such person and flow or be carried into or upon any public highway, street alley, drainage ditch, storm drain, sewer, gutter, paving, creek, river, lake or lagoon within the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-41. - Flaring of gas. 
    All produced gas shall either be sold or flared with the flaring procedures being approved by the oil and gas inspector and the city fire marshal. If in the sole opinion of the oil and gas inspector, the amount of gas being flared by permittee is excessive and the health, safety or comfort of the residents of the city may be in danger, the oil and gas inspector may require permittee to install a vapor recovery system or similar technology to reduce or eliminate the volume of gas so flared. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-42. - Damage to public property. 
    Any damage to paving, sidewalks, streets, alleys, curbing, parking, sewers or other public property arising out of any work relating to any oil or gas well shall be repaired immediately by the holder of the permit for such well, and such repairs shall be made in accordance with the requirements of the city manager or the oil and gas inspector. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-43. - Facilities. 
(a)  All lease equipment shall be painted and maintained in a good state of appearance and shall have posted in a prominent place a metal sign not less than two (2) feet square in area which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Permittees name. 
(2)  Appropriate phone numbers, including a phone number or numbers that are answered twenty-four (24) hours a day seven (7) days a week. 
(3)  Lease name. 
(4)  Location of the drill site by reference to the United States Survey. 
(5)  Identifying numbers of all permits, including the city permit number and the Railroad Commission of Texas permit number. 
(b)  The oil and gas inspector shall also have the power and authority to enforce orders of the city council to require such general landscaping of all well sites as it deems necessary. The phrase general landscaping shall mean the aesthetic improvement of land by adding trees, shrubs, lawns, ground cover and other appropriate landscaping features. 
(c)  All pumps, tanks and lease equipment used in the operation of a completed oil or gas well shall be enclosed on all sides by either a sightproof wooden stockade fence at least six (6) feet in height or a woven wire fence of not less than nine-gauge chainlink wire mesh of not less than two (2) inches, at least six (6) feet high, with additional angular extension outwardly secured by three (3) strands of barbed wire. Such fence shall be constructed not less than three (3) feet from outside the base of embankment within ninety (90) days of completion of the drill site, or erection of storage tanks, whichever occurs first. All gates thereto shall be kept locked when authorized persons are not within the enclosure. During drilling operations, a watchman shall be maintained on the premises at all times who shall be charged with the responsibility of protecting the general public from any hazard resulting from the conduct of such drilling operations. If such watchman is not employed, then the entire well location shall be fenced as in the operation of a completed well. The oil and gas inspector is empowered to determine which type of fencing is best and to require the same for any particular location. 
(d)  Lease roads shall be maintained in such manner as to allow for safe and comfortable ingress and egress of city or other governmental personnel traveling in a common passenger motor vehicle. All lease roads shall have a locked gate to prevent unauthorized personnel from entering. Provided however, that the terms of this section shall not in any way restrict any surface owner on whom the lease road is located, from the right of ingress or egress if so entitled. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-44. - Motive power. 
    Motive power for all well pumping equipment shall be electricity. The oil and gas inspector shall have authority to waive the requirements of this section if it is determined that in a particular case electric pumping equipment is not necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-45. - Loss of well control. 
    In the event of loss of control of any well, the operator shall immediately take all reasonable steps to regain control of such well, regardless of any other provision of this chapter, and shall notify the oil and gas inspector as soon as practicable after receipt of notice by his employees of the occurrence of such loss of well control. If and when the oil and gas inspector certifies in writing to the city secretary that, in his opinion, danger to persons or property exists because of such loss of well control (briefly describing the same) and the operator is not taking, or is unable to take, all reasonable necessary steps to regain control of such well, the oil and gas inspector may employ any well control experts or other contractors or suppliers of special services, or may incur any other expenses for labor or material which the oil and gas inspector deems necessary to regain control of such well. The city shall have a valid lien against the interest in the well of all working interest owners who have voluntarily joined in the drilling of such well to secure payment of any expenditure so made by the city pursuant to the above provisions. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-46. - Storage tanks and separators. 
(a)  Crude oil storage tanks shall not be constructed, operated or used except to the extent of two (2) low type steel tanks for oil storage, not exceeding five hundred (500) barrels capacity each and constructed and maintained in accordance with the recommendations of the American Petroleum Institute. It shall be unlawful and an offense and violation of this chapter for any person to locate a storage tank or separator site nearer than five thousand (5,000) feet to any residence or commercial building or public building within the city. 
(b)  A permittee may use, construct and operate a steel conventional separator and such other steel tanks and appurtenances as are necessary for treating oil, condensate, natural gas or natural gas liquids. All such facilities shall be constructed and maintained to control vapors. Each oil and gas separator shall be equipped with both a regulation pressure relief safety valve and a bursting head. If excessive vapors are released from the tanks, the oil and gas inspector may require that a vapor recovery system be installed and operated to prevent the release of gas vapors into the atmosphere. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-47. - Impounding around tanks by diking. 
    When protection of adjoining property or waterways is by means of impounding by diking around the tanks, such system shall comply with the following: 
(1)  A slope of not less than one (1) percent sway from the tank shall be provided for at least fifty (50) feet or to the dike base, whichever is less. 
(2)  The volumetric capacity of the diked area shall not be less than 1.5 X the greatest amount of liquid that can be released from the largest tank within the diked area, assuming a full tank. To allow for volume occupied by tanks, the capacity of the diked area enclosing more than one (1) tank shall be calculated after deducting the volume of the tanks, other than the largest tank, below the height of the dike. 
(3)  To permit access, the outside base of the dike at ground level shall be not closer than ten (10) feet to any property line that is or can be built upon. 
(4)  Walls of the diked area shall be of earth, steel, concrete or solid masonry designed to be liquid tight and to withstand a full hydrostatic head. Earthen walls three (3) feet or more in height shall have a flat section at the top not less than two (2) feet wide. The slope of an earthen wall shall be consistent with the angle of repose of the material of which the wall is constructed. Diked area for tanks containing class I liquids located in extremely porous soils may require special treatment to prevent seepage of hazardous quantities of liquids to low-lying areas or waterways in case of spills. Metal stairway(s) shall be constructed over the dike to allow ingress and egress to the diked area. Installation of such metal stairways will prevent erosion and loss of height of the dike due to foot traffic into the diked area. 
(5)  Where provision is made for draining water from diked areas, such drains shall be installed outside of the diked area and equipped with a lock or locking device so as to prevent flammable or combustible fluids from entering natural watercourses, public sewers, or public drains, if their presence would constitute a hazard. Control of drainage, if installed, shall be accessible under fire conditions from outside the dike. 
(6)  Storage of combustible materials shall not be permitted within the diked area. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-48. - Leakage of deleterious substance. 
    In the event of any leakage or spillage of any pollution or deleterious substance, whatever the cause thereof, the permittee shall promptly notify the oil and gas inspector. If, in the judgment of the oil and gas inspector, such leakage or spillage represents a potential environmental hazard, the inspector may issue whatever corrective orders are deemed appropriate and additionally may require the appropriate testing of the surface and subsurface for pollutant incursion, the cost of all such testing to be paid by the permittee. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-49. - Accumulation of vapor. 
    The oil and gas inspector shall have the authority to require the immediate shutting in or closing of any well if it is found that there exists within a one hundred-foot radius of any well, any gas or gasoline vapor in a quantity sufficient to constitute a fire hazard in the judgment of the oil and gas inspector or the city fire marshal. The well shall remain shut in or closed in until the hazard and its cause has been remedied. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-50. - Inspection of pressure lines. 
    The oil and gas inspector shall inspect all pressure lines in use at any well, facility or gathering system. All tubing, fittings, equipment or connections shall be tight, safe and free from leaks. All pressure lines shall be hydrostatically pressure-tested upon installation to full working pressure. If in the sole opinion of the oil and gas inspector there is a possibility that danger to the health, safety and well-being of the residents of the city may exist due to said pressure lines, the inspector may require inspection or testing of said lines to insure their pressure integrity. Furthermore, the oil and gas inspector has the authority to require the permittee to immediately shut-in and bleed off any pressure so contained within said pressure lines, until they are inspected or tested and meet the inspector's approval. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-51. - Burning of trash. 
    No permittee or any other person shall burn any trash or debris upon the well site. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-52. - Surface facilities-Location. 
    Whenever necessary to protect the health, safety or welfare of the public, the oil and gas inspector is authorized to direct any permittee or operator to locate, relocate, remove or replace any well surface facilities located within a particular drilling unit. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-53. - Safety precautions. 
    Persons drilling, operating or maintaining any well shall use all necessary care and take all precautions, which shall be reasonably necessary under the circumstances to protect the public. The provisions of this chapter shall be deemed to be the minimum requirements for the preservation of the public health, safety and welfare, and compliance with the terms hereof shall not be deemed to relieve any persons of any additional duty imposed by law. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Secs. 20-54-20-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LEASING OF CITY LANDS FOR OIL AND GAS ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 20-66. - City council authority to lease public lands for oil and gas activity. 
(a)  The city council shall from time to time on behalf of the city have the right and privilege to seek competitive bids for such public lands owned by the city as the city council may decide and determine subject to rules and regulations as herein set out or may be later from time to time provided by the city council. 
(b)  Any oil and gas lease entered into by the city shall be approved by ordinance, and the ordinance of approval shall provide that the lease shall be subject to the conditions and limitations as herein set out as if the same were repeated verbatim therein. Any oil and gas lease that the city proposes to enter into shall be approved as to form by the city attorney, whose approval shall be noted on the face of the document. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-67. - Governmental functions shall be preeminent. 
(a)  No rights granted by the city under an oil and gas lease shall ever be superior to or take precedence to the rights and needs of the city to use the public lands of the city for necessary governmental functions. All oil and gas activity of any type that may be from time to time permitted by a lease granted by the city shall be conducted upon an approved work or drilling site. The work or drilling site shall be described in the oil and gas lease and shall be the only site where drilling equipment and/or materials may be located in furtherance of any right or privilege granted under an oil and gas lease. In the event the city shall find and determine that the area designated for work or drilling shall be necessary for some governmental function as the city council is hereby exclusively authorized to determine, the city may designate another part of a tract leased for oil and gas purposes to the same lessee as the designated work or drilling site. 
(b)  If prior to the commencement of drilling operations, no other site is available, then the lessee under any oil and gas lease granted by the city, shall immediately upon demand of the city, vacate the designated work or drilling site and may seek to find a replacement or substitute site adjacent to or as close to the abandoned site as is possible. The lessee shall be entitled to a credit on its obligations under any applicable lease to the city if it shall be necessary for the lessee to move to a drilling or work site on a tract of property not owned by the city. The credit that shall be allowed shall be limited to the cost of acquiring the site and no other cost of removal or loss of time or opportunity shall be allowed. No credit shall ever be allowed if another or substitute site shall be provided to the lessee by the city. The city shall not have the right to demand the movement of the drill site as provided for herein after commencement of drilling operations on any well drilled under an oil and gas lease granted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-68. - Property to be leased upon competitive bidding. 
    If the city council at a public meeting shall first determine that certain public lands or property, and the minerals thereunder owned either solely by the city jointly with others, should be subjected to competitive bidding for the purpose of receiving proposals for leasing for oil and gas purposes. At such time the city council shall determine whether there shall be any safeguards or limitations that should be imposed upon a prospective lessee based upon the size of the property, its proximity to other property and residences and any other factors that in the discretion of the city council are reasonably necessary to preserve the health, safety and welfare of the residents, citizens and inhabitants of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-69. - City to receive bonus and quarterly payments. 
(a)  The city shall never receive a signing bonus in an amount less than the amount being paid for similar leases of property owned by private sector interests. It shall be incumbent upon the city council to conduct such studies or inquiries as shall be appropriate to determine the signing bonus per net acre for the same or similar property within or outside the city limits of the city. Prior to any proposal being considered, the person or entity making a proposal shall offer the city a signing bonus equal to or exceeding the amount then being offered to other similarly situated private sector entities. In the event a lessee under this provision shall enter into a lease providing for a higher lease bonus than provided and paid to the city, lessee shall immediately notify the city and pay to the city an amount equal to the difference between that paid previously to the city and paid subsequently to a third party. Failure of a lessee to make said payment(s) to the city within the time provided for herein, shall render lessee's lease with the city null and void. 
(b)  Payments that may become due and payable shall be paid and disbursed to the city no less frequently than provided for in the applicable lease. Payments to the city for its proportionate share of royalty or overriding royalty crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids shall be made no later than the end of the month following the month in which said crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids were produced. Payments to the city under the terms and conditions of the applicable lease shall not be suspended or delayed due to any cause, including failure of title arising from any interest other than that of the city. All oil and gas lessees shall provide to the city manager a copy of the Railroad Commission of Texas form P-1 or P-2 no later than the end of the month following the month in which a well subject to a city lease has produced crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids. 
(c)  Payments to the city for royalties or overriding royalties shall reflect the highest price paid by any purchaser for the sale of crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids in the area. All leases granted by the city shall reflect the minimum price to be paid by the lessee(s). Said minimum price shall be in the form of a regionally acceptable index or composite approved by the city council. All prices received by the city for its proportionate share of crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids shall be from unrelated third-parties and be exclusive of any transportation, compression, dehydration or marketing fees imposed by the lessee or purchaser(s). In all cases, the city shall retain the right to take in kind, its proportionate share of all produced crude oil, condensate, natural gas and/or natural gas liquids. 
(d)  All lessees shall be responsible for ad valorem payments, if any imposed by any taxing jurisdiction on the interest(s) of the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-70. - Right to audit. 
    The city reserves in and to itself the right to audit the books and records of any oil and gas lessee or any production records to determine whether all payments that are due and payable to the city have been properly paid. All oil and gas lessees shall immediately, or no later than ten (10) days from the date of request, provide the city such documents or records as shall be necessary to determine whether all appropriate royalties and/or working interests have been properly paid to the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Sec. 20-71. - Termination of lease. 
    All leases granted by the city shall contain express language that any failure on the part of any lessee under the terms of the applicable lease from the city, shall be cause for immediate termination of the lease. Said termination shall be for reasons including, but not limited to nonpayment of bonus, nonpayment of annual rentals, nonpayment of royalties or overriding royalties, not providing forms or reports as required by this article or any other violation of the lease covenants. 
(Ord. No. 99-28, §§ 1, 2, 7-6-99) 
Chapter 21 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Rental fees, deposits, etc., for use of city facilities, § 2-68; planning and development, § 2-86 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages restricted, §§ 3-3, 3-4; animals, Ch. 4; pets prohibited from running at large, § 4-2; animals prohibited in city parks, etc., § 4-10; racing of horses restricted in public places, § 4-94; staking or hitching horses, mules or other such animals upon streets or any public place prohibited, § 4-96; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; swimming pool regulations, § 6-211 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 24; subdivisions, Ch. 25; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 28. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 21-1-21-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS AND RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of council to remove any board member, § 3.07(a). 

Sec. 21-26. - Established; composition; compensation. 
    A parks and recreation board is established in and for the city. The parks and recreation board shall consist of at least seven (7) but not more than thirteen (13) members who shall be appointed by the city council. Members shall serve without compensation and each shall be a resident of the city or an owner of property or a business located within the city. 
(Code 1960, § 15B-2(a); Ord. No. 88-43, § 1, 8-2-88; Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 5-17-16) 
Sec. 21-27. - Appointment of members; terms. 
    The parks and recreation board shall be appointed after each city election to serve a term of one (1) year. Vacancies may be filled at any time at the discretion of city council by appointment for the remainder of the unexpired term. The terms shall continue until their successors have been appointed and confirmed. There is no limit to the amount of terms a member may serve as long as the member is active and participating. 
(Code 1960, § 15B-2(b); Ord. No. 90-46, § 1, 6-19-90; Ord. No. 2016-16 , § 1, 5-17-16; Ord. No. 2018-23, § 1, 7-3-18 ) 
Sec. 21-28. - Organization; conduct of business. 
    The parks and recreation board shall organize by electing from their membership a chairperson, a vice-chairperson and a secretary, each of whom shall hold office for one (1) year, or until their successor shall have been elected. A majority of the members of the parks and recreation board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of its business. The parks and recreation board may adopt its own rules of procedure for the conduct of its business. The parks and recreation board shall keep a record of its proceedings and shall file the same with the city secretary. The chairperson shall be entitled to vote upon any issue but shall have no veto power. 
(Code 1960, § 15B-2(c)) 
Sec. 21-29. - Attendance at meetings. 
    The parks and recreation board may establish its own rules as to attendance of its members at its meetings and in furtherance of such, the board shall expel any member who has missed three (3) meetings without reasons which, in the opinion of a majority of the members of the board, are valid. 
(Code 1960, § 15B-2(e); Ord. No. 88-43, § 2, 8-2-88) 
Sec. 21-30. - Advisory responsibilities. 
    The parks and recreation board shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city council regarding policy matters pertaining to parks and/or recreation as follows: 
(1)  Solicit funds, gifts and requests for park acquisitions, additions and improvements from foundations and civic organizations. 
(2)  Review and make advisory recommendations to the city council on proposed park acquisitions, additions and improvements. 
(3)  Review and make advisory recommendations on parks and recreation matters submitted by the director of parks and recreation or the city council. 
(4)  Promote and stimulate public interest in parks and recreation programs and to assist the director of parks and recreation in solicitation of public and private agencies that may have a direct or indirect involvement in parks and recreation policies of the city. 
(5)  The parks and recreation board shall have no right, power or authority to obligate or bind the city in any matter whatsoever. 
(Code 1960, § 15B-2(d)) 
Secs. 21-31-21-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARK REGULATIONS 

Sec. 21-46. - Definitions. 
    City parks shall include, but not be limited to, the Seabourne Creek, Garcia, Travis, Sunset, Harwood, Brazos, Riverbend, Community Parks and the civic center, and other parks or recreational facilities that may be established in the future by the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-30, § 3, 5-2-89; Ord. No. 2010-10, § 1, 4-20-10) 
Sec. 21-47. - Hours for use. 
    All parks within the city limits of the City of Rosenberg shall be open daily for use by the public between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m., except for Seabourne Creek Park, which shall be open daily for use by the public between the hours of 6:30 a.m. to dusk. The regulations as herein provided shall be applicable to all parks and park land. It shall be unlawful for any person to occupy, use or be present in any park during any hours or part thereof in which the park is not open for public use. The city manager or designee may, for good cause, grant an extension of the times for usage of the facilities as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 2012-05, § 1, 2-21-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 202-05, § 1, adopted Feb. 21, 2012, deleted § 21-47, in its entirety and enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, § 21-47 pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Sec. 21-48. - Use restricted. 
(a)  Any nonprofit organization may use any city park for organized activities upon receiving the prior consent of the city parks department. 
(b)  No private enterprise which operates with the expectation of profit may use any city park for any profit-making purpose. 
(Ord. No. 89-30, §§ 1, 2, 5-2-89) 
Sec. 21-49. - Prohibiting glass containers in city parks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon a city park with any glass container. 
(Ord. No. 89-17, § 1(b), 5-2-89) 
Sec. 21-50. - Display of alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to go in or upon any city parks, except the civic center, and publicly display any alcoholic beverage, or drink any alcoholic beverage in or upon any city parks, except the civic center. 
(Ord. No. 93-13, § 1, 9-21-93) 
State Law reference- Control and management of city parks, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 331.005; public use of city parks under rules prescribed by city, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 331.007. 
Sec. 21-51. - Seabourne Creek Park; prohibiting certain uses of city waterways. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to swim, bathe, wade or otherwise enter any creeks, lakes, canals or other waterways in Seabourne Creek Park. Entry, placement or operation of a boat, raft, canoe or any other type of watercraft, specifically including the operation of miniature boats, models or toys which are propelled by motor driven device, is strictly prohibited and declared a nuisance. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, fishing from the banks adjacent to the waterway is allowed consistent with the prohibitions provided herein. 
(b)  An exception is made to any recreational project sponsored by the parks and recreation board, authorized by the city manager and supervised by city employees or representatives, or, in the event of an emergency situation. 
(c)  Upon conviction for violation of this section, the penalty shall be as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2003-60, § 2, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 21-52. - Prohibiting use of tobacco products within city parks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use tobacco products within a city park. For the purposes of this section, use of a tobacco product shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Carrying or holding a lighted pipe, cigar, or cigarette of any kind; 
(2)  Lighting a pipe, cigar, or cigarette of any kind; 
(3)  Emitting or exhaling the smoke of a pipe, cigar, or cigarette of any kind; or 
(4)  Chewing, dipping, spitting, or using a smokeless tobacco product, such as chewing tobacco or snuff. 
    Prominently displayed reasonably sized signs shall be placed at the entrance of each city park, pool, court, and field, and on each building or structure within each city park, stating that smoking and the use of tobacco products, including smokeless tobacco is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2010-10, § 2, 4-20-10) 
Sec. 21-53. - Prohibiting unmanned drone use in city parks. 
(a)  Definitions . As used in this section, the following words and phrases shall be defined as follows: 
(1)  Drones means unmanned aircraft that can fly under the control of a remote pilot or via a global positioning system (GPS) guided autopilot mechanism. 
(b)  Prohibiting unmanned drone use in city parks. 
(1)  Drones are prohibited from flying in any airspace below four hundred (400) feet within or over any park property in the city, including courts and fields, unless otherwise exempt under this section. 
(2)  Operation of unmanned drones in city parks is strictly prohibited and declared a nuisance. 
(c)  Exemptions. 
(1)  This section shall not prohibit the use of drones in a recreational project sponsored by the city's parks and recreation board as authorized by the city manager. All activities conducted under this exemption shall be supervised by the designated city staff. 
(2)  This section shall not prohibit the use of drones by law enforcement agencies in the event of an emergency or public safety situation authorized by the city manager. 
(d)  Signage . 
(1)  Prominently displayed reasonably sized signs shall be placed at the entrance of each city park, court, and field and on each building or structure within each city park, stating that use of unmanned drones in city parks is strictly prohibited. 
(2)  The city manager is hereby authorized and directed to cause the placement of signs consistent with the provisions of this section. 
( Ord. No. 2015-31, § 2, 10-20-15 ) 
Secs. 21-54-21-65. - Reserved.
