DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 21-66. - Park pavilion and field rental fees. 
    Park pavilion and field rental fees shall be provided for in a schedule of fees established by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2010-16, § 1, 8-17-10) 
Secs. 21-67-21-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ATHLETIC FIELD 

Sec. 21-76. - Policy administration. 
    The parks and recreation department shall be responsible for administering such specific rules and regulations for the use of athletic facilities set forth in the policy established by the city council. 
(Code 1960, § 15B-3; Ord. No. 91-13, § 3, 3-19-91) 
Sec. 21-77. - Field rental. 
(a)  Any non-cosponsored league, person, group or establishment may use the athletic ballfields for practice or tournaments upon signing an athletic field rental agreement, in the form provided by the city, and payment of the cash deposits and fees as listed below: 
(1)  Non-tournament use of the field with lights: Ten dollars ($10.00) for every two (2) hours. 
(2)  Tournaments: One hundred dollars ($100.00) damage deposit for reservation of facility. Eight dollars ($8.00) for each game played during the daylight hours and ten dollars ($10.00) for each game played with use of lights. A tournament bracket must be turned in twenty-four (24) hours prior to the tournament. 
(b)  The above fees are charged for guaranteed reservations. No charge is made for use of fields for informal or family activities. 
(Code 1960, § 15B-6; Ord. No. 91-3, § 5, 3-19-91) 
Editor's note- Former § 21-77, relating to ballfield lighting and derived from Code 1960, § 15B-4 and § 17-79, relating to field cleanup and disposition of waste and derived from Code 1960, § 15B-15, were repealed by § 4 of Ord. No. 91-13, adopted Mar. 19, 1991. 
Secs. 21-78-21-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SWIMMING POOL 

Sec. 21-96. - Admission fees, season passes, rental fees and deposits. 
(a)  Admission fees shall be charged during public swim hours: 
(1)  Brazos swimming pool. 
Sundays through Saturdays will be open from 1:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. (per person) ..... $1.00 
(2)  Travis swimming pool. 
Sundays, Wednesdays and Saturdays will be open from 1:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. (per person) ..... 1.00 
Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays will be open from 1:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. (per person) ..... 1.00 
Re-open from 7:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. (per person) ..... 1.00 
(3)  Season passes. 
Available for use at Travis Pool and Brazos Pool: 
Family season passes ..... 50.00 
Individual season passes ..... 25.00 
(b)  A rental fee, which covers all city costs, shall be charged and collected by the city from the person or organization wishing to rent the Travis swimming pool. 
(1)  Charge for three (3) hours for up to fifty (50) people ..... $180.00 
(2)  Charge per each additional person over fifty (50) people ..... 1.00 
(c)  A twenty-five dollars ($25.00) deposit to secure use of Travis Pool shall be collected by the city from the person or organization renting a facility. Such deposit shall be paid in advance of the proposed rental period. Following the termination of the rental period, if the facility is in proper condition such deposit shall be refunded in full. 
(d)  City staff may impose limits on the number of persons who may be within a rented swimming pool facility at any one (1) time. The person or organization renting the city facility shall report to the city staff the number of persons expected to occupy the facility and obtain approval of such expected occupancy prior to use of the facility. The city staff may demand that persons in excess of the approved occupancy limit leave the facility. 
(Ord. No. 88-32, §§ 1-3, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 97-13, § 1, 4-1-97; Ord. No. 2000-13, § 1, 4-18-00) 
Chapter 22 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Police department, § 4.02; salaries, § 4.02(c); administration and budget under city manager's powers and duties, § 4.01; municipal finance, Art. 9; finance department, Art. 11; city council's authority to fix salaries and compensation, § 3.07(m); to provide by ordinance for exercise of the police power, § 3.07(s). 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; emergency management, Ch. 10; miscellaneous offenses, Ch. 18; municipal court, Ch. 19; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 28; vehicles for hire, Ch. 30. 
State Law reference- Provide for police department, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.003. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Authority of police department to enforce state law. 
    The police department of the city is empowered to enforce any and all statutes as authorized by state law in addition to those ordinances passed by the city council. 
Sec. 22-2. - Appointment of special police. 
    Any person of good character may be appointed a special policeman by the city manager, provided that, except upon authorization by the council, no such special policeman shall be entitled to any compensation from the city, nor shall such special policeman be considered an employee of the city by reason of such appointment. The city will provide uniforms for such special police. Special policemen shall obey all rules of the police department applicable to them, and may be deprived of their appointment by the chief of police at any time. 
(Code 1960, § 18-3) 
Sec. 22-3. - Mutual aid assistance. 
(a)  The police department shall be and is hereby authorized to provide the assistance of the regularly employed law enforcement officers of the city to any municipality or county requesting such assistance through its duly authorized office to aid in coping with situations where there exists in such other county or municipality a need for the services of additional law enforcement officers to protect the health, life, and property of such other county or municipality, its inhabitants, and the visitors thereto, by reason of riot, unlawful assembly characterized by the use of force and violence, or threat thereof by three (3) or more persons acting together or without lawful authority, or during time of natural disaster or manmade calamity. 
(b)  The assistance offered hereby shall be in accordance with the provisions of Section 362.002 of the Texas Local Government Code. 
(Code 1960, § 18-4) 
Secs. 22-4-22-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVE POLICE FORCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees, § 2-26 et seq. 

Sec. 22-26. - Established. 
    An auxiliary police force, to be known as the police reserve, is hereby established, such force to be separate and distinct from the police department. 
(Code 1960, § 18-21) 
Sec. 22-27. - General powers of chief of police relative to reserve. 
(a)  The chief of police shall be the head of the police reserve, and the members of the reserve shall be under the authority, control and command of the chief of police, subject to all ordinances of the city and this article. 
(b)  The chief of police may, by order, establish rules and regulations to govern the police reserve force, to fix specific duties of its members and to provide for the maintenance of discipline. He may change such orders from time to time, and he may command members of the police reserve force to obey the instructions of a regular police officer in carrying out their orders. 
(Code 1960, § 18-22) 
Sec. 22-28. - Composition. 
    The police reserve force shall be composed of personnel who have volunteered to join the organization and whose applications for membership have been accepted and who have complied with all rules, regulations and orders provided for the conduct and control of the members thereof. It shall be composed of not more than ten (10) members. 
(Code 1960, § 18-23) 
Sec. 22-29. - Diminishing or expanding membership. 
    The chief of police may by order diminish or expand the membership of the police reserve force as may be required within the limit established in section 22-28. 
(Code 1960, § 18-24) 
Sec. 22-30. - Application for membership. 
    Application for membership in the police reserve force shall be filed with the police department. Such application shall be on a form prescribed by the chief of police and approved by the city manager. 
(Code 1960, § 18-25) 
Sec. 22-31. - Applicant's qualifications and references. 
(a)  Each applicant for membership in the police reserve force shall be an actual resident of the city or an employee of the city who is classified as a full-time employee, and the applicant's background will be checked in the same manner as a full-time officer candidate. The applicant must be of good character, temperate habits, free from communicable diseases and have the physical ability to perform the duties of the position for which he seeks appointment. 
(b)  Any qualifications established for the positions of police reserve force officers for the city shall meet the minimum physical, mental, educational and moral standards established by the State of Texas Commission on Law Enforcement Officer Standards and Education but may be stricter than the standards of the commission. 
(Code 1960, §§ 18-26, 18-34(c); Ord. No. 88-05, § 1, 1-19-88) 
Sec. 22-32. - Oath required of applicants. 
    Every person who may be selected by the chief of police as a police reserve force officer shall subscribe to an oath that he will observe and obey the Constitution of the United States, the constitution of this state and the laws of this nation, this state and this city, and that he will carry out the duties of a member of the police reserve force to the best of his abilities. 
(Code 1960, § 18-27) 
Sec. 22-33. - List of eligibles; appointment of members. 
    A list of eligibles, compiled by the chief of police and accompanied by a complete set of fingerprints or supplemented immediately by fingerprinting by the police department, which fingerprints shall be checked by the identification bureau to ascertain any criminal record of such person, shall be maintained by the police department. Members of the police reserve force shall be appointed by the chief of police from such lists of eligibles. 
(Code 1960, § 18-28) 
Sec. 22-34. - Uniforms and badges for members. 
    The chief of police shall prescribe the uniforms and badges for the members of the police reserve force and direct the manner in which the same shall be worn. Each individual reserve officer shall bear the cost of uniform and badge but shall be reimbursed for such expenses after twelve (12) months consecutive service, at which time the uniform and badge will become the property of the police department. 
(Code 1960, § 18-29) 
Sec. 22-35. - Duties. 
    The duties of the police reserve force, subject at all times to the direction, supervision and control of the chief of police, shall be to assist the regular members of the police department in the enforcement of law and the maintenance of peace and order during periods of emergency designated by the chief of police. The chief of police may prescribe other duties than those mentioned herein to be performed by the police reserve force not inconsistent with the provisions of this article or state law. 
(Code 1960, § 18-30) 
Sec. 22-36. - Power or arrest. 
    A member of the police reserve force shall have the powers of arrest as set forth in state law. 
(Code 1960, § 18-31) 
Sec. 22-37. - Entry upon private property. 
    No member of the police reserve force shall break into or otherwise forcefully enter upon private property or enter the dwelling or habitation of another person without the consent of a member of the police department, who then and there requests his aid in the enforcement of the law and is properly authorized to enter. 
(Code 1960, § 18-32) 
Sec. 22-38. - Termination of membership generally. 
    Membership of any person in the police reserve force may be terminated by the chief of police at any time for any cause deemed sufficient by the chief of police or the city manager. Any member may resign from the police reserve force at any time, but it shall be his duty to notify the chief of police of his resignation. 
(Code 1960, § 18-33) 
Sec. 22-39. - Possession of weapons. 
    No person appointed to the police reserve force may carry a weapon or otherwise act as a peace officer, until he has been approved by the city council. After approval, he may carry a weapon only when authorized by the chief of police and when discharging official duties as a duly constituted peace officer. 
(Code 1960, § 18-34(a)) 
Sec. 22-40. - Scope of authority limited. 
    Members of the police reserve force shall act only in a supplementary capacity to the regular police force and shall in no case assume the full-time duties of regular police officers without first complying with all requirements for such regular police officers. 
(Code 1960, § 18-34(b)) 
Chapter 23 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Specific authority to provide for sanitary garbage disposal and set fees for such service, § 3.07(p); health department, § 4.06. 
Cross reference- Planning and development, § 2-86 et seq.; animals, Ch. 4; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; plumbing and gas standards, § 6-171 et seq.; dangerous buildings, § 6-271 et seq.; health, sanitation and nuisances, Ch. 14; vermin-proofing required for all garbage containers, § 14-51; manufactured housing, mobile homes and travel trailer parks, Ch. 17; requirements for manufactured housing, mobile home or travel trailer park, § 17-114; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 24; subdivisions, Ch. 25; utilities, Ch. 29. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dry kitchen refuse shall mean the solids after the liquid or slop has been drained off. 
    Kitchen garbage shall mean dry kitchen refuse; all meat, vegetable and fruit refuse; small dead animals and dead fowls. 
    Premises shall mean business houses, boardinghouses, offices, theaters, hotels, restaurants, cafes, eating houses, tourist camps, apartments, sanitariums, roominghouses, schools, private residences, vacant lots and all other places within the city limits where garbage, trash or rubbish accumulates in ordinary quantities. 
    Rubbish shall mean tin cans, bottles, glass, scraps of iron, tin, wire or any other metals. 
    Trash shall mean paper of all kinds, rags, old clothing, paper containers, old rubber, pieces of wood, boxes, barrels, crates, feathers, weeds, grass and tree limbs. 
(Code 1960, § 11-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 23-2. - Heavy, bulky accumulations; construction and wrecking yards. 
    Heavy accumulations, such as brick, broken concrete, lumber, ashes, clinkers, cinders, dirt and plaster, sand or gravel, automobile frames, dead trees and other bulky, heavy material shall be disposed of at the expense of the owner or person controlling the accumulations under the direction of the designated official. 
(Code 1960, § 11-10) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; licenses and business regulations, Ch. 16. 
Sec. 23-3. - Manure; waste oils. 
    Manure from cowlots, horse stables, poultry yards, pigeon lofts and waste oils from garages or filling stations shall be disposed of at the expense of the party responsible for the accumulations under the direction of the designated official. 
(Code 1960, § 11-11) 
Cross reference- Animals, Ch. 4. 
Sec. 23-4. - Meddling and pilfering. 
    The meddling with garbage cans, trash or rubbish receptacles or in any way pilfering, scattering contents or junk in any alley or street within the city is prohibited. 
(Code 1960, § 11-15) 
Sec. 23-5. - Placing in streets. 
    The placing of kitchen garbage, trash or rubbish or any article, thing or material in any street or alley within the city is prohibited. 
(Code 1960, § 11-16) 
Cross reference- Health, sanitation and nuisances, Ch. 14; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 23-6. - Willful deposits; gutters and sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful, in this city, willfully to throw, put or place, any wood, paper, sawdust, straw, bottles, chips, earth, or other material whatever, in the gutters, or upon the sidewalks or streets of this city. 
(Code 1960, § 11-17) 
Sec. 23-7. - Offensive materials; any place. 
    No person shall throw, place or convey, or suffer his servant, child or any member of his family to throw, place or convey into any street, alley, gutter, sidewalk, lot or any other place within this city, any putrid beef, pork, or other meat, fish, hides of animals, bones or other slop, dishwater, or any other unsound or offensive matter, or anything likely to become offensive; nor shall any person allow such filth, offal, or other offensive matter to be or remain upon his premises, or in any street, gutter or alley in front of or adjoining such premises, so as to be offensive to others. 
(Code 1960, § 11-18) 
Sec. 23-8. - Failure to secure property. 
    No person who owns or controls real property shall fail to secure such property in a manner to prevent unauthorized entry or use as a passageway to public drainways or other public grounds for the purpose of transporting materials of any type for dumping of waste, trash, debris, rubbish or any other objectionable material or for dumping of waste, trash, debris, rubbish or any other objectionable material on property owned or controlled privately. It shall be a violation of this Code for any person to use any property which is not a licensed dumping ground for the dumping of waste, trash, debris, rubbish or any other objectionable material, nor shall any property be used as a means of point of ingress or egress to any other property, public or private, for such unlawful dumping of waste, trash, debris, rubbish or any other objectionable material. All property owners affected by this section shall install such signs, barricades, fencing or other materials which will prevent entry upon property in violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 98-10, § 1, 2-17-98) 
Secs. 23-9-23-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Vermin-proofing required for all garbage containers, § 14-51. 

Sec. 23-26. - Special conditions for collection and disposal. 
    The collection and disposal of solid waste within the corporate limits of the city by any person or business entity other than a business entity which has been approved by the city council to collect and dispose of solid waste and with whom a contract has been duly executed is prohibited, except as provided for in sections 23-2 and 23-3. 
(Code 1960, § 11-19; Ord. No. 89-59, § 1, 9-28-89) 
Sec. 23-27. - Frequency. 
(a)  Curbside collection. Collection of curbside solid waste shall be provided or contracted for by the city. Collection following a holiday shall be in accordance with the terms of a contract between the city and the business entity providing solid waste collection and disposal for the city and as established and approved by the city council. 
(b)  Containerized collection. Collection of containerized solid waste shall be provided a minimum of one (1) time per week and up to six (6) times per week, with the express provision that food establishments shall have containerized collection at a minimum of two (2) times per week. 
( Ord. No. 2014-13, § 1, 3-18-14 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-13, § 1, adopted Mar. 18, 2014 , repealed the former § 23-27 and enacted a new § 23-27 as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 23-28. - Conformance required; collection not made from nonconforming premises. 
    The city will not make collection of kitchen garbage, trash, rubbish or tree limbs where it is not prepared for collection and placed as designated in sections 23-29 through 23-31. Failure to comply with this provision will be an offense and each day's failure to comply will constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1960, § 11-3) 
Sec. 23-29. - Containers-Kitchen garbage and dry kitchen refuse. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person owning, managing, operating, leasing or renting any premises, or any place where kitchen garbage accumulates, to provide a portable garbage can constructed of galvanized iron, tin, plastic, rubber or other suitable material, with two (2) handles and a tight-fitting cover of a capacity more than twenty (20) gallons but less than thirty-five (35) gallons. Plastic garbage bags may be used in lieu of trashcans so long as they are of a suitable strength to allow collection without loss of garbage or refuse. Trash bags must be properly secured and, if directed by the city health department, treated with ammonia or another agent to discourage damage from animals. The daily accumulation of kitchen garbage and dry kitchen refuse shall be placed in one (1) of these containers. 
(b)  An exception to section 23-29(a) shall be made when the city's contracted business entity for solid waste collection provides a specific container for automated solid waste and/or recycling service. In such circumstance, all persons shall be required to utilize the container provided by the contracted business entity. 
( Ord. No. 2014-13, § 1, 3-18-14 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-13, § 2, adopted Mar. 18, 2014 , repealed the former § 23-29 and enacted a new § 23-29 as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 23-30. - Same-Trash and rubbish; tree limbs. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning, managing, operating, leasing or renting any premises to place all trash and rubbish from the premises in garbage cans, bags, boxes, barrels or other receptacles of a reasonable size and weight in accordance with the terms of a contract between the city and the business entity providing solid waste collection and disposal for the city and as established and approved by the city council. Tree limbs shall be cut into lengths not exceeding four (4) feet and bundled. 
(Code 1960, § 11-5; Ord. No. 91-27, § 4, 7-16-91) 
Sec. 23-31. - Same-Location. 
(a)  Solid waste and/or recycling carts, garbage cans, bags, boxes, barrels or other receptacles of trash, except commercial bins, shall be placed behind the curb or the street side of the ditch. 
(b)  Customers may not place carts in the street right-of-way for collection earlier than 12:00 p.m. (noon) the day before the day of collection and no later than 7:00 a.m. of the day of collection. Emptied carts must be removed from the street right-of-way no later than 8:00 a.m. on the morning following the day of collection. 
( Ord. No. 2014-13, § 3, 3-18-14 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2014-13, § 3, adopted Mar. 18, 2014 , repealed the former § 23-31 and enacted a new § 23-31 as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 23-32. - Same-Maintenance. 
(a)  Generally. Garbage cans and bags shall be kept in a sanitary condition and closed tightly. 
(b)  Preventing scattering. The contents of all receptacles shall be so protected and secured that animals or the wind cannot blow or scatter the contents over the streets, alleys and premises of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 11-7; Ord. No. 91-27, § 6, 7-16-91) 
Sec. 23-33. - Places of wholesale accumulations. 
    The places of wholesale accumulations, such as killing and dressing plants for fowl, wholesale fruit and vegetable houses, storage and other places, where the daily accumulation of kitchen garbage, trash and rubbish is more than the ordinary quantities, are not included in the service furnished by the city and such places are required to remove and safely dispose of accumulations at their own expense, in the manner and by the method directed by the official designated by the city council. 
(Code 1960, § 11-8) 
Cross reference- Health, sanitation and nuisances, ch. 14; rental fees, deposits, etc., for use of city facilities, § 2-68. 
Sec. 23-34. - Schedule of charges. 
    The rate schedules for solid waste collection and disposal service shall be established and approved by resolution of the city council. 
( Ord. No. 2017-18, § 1, 7-18-17 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-18 , § 1, adopted July 18, 2017, deleted § 23-34, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1960, § 11-21; Ord. No. 89-59, § 3, 9-28-89; Ord. No. 2012-01, § 1, 1-3-12. 
Chapter 24 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to exercise exclusive dominion, control and jurisdiction over streets, sidewalks and other public grounds, § 3.07(o,v). 
Cross reference- Planning and development, § 2-86 et seq.; alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; location restrictions on alcoholic beverage establishments, § 3-2; consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages restricted, §§ 3-3, 3-4; animals, Ch. 4; pets prohibited from running at large, § 4-2; animals prohibited in city parks, etc., § 4-10; racing of horses restricted in public places, § 4-94; staking or hitching horses, mules or other such animals upon streets or any public place prohibited, § 4-96; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; plumbing and gas standards, § 6-171 et seq.; apartment buildings or complexes, § 6-251 et seq.; permits required for construction or reconstruction of driveways, culverts, etc., § 6-326 et seq.; emergency management, Ch. 10; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 11; flood prevention and protection, Ch. 12; health, sanitation and nuisances, Ch. 14; rodent control, § 14-50 et seq.; itinerant vendors, solicitors and peddlers, § 16-171 et seq.; itinerant sales from vehicles parked on streets prohibited, § 16-183; manufactured housing, mobile homes and travel trailers and parks, Ch. 17; parking of mobile homes and recreational vehicles on streets restricted, § 17-57; parks and recreation, Ch. 21; solid waste, Ch. 23; placing garbage and debris in streets prohibited, § 23-5; specific street regulations, § 28-26 et seq.; railroad grade crossings, obstruction, unloading, § 28-181; subdivisions, Ch. 25; traffic and vehicles, Ch. 28; utilities, Ch. 29; vehicles for hire, Ch. 30. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 24-1. - Abandonment. 
(a)  The city council may abandon and release any claim of the city to a roadway or any other real property interest of the city, provided that the person requesting such abandonment has submitted to the city secretary a petition for abandonment, and payment of all costs incurred by the city. Such petition shall include the following statements and attachments: 
(1)  A statement of the reason for the petition for abandonment. 
(2)  A survey plat and metes and bounds legal description of the property which the applicant seeks to have abandoned, prepared by a state licensed public surveyor. 
(3)  Written consent of all owners of land which abuts the property which the applicant seeks to have abandoned. 
(4)  Evidence of ownership of all of the property which abuts the property which the applicant seeks to have abandoned, so that the city can insure that all necessary parties have consented to the abandonment. 
(5)  An attorney's opinion letter stating that all of the abutting property owners have consented to the abandonment, and copies of the deeds by which those owners acquired title and any title policies issued to those owners. 
(6)  A statement that the applicant will indemnify and hold harmless the city from any and all claims or causes of actions relating to the abandonment. 
    Any of these statements and conditions may be waived by city council if it finds that any such statement or condition is not necessary for city council to make its determination whether to abandon such interest. 
(b)  The city's planning commission, director of public works and the city's legal counsel shall review each petition submitted hereunder and its attachments and recommend to city council whether the petition should be granted. The review by the planning commission and director of public works shall include a determination whether the property interest proposed to be abandoned is reasonably expected to be needed in the future for water, sewer or other public purposes of the city. The legal counsel's review shall include a determination whether the city has the legal power to abandon any interest it has in the real property. 
(Ord. No. 88-46, § 1, 9-20-88) 
State Law reference- Authority and restrictions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 253.001; closing of street or alley by city, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 311.007. 
Sec. 24-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-36 , § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 2017, deleted § 24-2, which pertained to riding bicycles, tricycles, and roller skates, and derived from Code 1960, § 19-20. 
Sec. 24-3. - Property owner's duty to maintain sidewalks. 
    All persons owning lots in this city upon the streets shall keep the sidewalk around the same in a good condition. 
(Code 1960, § 19-21) 
Sec. 24-4. - Blocking sidewalks by congregating. 
    It shall be unlawful for any two (2) or more persons to congregate upon the sidewalks of this city and cause the same to be blocked in any manner so to stop free passage on the sidewalk where such persons are congregated. 
(Code 1960, § 19-22) 
Sec. 24-5. - Obstructing sidewalks, streets restricted; permit. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases are, for the purposes of this section and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, defined as follows: 
    Free passage shall mean the ordinary use of sidewalks and streets for public travel, either on foot or by vehicle. 
    Obstruct shall mean to interfere, either partially or completely, directly or indirectly, with free passage along the city's sidewalks and streets, including causing an interference by attracting crowds. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to place or cause to be placed upon, across, over, through, or above any street, sidewalk, or street right-of-way, within this city, any object of whatsoever kind which obstructs so as to prevent free passage upon any sidewalk or all parts of any street or which obstructs the view of, or access to fire hydrants, mailboxes, traffic-control devices or signs, or street corners, except as provided in (c) below. 
(c)  A person, business, society or organization may conduct an activity that will obstruct free passage along the city's sidewalks and streets by first obtaining a permit from the customer service department. The customer service department will grant permits upon satisfactory completion of a form setting forth a detailed description of the time, place and manner of the activity; provided that in no event shall a permit allow a complete obstruction of any city sidewalk or street which would prevent all ordinary use of such sidewalk or street. 
(d)  If the activity is one which is covered by article IV or article V hereof, compliance with (c) above is not necessary however application pursuant to such provisions shall be required. 
(Code 1960, §§ 19-23-19-25; Ord. No. 88-29, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 92-11, § 1, 4-7-92; Ord. No. 95-03, § 3, 6-20-95; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 6, 8-15-00) 
Sec. 24-6. - Prohibiting buildings and structures within public rights-of-way and easements and requiring their removal. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to construct a permanent or temporary building or structure within a public right-of-way or easement, except for fences and landscaping. It shall further be unlawful for any person, upon written notice from the city, to fail to immediately remove, at such persons expense, any building, structure, or improvement, permanent or temporary, constructed or maintained by such person within a public right-of-way or easement, including, but not limited to, any part of a building, fence, landscaping, or other improvement, that may interfere with the construction, maintenance, or operations of the public facilities located with such right-of-way or easement. The city shall at all times have the right to ingress and egress along and upon said easement for the purpose of constructing, reconstructing, inspecting, operating, maintaining, or removing all or part of the public facilities located within such easement, without the necessity of procuring the permission of the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 2009-03, § 1, 1-20-09) 
Secs. 24-7-24-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NAMES AND NUMBERS 

Sec. 24-26. - Maps-Incorporated by reference. 
    The map or plat of the city, prepared by S. A. Russell a duly licensed engineer of the state, dated March 7, 1946, setting out the changes in the names and numbers of the streets is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference as a part of this article for the purpose of showing the names and numbers of the streets and avenues in the city and for that purpose only. All names and numbers of streets and avenues found to be in conflict with the names and numbers of streets and avenues as reflected by the map or plat are hereby changed, canceled and annulled. 
(Code 1960, § 19-1) 
Sec. 24-27. - Same-Filed in deed records. 
    The map or plat incorporated by reference in this article is filed in the records of the county clerk's office in order that the public may have ready reference to the plat, showing the change in the names and numbers of streets and avenues of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 19-2) 
Sec. 24-28. - Markers. 
    Markers designating the names and numbers of the streets and avenues of the city shall be erected and avenues and streets shall be numbered and named as shown on the plat incorporated by reference in this article. 
(Code 1960, § 19-3) 
Secs. 24-29-24-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATION AND CONSTRUCTION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Permits required for construction or reconstruction of driveways, culverts, etc., § 6-326 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 24-46. - Excavation and grading code adopted; references construed. 
(a)  The Standard Excavation and Grading Code, 1985 Edition, including all subsequent amendments thereto, as published by the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc., is hereby adopted by reference as though fully set forth herein. 
(b)  Within said excavation and grading code, any and all references made to the "Unsafe Building Code," including the following, shall mean the dangerous buildings ordinances of the city found in section 6-271 et seq., of the Code of Ordinances of the city (the "Code of Ordinances") which ordinances and amendments thereto shall hereby be known as the unsafe building code: 
Section 102.5 of the Standard Building Code. 
Section 102.4 of the Standard Existing Buildings Code. 
Section 102.2 of the Standard Fire Prevention Code. 
Section 103.2.4 of the Standard Housing Code. 
Section 102.5 of the Standard Plumbing Code. 
(c)  Within said excavation and grading code when reference is made to the duties of certain officials named therein that designated official in the city who has duties corresponding to those of the named official in said excavation and grading code shall be deemed to be the responsible official insofar as enforcing the provisions of said excavation and grading code are concerned. 
(d)  Within said excavation and grading code, any and all references made to a "board of adjustment and appeals," shall mean the city council which shall hereby be appointed as the board of adjustment and appeals to consider all variances to the excavation and grading code and appeals of the decisions of the building officials, upon recommendation of the city planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 90-63, §§ 1-3, 12-4-90; Ord. No. 92-15, §§ 9-11, 4-21-92) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-63, §§ 1-3, adopted Dec. 4, 1990, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been included as § 24-46 herein, at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 24-47-24-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-66 et seq. 

Sec. 24-61. - Required for work on property under city jurisdiction. 
    Any person desiring to do any work of any nature on any street, alley or property under the jurisdiction of the city in any instance not specifically covered by this article shall obtain a permit from the city engineer. The application for such permit shall be made in writing and received in the city engineer's office at least thirty-six (36) hours before the work is to be commenced. 
(Code 1960, § 19-4) 
Sec. 24-62. - When surface cuts not allowed. 
    No permit shall be issued to any person for cutting into the surface of any street, alley or property under city jurisdiction if the desired work may be accomplished without making such surface cut. 
(Code 1960, § 19-5) 
Sec. 24-63. - Cutting and excavating; deposit. 
(a)  Permit; application; time. Any person desiring to cut into or excavate under any street, alley or property under the jurisdiction of the city shall obtain a permit in writing from the city engineer prior to beginning work. The application for such permit shall be in writing and shall be made at least three (3) days before the work is to be commenced. 
(b)  Deposit. Every person desiring to cut into or excavate under any street or alley or property under the jurisdiction of the city shall place with the city engineer a deposit in an amount as determined by the city engineer sufficient to pay for the estimated cost of repair of such street, alley or other property under city jurisdiction, before any permit shall issue. 
(Code 1960, § 19-6) 
Sec. 24-64. - Protective fence. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to dig or cause to be dug any excavation in or adjoining any highway, street, alley or sidewalk, or upon any unenclosed lot or square and leave it during the night without a substantial fence surrounding the same at least three (3) feet high with the boards not more than eight (8) inches apart. 
(Code 1960, § 19-7) 
Secs. 24-65-24-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION 

Sec. 24-76. - Standards and specifications. 
    Any person desiring to construct any curb, curb and gutter, sidewalk, street or alley on property under the jurisdiction of the city shall construct same in accordance with the standard sections and specifications adopted by the city on file in the office of the city engineer. 
(Code 1960, § 19-8) 
Sec. 24-77. - Application; time; contents. 
    Written application shall be made to the city engineer at least ten (10) days prior to the start of any construction, setting out the location, lines, grades and other pertinent facts concerning the proposed construction. In the absence of any adopted or approved standards, the city engineer shall make, in writing, any changes which he deems necessary, subject to approval of the city council before the request shall be approved. 
(Code 1960, § 19-9) 
Sec. 24-78. - Permit. 
    When the proper application has been submitted, and the necessary changes if any have been made, the city engineer shall issue a permit for the proposed construction. 
(Code 1960, § 19-10) 
Sec. 24-79. - Inspection. 
    The city engineer shall have access to the work at all times for the purpose of making inspections to see that the work conforms to city standards or requirements. 
(Code 1960, § 19-11) 
Sec. 24-80. - Acceptance; certificate. 
    When the work has been completed in a manner satisfactory and acceptable to the city engineer, he shall issue a certificate of acceptance to the person making application for the permit, provided the estimated cost of construction is less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). If the estimated cost is in excess of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), the certificate will be issued only with approval of the city council. 
(Code 1960, § 19-12) 
Sec. 24-81. - Areas under development. 
(a)  Application; plans; developer's duty. Any developer of a subdivision or addition whose responsibility it is to construct the streets or alleys, by grading, graveling, paving or otherwise improving, or by construction of curbs, curbs and gutters or sidewalks, shall make written application accompanied by detailed specifications and plans showing all lines, grades and other pertinent facts concerning the proposed construction to the city engineer for approval at least ten (10) days prior to the start of any construction. 
(b)  Standards. All work done shall be done in accordance with the standard sections and specifications adopted by the city council and on file in the office of the city engineer. In the absence of standard sections adopted and approved by the city council, the city engineer shall make, in writing, whatever changes he deems necessary to the plans and specifications subject to the approval of the city council before approval for the construction is given. 
(c)  Approval. Approval of the city engineer must be obtained prior to starting the work. 
(d)  Inspection and acceptance. The city engineer shall have access to the work at all times for the purpose of making inspections to see that the work conforms to city requirements. Acceptance of this work shall be as specified in section 24-80. 
(Code 1960, § 19-13) 
Secs. 24-82-24-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC UTILITY INSTALLATIONS 

Sec. 24-96. - Standards and specifications. 
(a)  Any person desiring to install any water meter, gas meter, underground cables of any kind, or any meter, gas or sewer mains along any street or alley in the city shall install same in accordance with the standard sections and specifications adopted by the city and on file in the office of the city engineer. In the absence of adopted standards, written requirements of the city engineer with the approval of the city council shall be adhered to. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed as requiring permits for overhead lines (including, but not limited to, electric distribution, telephone, street lighting, alarm and signal circuits) and poles erected to accommodate the same. 
(Code 1960, § 19-14) 
Sec. 24-97. - Application; plans. 
(a)  Time. Written application shall be made to the city engineer at least thirty-six (36) hours in advance of the start of any new utility installation or construction. 
(b)  Sketch; required information. The application shall be accompanied by a sketch showing the location of lines, grades and other pertinent facts concerning the proposed utility installation or construction. 
(Code 1960, § 19-15) 
Sec. 24-98. - Permit. 
    When the proper application has been submitted, and the necessary changes, if any, have been made, the city manager shall issue a permit for the proposed construction. 
(Code 1960, § 19-16) 
Sec. 24-99. - Inspection. 
    The city engineer shall have access to the work at all times for the purpose of making inspections to see that the work conforms to city standards or requirements. 
(Code 1960, § 19-17) 
Sec. 24-100. - Acceptance; certificate. 
    When the work has been completed in a manner satisfactory and acceptable to the city engineer, he shall issue a certificate of acceptance to the person making application for the permit, provided the estimated cost of construction is less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). If the estimated cost is in excess of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), the certificate will be issued only with the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1960, § 19-18) 
Sec. 24-101. - Repairs. 
(a)  Regular. In the event of repair work on public utilities located on city streets or alleys, application shall be made to the city engineer prior to the work being commenced, except in the case of emergency repair work. 
(b)  Emergency. In case of emergency an application and permit shall be obtained from the city engineer as soon as feasible, but in no case shall the expired time be greater than three (3) days. 
(c)  Section construed. This section shall not be construed as requiring permits for overhead lines (including but not limited to, electric distribution, telephone, street lighting, alarm and signal circuits) and poles erected to accommodate the same. 
(Code 1960, § 19-19) 
Secs. 24-102-24-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARADES, EXHIBITIONS, RALLIES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 28. 

Sec. 24-126. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parade shall mean any parade, march or procession of any kind, in or upon any street, park or other outdoor places owned or under the control of the city. 
    Parade permit shall mean a permit as required by this article. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-2; Ord. No. 95-03, § 2, 6-20-95) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 24-127. - Permit. 
(a)  Required. No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the chief of police. 
(b)  Exceptions. This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions. 
(2)  Fort Bend County Fair. 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-3) 
Sec. 24-128. - Application for permit. 
    A person seeking the issuance of a parade permit shall file an application with the customer service department on forms provided by the customer service department. 
(1)  Filing period. An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the customer service department not less than thirty (30) days before the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade. The application shall be signed by the applicant and notarized. 
(2)  Contents. The application for a parade permit shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, address and telephone number of the person seeking to conduct such parade. 
b.  If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such organization. 
c.  The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct. 
d.  The date when the parade is to be conducted. 
e.  The route to be traveled, the starting point and termination point. 
f.  The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals and description of the vehicles. 
g.  The hours when such parade will start and terminate. 
h.  A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed. 
i.  The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade. 
j.  The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any such assembly area or areas. 
k.  If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of or for, any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file with the customer service department a communication in writing from the person proposing to hold the parade authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his behalf. 
l.  The purpose of the parade. 
m.  Any additional information which the customer service department shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(3)  Late applications. The customer service department, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than thirty (30) days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted. 
(4)  Application fee. A fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to cover the expenses incident to processing shall be paid by the person applying for the permit at the time of the filing of the application. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-4; Ord. No. 2000-32, § 7, 8-15-00) 
Sec. 24-129. - Standards for issuance of permit. 
    The chief of police shall issue a permit under this article when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, he finds that: 
(1)  The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route. 
(2)  The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the line of movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(3)  The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the city other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas contiguous thereto. 
(4)  The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas. 
(5)  The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(6)  The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance. 
(7)  The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route. 
(8)  The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private profit. Provided, however, the prohibition against advertising any product, goods or event shall not apply to signs identifying organizations or sponsors furnishing or sponsoring floats or transportation for the parade. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-5) 
Sec. 24-130. - Notice of rejection. 
    The chief of police shall act upon the application for a parade permit within eight (8) days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant, by registered mail within eight (8) days after the date upon which the application was filed, a notice of his action stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-6) 
Sec. 24-131. - Appeal procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved by the rejection of an application for a parade permit shall have the right to appeal such denial to the city manager. The appeal shall be taken within five (5) days after receipt of the notice of denial. The city manager shall act upon the appeal within five (5) days after its receipt. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-7) 
Sec. 24-132. - Alternative permit. 
    The chief of police in denying an application for a parade permit shall be empowered to authorize the conduct of the parade on a date, at a time or over a route different from that named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within five (5) days after notice of the action of the chief of police, file a written notice of acceptance with the chief of police. An alternate parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect of a parade permit under this article. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-8) 
Sec. 24-133. - Notice to city and other officials. 
    Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, the chief of police shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The city manager. 
(2)  The city attorney. 
(3)  The fire chief. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-9) 
Sec. 24-134. - Contents of permit. 
    Each parade permit shall state the following information: 
(1)  Date of the parade. 
(2)  Starting time and termination time of the parade. 
(3)  The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by the parade. 
(4)  The number of persons, animals and motor vehicles that will be in the parade. 
(5)  Such other information as the chief of police shall find necessary to the enforcement of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-10) 
Sec. 24-135. - Duties of permittee. 
(a)  A permittee under this article shall comply with all permit directions and conditions and with applicable laws and ordinances. 
(b)  The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-11) 
Sec. 24-136. - Public conduct during parades. 
(a)  Interference. No person shall unreasonably hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any parade or parade assembly or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used in a parade. 
(b)  Driving through parades. No driver of any vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade. 
(c)  Parking on parade route. The chief of police shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade. The chief of police shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. No person shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-12) 
Sec. 24-137. - Revocation of permit. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued under this article upon violation of the standards for issuance as herein set forth. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-13) 
Sec. 24-138. - Indemnification and insurance. 
(a)  The applicant and any other persons on whose behalf the application is made, by filing such application do represent, stipulate, contract and agree that they will jointly and severally indemnify and hold the city harmless against liability for any and all claims for damage to property, or injury to, or death of persons arising out of or resulting from the issuance of the permit or the conduct of the parade or its participants. 
(b)  In addition, no parade permit shall be issued unless the applicant therefor shall obtain a comprehensive general liability insurance policy, issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state, with coverage that includes the assembly area, the parade route, the disbanding area of the parade, and any other area used by the participants of the parade. The city shall be named as an additional insured on the policy. The policy limits of such insurance shall not be less than: 
(1)  Property damage: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) each occurrence. 
(2)  Bodily injury or death: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) each person; three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) each occurrence. 
(c)  At the time of the application for the parade permit satisfactory proof that the required insurance has been obtained must be presented to the chief of police. The requirement for satisfactory proof may be complied with either by depositing the insurance policy itself with the chief of police or by furnishing a certificate of insurance, meeting the following specifications to the chief of police: 
(1)  The insurance policies issued should be listed and for each policy the type of insurance, policy number, expiration date and limits of liability should be shown. 
(2)  The certificate should designate the city as certificate holder and as an additional insured, and should contain a statement to the effect that the policies listed are in force and that in the event of cancellation or any material change in a policy affecting the certificate holder, at least ten (10) days' prior written notice will be given to the certificate holder. 
(3)  Below the schedule of insurance in force, the certificate should include a statement substantially as follows: 
"The comprehensive general liability policy listed above includes coverage of designated premises and coverage for contractual liability in compliance with the provisions of Ordinance No. _____ of the City Code of the City of Rosenberg, for a parade to be held on _______, 19___." 
(4)  The certificate should be signed by an authorized agent of the issuing company or companies and should have attached a copy of a power of attorney evidencing the agent's authority. 
(d)  The requirements of subsections (b) and (c) of this section shall not be applicable to parades composed of pedestrians only and not including any vehicles or animals. If motor vehicles are to be included, evidence of public liability insurance with the same limits on such vehicles may be accepted in lieu of the insurance required in subsections (b) and (c). 
(Code 1960, § 15A-14) 
Sec. 24-139. - Penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to stage, present or conduct, or attempt to stage, present or conduct a parade without first having obtained a permit therefor as herein provided or who shall otherwise violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in a parade on the city streets for which a permit has not been granted. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to comply with all directions and conditions of the parade permit. 
(d)  The penalty upon conviction for violation of this article shall be as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 15A-15; Ord. No. 90-55, § 2, 9-4-90) 
Secs. 24-140-24-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SPECIAL EVENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-18, § 1, adopted April 17, 2012, deleted Art. V, §§ 24-156-24-160, in its entirety. Section 2 of said ordiance enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Prior to this amendment, Art. V pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for derivation. 
Cross reference- Alcoholic beverages, Ch. 3; license and permit required for certain alcoholic beverage establishments, §§ 3-26, 3-27; location restrictions on alcoholic beverage establishments, § 3-2; consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages restricted, §§ 3-3, 3-4; food and food services, Ch. 13; permits required for carnivals, § 16-36 et seq.; itinerant vendors, solicitors and peddlers, § 16-171 et seq.; solid waste containers, § 23-29; obstructions permit, § 24-5; parade permit, § 24-126 et seq. 

Sec. 24-156. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Emergency medical services mean those services provided by agencies whose primary purpose it is to provide for the general safety and welfare of the public; such agencies include ambulance, police and fire departments. 
    Emergency operations mean those operations or repairs necessary to prevent imminent damage or injury to the health or safety of the public or any person. 
    Emergency service agencies mean those agencies whose primary purpose is to provide for the general safety and welfare of the public; such agencies include ambulance, police and fire departments. 
    Nonprofit organization means any organization which has been determined to qualify under Section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code as a nonprofit organization. 
    Public area means any right-of-way/street, roadway, or sidewalk area/pedestrian way, owned or under the control of the city. 
    Public service agencies mean those agencies whose primary function it is to provide and maintain public utilities. 
    Right-of-way/street means the entirety of any public street area and/or strip of land including the public roadway and adjacent pedestrian ways. 
    Roadway means that portion of the public highway improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel or parking. In the event highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways, the term "roadway" as used herein shall refer to any such roadway. 
    Sidewalk area/pedestrian way means those portions of a street right-of-way not used as a roadway, generally located between the curb or edge of the roadway and the adjacent property line. 
    Space assignment means the specific portion of a public area to be blocked or closed for a specific time period for a specific purpose. 
    Special event is defined as any temporary gathering open to the public, including, but not limited to, arts and crafts shows, fairs, celebratory functions, political events, religious events, theatrical exhibitions, musical performances, public shows, entertainment, amusement, sports tournaments, festivals, ceremonies, shows, exhibitions, rallies, pageants, demonstrations or efforts of any kind by public or private organizations, or other exhibitions held on city-owned public property with fifty (50) or more persons expected in attendance, or the temporary use or closure of any portion of a public right-of-way, street, or sidewalk area regardless of the number of attendees. 
    Traffic lane means that portion of the roadway which has been striped or by some means channelized to convey a single flow of traffic. 
(Ord. No. 2012-18, § 2, 4-17-12) 
Sec. 24-157. - Occupancy for special events. 
(a)  Any person desiring to hold a special event as defined in Section 24-156, shall make application for the use of such public area to the code enforcement department on forms furnished by the city. Such applications for a special event must be filed with the code enforcement department a minimum of thirty (30) days before the date the public area is to be used and shall thereafter be forwarded to the building official for distribution to the appropriate city department(s) for their review and comments. Thereafter, such application shall be submitted with recommendations from all city officials reviewing same to the building official for approval and issuance. 
(b)  The following information will be required to process the application: 
(1)  Date and type of event. 
(2)  Proposed rain date of event. 
(3)  Start and finish time of the event, including set-up and clean-up time. 
(4)  Whether or not alcohol or food will be served/sold. 
(5)  Name of individual or organization responsible for coordinating the event. 
(6)  Name of contact person concerning the event. 
(7)  List of items that may be unique to the event, including but not limited to, animals, equipment, vehicles, or rides. 
(8)  Location of the event, including a map showing the area of the event with any booths, stages, canopies, tents, or other types of structures. 
(9)  List of requested services. 
(10)  Traffic/parking plan and emergency medical plan (if applicable). 
(11)  Rental agreements for area/property/park to be utilized for the special event (if applicable). 
(c)  As conditions to the approval of a request for a special event permit, the following items are incorporated in the agreement: 
(1)  If deemed necessary by the city, Rosenberg police officers, the number of which shall be determined by the police chief, shall be available on-site during the entire time the event takes place. Upon approval by the police chief, other certified peace officers, may be approved in addition to or in lieu of Rosenberg police officers. 
(2)  The event shall be terminated in sufficient time to clean up the immediate and surrounding areas affected by the event in order that the public area may be reopened at the time set by the city. 
(3)  The applicant is responsible for returning the city property to pre-event condition and agrees to compensate the city for damages and/or clean-up costs. The city may conduct a pre- and post-event survey of city property with the applicant to verify the condition of city property. The appropriate time for clean-up shall be determined by staff, but in no case exceed twenty-four (24) hours after the event has ended. Cost for clean-up will be charged at actual hourly staff rates plus the direct cost of any repairs. All damages will be assessed by the city and the cost will be billed to the event applicant, deducting from the paid deposit as needed. Clean-up and damage deposits based on the size and nature of the event shall be provided for in a schedule of fees established by resolution by the city council. 
(4)  If deemed necessary by the city, portable toilets shall be provided on-site. When provided, at least five (5) percent but not less than one toilet unit per cluster shall be handicap accessible and in compliance with the Texas Accessibility Standards. In the alternative, the applicant may present a diagram showing sufficient existing toilet facilities and written certification that the facilities are available for public use during the event. If this alternative is accepted, the location of the toilets should be clearly marked on the site of the event. 
(5)  If the event will take place on a street and/or sidewalk area, the applicant shall attempt to contact all property owners or residents of property fronting on the portion of street and/or sidewalk area sought to be closed prior to the date an application is filed. A list of persons contacted, their address and telephone listing, and a statement indicating whether each such person favors or opposes the closure shall be attached to the application. This information shall be taken into consideration in determining whether to grant a permit and under what conditions. If an approved date is later adjusted to satisfy a request of the applicant, it shall be the responsibility of the applicant to contact abutting property owners in person or by telephone and advise them of the change in schedule no less than twenty-four (24) hours in advance of the actual planned event. 
(6)  If deemed necessary by the city, event organizers shall rope off lawn or other properties of residents which are on private property immediately adjacent to and abutting the area where the event is to take place who desire such protection. Such security measures shall not impede access to or from the property. 
(7)  If deemed necessary by the city, monitor(s) shall be provided by the applicant to be stationed at each exit to discourage alcoholic beverages being taken from the area where the event is to take place. The number and location of such monitors shall be determined by the city. 
(8)  The applicant shall pay the fee as provided herein. 
(9)  If the city co-sponsors an event, said fees and related costs may be waived by the city manager upon review of the event application. 
(10)  Any services being requested from the city must be listed in writing and attached to the application form. If the city agrees to provide such services, the applicant shall reimburse the city for the cost of all personnel, (including salary, fringe benefits, and overtime) and equipment and vehicles used by the city in setting up for the event. The rates will be determined by the city using F.E.M.A. schedules and shall be payable before the event is to take place. 
(11)  The applicant shall secure a parade permit if applicable, as well as any alcoholic beverage permit, itinerant vendor permit, food dealer's permit, carnival permit, or other permit or license required by city, state and federal laws or regulations. 
(12)  If the applicant wishes to have alcoholic beverages at the event, this information should be provided at the time the application is made. No alcoholic beverages shall be allowed on any city-owned property unless in full compliance with the City of Rosenberg Code of Ordinances, and pursuant to all other state and federal regulations. 
(13)  The application shall require that the permit holder protect, indemnify and hold harmless the city from any claims for damages to any person or property arising from the permitting of the event. 
(14)  An insurance policy providing comprehensive general liability coverage over any and all areas used by the participants of the event throughout the duration of the event, issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state must be submitted naming the city as an insured party for any event being requested. The amount of insurance required from the permit holder will be for no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00). If the city determines that any activity is abnormally dangerous or ultra-hazardous, including amusement rides, motor vehicle races, or similar high-risk activities, the amount of insurance required from the permit holder will be adjusted to cover said high-risk activities. 
(d)  This section does not apply to any activity performed by or under the management, direction, or control of emergency service agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2012-18, § 2, 4-17-12) 
Sec. 24-158. - Permit required and liability of permitee. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make use of a right-of-way/street, roadway, or sidewalk area/pedestrian way, owned or under the control of the city covered by this article without first having obtained a permit therefore as herein provided or to otherwise violate any of the provisions of this article. 
    The person or persons to whom a permit is issued shall be liable for any loss, damage or injury sustained by any person whatever by reason of the negligence of the person or persons to whom such permit shall have been issued. 
(Ord. No. 2012-18, § 2, 4-17-12) 
Sec. 24-159. - Fee for permit. 
    No permit may be issued hereunder until the applicant has paid the permit fee provided for in a schedule of fees established by resolution by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2012-18, § 2, 4-17-12) 
Sec. 24-160. - Variances and appeals. 
(a)  Variations and modifications of the general requirements of this article will be considered by the police chief when in his judgment special or particular factors and conditions warrant such variation. 
(b)  Before any decision of the police chief shall become final, such decision shall be subject to review by city council if requested within ten (10) days from the date of the decision, and a member of council requests review of such decision at the next regularly scheduled council meeting." 
(Ord. No. 2012-18, § 2, 4-17-12) 
Secs. 24-161-24-169. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PERMITTED USE OF PUBLIC STREETS' RIGHTS-OF-WAY FOR ESTABLISHMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF TREES OR DECORATIVE LANDSCAPING[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-34, § 1, adopted Nov. 15, 2016, amended Art. VI in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. VI, §§ 24-170-24-176, pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 24-170. - Enablement of mechanism provided for by state law. 
    The city council of the city does hereby declare it is the policy of the city to provide for the enablement of the provisions of V.T.C.A., Transportation Code Ch. 316 entitled, "Use of Municipal Streets and Sidewalks for Public Conveniences and Amenities or for Private Uses," to provide for a mechanism to permit the installation of decorative landscaping, including landscaping lighting where appropriate, watering systems or other accessories for the maintenance of trees or landscaping. 
( Ord. No. 2016-34 , § 1, 11-15-16) 
Sec. 24-171. - Application procedure required. 
    Any persons seeking to use any portion of a public street right-of-way or other public way or public area for the installation of trees or decorative landscaping or the maintenance of presently existing trees or decorative landscaping, including landscaping lighting, watering systems or other accessories for the maintenance of trees or landscaping shall apply to the director of public works of the city for such authority as herein provided. 
( Ord. No. 2016-34 , § 1, 11-15-16) 
Sec. 24-172. - Content of application. 
    The applicant seeking authority hereunder shall provide to the city plans, drawings, diagrams in such manner and formality and under such procedures as may be from time to time provided for by rules established by the city manager of the city. The application shall describe the type and nature of improvement sought to be installed, the mechanism or procedures to be used to insure the continuing viability and maintenance of the proposed improvements as well as such information relating to the financial aspects of such improvements including, but not limited to, maintenance, replacement and long term oversight. The applicant shall provide such information and documentation to permit the director of public works to be completely informed as to nature and description of the improvements sought to be installed including such technical aspects thereof as may be appropriate and necessary. In addition, the applicant shall provide a statement as to the source of funding or potential funding that may be available to insure the continuing maintenance of the improvements over a long term. 
( Ord. No. 2016-34 , § 1, 11-15-16) 
Sec. 24-173. - Review of application. 
    The director of public works and the city manager shall review any applications filed hereunder and shall make such inquiries or investigations including, but not limited to, requesting additional information and documentation as shall be necessary to ensure that they are properly and fully informed as to the proposal that is being made. 
( Ord. No. 2016-34 , § 1, 11-15-16) 
Sec. 24-174. - Approval process. 
    As soon as the director of public works and city manager have noted their approval, the application shall be forwarded to the city council for final review and approval except for (1) shrubs or groundcover three (3) feet or less in height and not impacting visibility and (2) trees planted pursuant to section 24-177, which may be approved by the city manager or his or her designee. All other types of landscaping shall be forwarded to the city council for final review and approval. If either the director of public works or city manager shall fail to note their approval thereon, the application shall be deemed denied. 
( Ord. No. 2016-34 , § 1, 11-15-16) 
Sec. 24-175. - Required findings of fact. 
    Before a final approval hereunder can be made by the city council, the city council shall make the following findings of fact: 
(1)  The proposed improvement or facility will not be located on, extended onto or intrude on (1) the roadway, or (2) a part of the sidewalk needed for pedestrian use; 
(2)  In addition, the city council shall find and determine the improvement or facility will not create a hazardous condition or obstruction of vehicular or pedestrian travel on the municipal street and the design and location of the improvement or facility includes all reasonable planning to minimize potential injury or interference to the public in use of the municipal street. 
( Ord. No. 2016-34 , § 1, 11-15-16) 
Sec. 24-176. - Conditions, limitations and term. 
    The city council shall have the authority to provide such term provisions, limitations, restrictions or conditions as shall be appropriate or necessary. Failure by the applicant to comply with such term, limitations or restrictions as shall be provided for by the city council shall terminate the authority as herein provided. 
( Ord. No. 2016-34 , § 1, 11-15-16) 
Sec. 24-177. - Street right-of-way tree planting list, definitions and additional conditions for approval. 
(a)  Street right-of-way tree planting list. The following tree types may be approved by the city manager or his or her designee under the conditions as outlined below. Other types of landscaping, with the exception of shrubs or groundcover three (3) feet or less in height and not impacting visibility, shall be forwarded to the city council for final review and approval.

(b)  Definitions . 
(1)  Growspace shall mean an area capable of supporting tree establishment and growth and shall contain soil that has not been stabilized, or compacted to a point where water infiltration rates fall below 3.0 inches/hour. Growspace shall not include street, sidewalk, parking lot or other hardscape. Each growspace shall include no more than one (1) tree. 
(2)  Visibility triangle shall mean the triangular area bounded by the intersecting street lines and a line joining points along said street lines twenty (20) feet from the point of their intersection or, in the case of driveways, the triangular area bounded by the intersecting street and driveway lines and a line joining points along said street and driveway lines ten (10) feet from the point of intersection. 
(c)  Additional conditions for approval. 
(1)  Large trees shall not be planted within sixteen (16) feet of overhead utility lines; 
(2)  No tree shall be planted within visibility triangle of street intersection or driveway; 
(3)  No tree shall be planted within thirty (30) feet of a traffic signal, stop sign, street light or other regulatory traffic sign; and 
(4)  In rights-of-way with open ditches, such trees shall be located on the opposite side of all parts of the ditch from the street pavement. 
( Ord. No. 2016-34 , § 1, 11-15-16) 
Secs. 24-178-24-184. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PUBLIC STREET RIGHT-OF-WAY MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 24-185. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article shall be effective within the city limits and including all areas that from time to time may be subsequently annexed or added to the city. However, the provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any person with a current, unexpired consent, franchise, agreement or other authorization from the city to use the public rights-of-way that is in effect at the time this article shall take effect to the extent that there be any conflict in this article with the terms and provisions of the prior grant, and such prior grant shall remain superior to any provisions as herein set out until the same shall terminate or otherwise expire. The provisions of this article shall control where no conflict exists; however, in the event of conflict or uncertainty as to any prior document, this agreement shall control. 
(Ord. No. 2000-08, § 1, 3-21-00) 
Sec. 24-186. - Definitions. 
    Entity as used herein shall be understood to mean a corporate organization consisting of one (1) or more persons as otherwise defined in this Code. The term "entity" shall mean one (1) or more persons and shall have the same legal effect as the word "person" as otherwise used in this Code. 
    Public right-of-way or public street right-of-way as used herein shall mean that area on, below or above a public roadway, highway, street, public sidewalk, alley, waterway or utility easement in which the municipality has an interest. The term does not include airwaves above a right-of-way with regard to wireless communications. 
(Ord. No. 2000-08, § 1, 3-21-00) 
Sec. 24-187. - Notice and penalties. 
(a)  In the event of any violation of the provisions of this article, the city shall first provide notice of the violation and a reasonable opportunity shall be provided to the person in violation to cure such violation. An entity so notified shall have ten (10) days upon receipt of the notice to cure or remedy the condition or circumstance which is the subject of such notification to cure the same.
