ARTICLE V. - RAILROADS 

Sec. 28-181. - Grade crossing; obstructing vision; unloading. 
    Where a city street or road within the city limits crosses a railroad at the same grade, it shall be unlawful for a railroad car or any type of railroad equipment which will obstruct the vision of motorists to be parked within one hundred (100) feet of such grade crossing except for the purpose of unloading cargo into a building adjacent to a spur. In this event the end of the car or cars being unloaded shall not extend past the street side of the building receiving the cargo more than one-half (1/2) the length of a boxcar; and in no event shall the end of the car being unloaded be less than fifty (50) feet from the street crossing the track occupied by the car being unloaded. 
(Code 1960, § 24-59) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 24. 
Sec. 28-182. - Blocking crossings; time limit. 
    No railroad conductor or acting conductor, in charge of an engine or train of cars, shall stop or cause to be stopped any railway engine or cars across any street, alley or roadway, highway, or other passageway in this city, so as to interfere with the free passage thereon for a longer period of time than five (5) consecutive minutes. 
(Code 1960, § 24-60) 
Sec. 28-183. - Whistles; sirens and bells. 
    It shall be unlawful to blow, or cause to be blown, the railroad engine whistle or siren or ring or cause to be rung the railroad engine bell, within the city limits, except when there is imminent danger of an accident. 
(Code 1960, § 24-62) 
Cross reference- Noise, § 14-91 et seq. 
Secs. 28-184-28-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TRANSPORTATION OF TOXIC OR HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-40, § 1, adopted August 6, 1990, added Art. VIII, § 24-63-24-65 to the 1960 Code. At the discretion of the editor, said article and sections have been redesignated as Art. VI, §§ 28-191-28-193 herein. 
Cross reference- Required designation of certain hazardous cargo, Ch. 2203 of the fire code adopted in § 11-81. 
Federal law reference- Authority of city to regulate, 49 U.S.C.A. § 5125. 

Sec. 28-191. - Definitions. 
    As used herein, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings set forth adjacent to them: 
    Bulk form: 
(1)  Substances in dry form weighing over one thousand (1,000) pounds; or 
(2)  Substances in liquid form consisting of more than fifty-five (55) gallons. 
    Commercial substance: 
(1)  Any substance that has monetary value; 
(2)  Any sellable product; or 
(3)  Any substance capable of being used for a purpose other than as a waste product. 
    Hazardous: 
(1)  Any substance, mixture or article that is poisonous on the basis of human experience; 
(2)  Any substance, mixture or article that is toxic, corrosive, an irritant, a strong sensitizer, flammable or that generates pressure through decomposition, heat or other means, if such substance or mixture of substances may cause substantial personal injury or substantial illness during or as a proximate result of any customary or reasonably foreseeable handling or use; 
(3)  Any radioactive substance; or 
(4)  Anhydrous ammonia. 
    Noncommercial substance: 
(1)  Waste; or 
(2)  Any substance that has no market value and that is not reasonably capable of being used for any purpose other than as a waste product. 
    Toxic: 
(1)  Any substance, mixture or article that is poisonous on the basis of human experience; 
(2)  Any substance, mixture or article found to be a hazardous substance or banned hazardous substance in accordance with the Federal Hazardous Substances Act; or 
(3)  Any substance, mixture, or article found to be toxic, highly toxic, an irritant, a strong sensitizer, corrosive, flammable or pressure-generating in accordance with the Federal Hazardous Substances Act. 
(Ord. No. 90-40, § 1(24-63), 8-6-90) 
Sec. 28-192. - Transport of toxic or hazardous substances restricted to designated route. 
(a)  Every vehicle, whether common carrier or not, transporting noncommercial toxic or hazardous substances in bulk form shall be confined to movement within the city to the following routes: 
(1)  Along U.S. Highway 59 within the city limits; and 
(2)  Along U.S. Highway 36 West beginning with the 500 block to U.S. Highway 90, 900 block only, to State Highway 529; and 
(3)  Along U.S. Highway 36 South, from the 3400 block to the 4300 block. 
(b)  Vehicles transporting commercial toxic or hazardous substances shall be confined to such route except when: 
(1)  Such vehicle is being driven to or from a place outside the route designated in subsection (a) above, but within the city limits where the cargo of such vehicle is intended to be loaded or unloaded; or 
(2)  Such vehicle is being driven to or from the property of the motor carrier owning such vehicle or under whose contract the vehicle is being driven and such property is located outside the route designated in subsection (a) above, but within the city limits; or 
(3)  Such vehicle is being driven to or from a place designated as a safe haven in accordance with federal law and supporting regulations where such vehicle is to be parked or was parked for a period of not less than four (4) hours and such place is located outside the route designated in subsection (a) above, but within the city limits. 
(c)  Proof that a vehicle transporting toxic or hazardous substances was outside the route designated in subsection (a) above shall constitute prima facie evidence of a violation of this section; but the owner or operator of such vehicle shall have the right to introduce evidence to show that the vehicle was being driven to or from a place outside the route designated in subsection (a) above as authorized by subsection (b). 
(Ord. No. 90-40, § 1(24-64), 8-6-90) 
Sec. 28-193. - Penalty. 
    Any person who commits an offense under this article is, on conviction, subject to a fine not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 90-40, § 1(24-65), 8-6-90) 
Secs. 28-194-28-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - REGULATIONS FOR MOTOR ASSISTED SCOOTERS 

Sec. 28-200. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Custodian means the natural or adoptive parent or court-appointed guardian or conservator of a child. 
(2)  Motor assisted scooter means a self-propelled device with at least two (2) wheels in contact with the ground during operation, with a braking system capable of stopping the device under typical operating conditions, a gas or electric motor not exceeding forty (40) cubic centimeters, a deck designed to allow a person to stand or sit while operating the device, and the ability to be propelled by human power alone. This term does not include a neighborhood electric vehicle, which is defined as a vehicle subject to Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards 500 (49 C.F.R. Sec. 571.500) (Tex. Trans. Code § 551.301[1][2]). See Texas Transportation Code, § 551.351 (defining motor assisted scooter). 
(3)  Pocket bike or mini motorbike means a self-propelled vehicle that is equipped with an electric motor or internal combustion engine having a piston displacement of less than fifty (50) cubic centimeters, is designed to propel itself with not more than two (2) wheels in contact with the ground, has a seat or saddle for the use of the operator, is not designed for use on a highway, and is ineligible for a certificate of title under Chapter 501 of the Texas Transportation Code. The term does not include a moped or a motorcycle. 
(4)  Public way or public property means real property owned, leased or controlled by a political subdivision of the State of Texas, a governmental entity or agency, or similar entity, or any property that is publicly owned or maintained or dedicated to public use, including, but not limited to, an alley, street, or highway. This term does not include a sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 2006-07, § 2, 6-6-06) 
Sec. 28-201. - Operation on sidewalks, public property, and certain streets prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or ride a motor assisted scooter, pocket bike or mini motorbike on any sidewalk located within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or operate a motor assisted scooter, pocket bike or mini motorbike on a street, road, highway, public way, or public property within the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a custodian to allow or permit a child to operate or ride a motor assisted scooter, pocket bike or mini motorbike on any sidewalk, street, road, highway, public way or public property located within the city. 
(Ord. No. 2006-07, § 2, 6-6-06) 
Sec. 28-202. - Affirmative defenses. 
    It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution from an offense under this article that: 
(1)  The person was operating an electric personal assistive mobility device in accordance with the provision of Subchapter C, Chapter 551, of the Texas Transportation Code; 
(2)  That the person was operating a moped or motorcycle licensed by the Texas Department of Transportation; or 
(3)  The person was operating a motorized mobility device as defined by § 542.009 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(Ord. No. 2006-07, § 2, 6-6-06) 
Sec. 28-203. - Penalty. 
    A person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be subject to the penalty provided in section 1-13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2006-07, § 2, 6-6-06) 
Chapter 29 - UTILITIES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 1, adopted July 5, 2016, repealed former Art. I, §§ 29-1, 29-2, and enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. The former article pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 29-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Combination residential and commercial/industrial user shall mean an establishment containing any combination of uses which would qualify as a single-family residence and/or multiple-dwelling units and a commercial/industrial user. 
    Commercial/industrial user shall mean any business or establishment which does not meet the definition of residential user of water and/or sewer services. 
    Residential users of water and/or sewer services shall mean a single-family residence established to serve a single-family or household. 
    Multiple-dwelling units shall mean one (1) or more buildings, each equipped for occupancy by two (2) or more families or households. Manufactured housing, mobile home and/or travel trailer parks, as defined in section 17-1 shall be classified as multiple-dwelling units. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 1, 7-5-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 29-2. - Fees and penalties for dishonored checks. 
(a)  Deposits . If any person attempts to pay a required deposit by check or similar instrument and such instrument is dishonored, the service for which such deposit was made shall be subject to disconnection without notice and a processing fee equal to the maximum allowed by state law, not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be assessed. Additional fees to reinstate service will be charged in accordance with the schedule set out in section 29-46. 
(b)  Account payment. If any person attempts to pay an account bill by check or similar instrument and such instrument is dishonored, then the person obligated on the corresponding account shall be notified that if he does not pay the bill, plus a processing fee as prescribed in subsection (a), in full, by cash, cashier's check, money order, debit card or credit card, within five (5) days, the service for which such bill was prepared shall be discontinued and the corresponding account will be charged additional fees in accordance with the schedule set out in section 29-46. The payment on an account by dishonored check or similar instrument shall constitute nonpayment and shall be subject to penalties therefor. 
(c)  Payment by cash, cashier's check, money order, debit card or credit card. The city may refuse to accept payment by check or similar instrument from any person who has had within a year three (3) or more payments to the city made by check or similar instrument dishonored. The city shall notify such person in writing that only cash, a cashier's check, money order, debit card or credit card will be accepted from that person. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 1, 7-5-16) 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-66 et seq. 
State Law reference- Maximum processing fee for dishonored check, V.T.C.A., Business and Commerce Code § 3.506. 
Secs. 29-3-29-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) ---

DIVISION 1. - WATER SERVICE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, adopted July 5, 2016, repealed former Div. 1, §§ 29-26-29-59.2, and enacted a new Div. 1 as set out herein. The former division pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 29-26. - City's reserved rights; liability exemption. 
(a)  Shutting off all water; purposes. The city reserves the right at any time to shut off the water in its mains for the purpose of cleaning, repairing or making any connections or extensions, or for the purpose of repairing machinery, reservoir or any part of the waterworks system. 
(b)  Exemption from liability. The city shall not be liable for any damages on account of leakage or breakage of pipes on any premises. 
(c)  Proof of ownership. Whenever ownership is a prerequisite to any right in this article, the city reserves the right to consider any reasonable proof thereof. 
(d)  Right to make other rules. The city reserves the right to make such other rules and regulations as may be necessary for the preservation, protection and economical administration of its water system. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-27. - Right of entry; time; purposes. 
    Every person taking water from the city shall, at all reasonable times, permit the city water employee, or other officer or agent of the city, to enter his premises or buildings to examine his water pipes and fixtures, the manner in which the water is used and for the purpose of repairing, reading or testing the meters. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-28. - Securing pipe repairs; persons authorized to receive notice. 
    All repairs of the city's pipes, whether made necessary from leaks or other causes, will receive attention by giving information to the utility department or customer service department. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-29. - Property rights designated. 
(a)  Pipe; property line. The property of the city ends and the property of the landlord or property owner begins where the service pipe running on the premises connects with the curbstop at the meter. 
(b)  Water meter and box. Each water meter and box shall be the property of the city and shall be subject to inspection, readings, repairs and removal by the city at all times. Each water meter and box shall be installed outside and adjacent to the property limits conveniently accessible to the city or as directed by the utility department. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-30. - Service line-Distance from main. 
(a)  Distance furnished by city. The service initiation fee as set in section 29-37 shall include the cost of furnishing service lines to the property line of any person living in the city on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived for a distance of not more than one hundred twenty (120) feet in open cut from any existing service line or main where there is or will be only one (1) consumer to be supplied from such service line. 
(b)  Payment by consumer. Any person within the city limits desiring a service line that requires the laying of more than one hundred twenty (120) feet of line will be furnished water by the city by his paying for any additional line over and above one hundred twenty (120) feet. 
(c)  Connections required. Any person using water service within the corporate limits of the city must connect to the city service line or main when the service line or main exists within one hundred twenty (120) feet of that person's property. Any person who has a service line or main available in accordance with this subsection must make a connection within thirty (30) days of such availability. Failure to make a connection to such service line or main shall constitute a violation of this subsection and persons in violation hereof shall be subject to the fines and penalties as described in section 1-13 of this Code. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-31. - Same-Outside city limits; to city boundary. 
    The city will not lay or furnish service lines outside the city limits except upon approval by a majority vote of city council. The applicant must pay for any extension of service lines required to serve his property. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-32. - Meter installation; separate meters; charges outside city. 
(a)  Inside city. The city will furnish and install meters within the city limits, except as hereinafter provided. Meters for water service up to one-inch service will be furnished and installed by the city. Meters for one and one-half-inch or two-inch service will be furnished and installed by the city, unless the city requires the customer to furnish and install such meter. All meters for service greater than two-inch, and all separate leak detector meters for fire lines, shall be installed by the customer. Each separate house, premises, or fire line must be provided with a separate meter and connection and is subject to all rules and regulations contained in this article. Fire line leak detector meters must be installed outside of the building in a vault, protected from damage by vehicular traffic, and accessible by city employees for reading purposes. Meter type must be compatible with the city meter reading system and be approved by the utility department prior to installation. 
(b)  Outside city; installation fee. Each consumer outside the city limits must pay the regular installation fee as set forth in section 29-37, plus an additional amount representing ten (10) percent of the regular fee. 
(c)  Outside city; separate meters. Each separate house, premises or fire line outside the city must be provided with a separate meter and connection, is subject to all the rules and regulations contained in this article and shall pay the rates for water service as set forth in section 29-50(d). 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-33. - Contract of supply; no specified quantity; ample for purposes named; violations; rationing of water. 
(a)  Water consumers are not guaranteed a specified quantity of water for any purpose whatsoever but simply an ample quantity for the purposes named in the permit. All other purposes to which water may be applied is a direct violation of the agreement made between the city and consumer at the time of granting the permit, and any persons so violating such agreement shall be subject to the fines and penalties as described in section 1-13. 
(b)  The city council shall declare when an emergency water shortage exists, requiring the rationing of water in the city to provide fire protection, protect city equipment and to protect the health of the citizens of the city. If the council is unable to promptly convene to make such declaration, the mayor may declare such an emergency water shortage. Upon declaration of an emergency, the council, or the mayor acting if the council is unable to convene, shall adopt a water rationing plan as submitted by the city manager. Such plan may provide for the city manager to declare an end to water rationing upon certain conditions and may allow the city manager to grant variances from the water rationing plan and set forth water use restrictions or prohibitions and other provisions. Any persons violating a water rationing plan adopted by the council or the mayor will be subject to the fines and penalties as described in section 1-13. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-34. - Tapping water mains; city water service employees only; consent. 
    No plumber or other person, except the water service employees of the city, shall be allowed to tap any street main or pipes belonging to the city or to do any work in the streets, alleys or public grounds in connection with the laying of the street service connections and in connection with their mains, without the consent of the utility department. Persons violating this provision shall be subject to the fines and penalties as described in section 1-13. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-35. - Application for service; payment responsibility. 
(a)  An application for water service on any premises in the city must be completed. The applicant and any co-applicants must sign the application and provide either a Texas driver's license, a photo identification card issued by the Texas Department of Public Safety or two (2) other forms of identification, of which one (1) must be a valid picture identification. All requirements must be met before service will be provided and accounts may only be discussed with persons whose names appear on the account as either an applicant or a co-applicant except as permitted by the Texas Public Information Act. 
(b)  A customer requesting a transfer of existing service to a different location within the city must complete and sign an application for service at the new location. Any utility charges pending billing or already billed on the existing service account must be paid in full before transfer of service. 
(c)  No water service will be furnished to any person who is indebted to the city for any utility-related debts. No water service will be furnished to any person if the owner of the property is indebted to the city for any utility-related debts. 
(d)  If water is used at a premise for which application has not been made, then the owner of the premise shall be billed for the water so used and shall be responsible for the payment thereof. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-36. - Deposit, use and final disposition; service initiation fees. 
(a)  Deposits as set forth in this section shall be paid to the city at the time of applying for the water service. The amount of the required deposit shall be determined according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Residential service. 
Type of Service Deposit Amount Residential account $150.00 Residential account, senior citizen over 65 80.00  
If the applicant is requesting residential service, as defined in this section, with an existing account and no more than two (2) delinquent payments within the last twelve (12) months on the existing account, no deposit shall be required on any additional account at such other service address. 
(2)  Commercial service. Commercial service includes industrial, combination residential and commercial service, multiple dwelling units and multiple tenant units. The amount of the required deposit shall be determined by the customer service department staff, based upon the estimated water, wastewater (sewer) and solid waste charges for two (2) months and the nature of the business, with a minimum deposit of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). However, if the applicant is requesting commercial service, as defined in this section, with an existing account and no more than two (2) delinquent payments within the last twelve (12) months on the existing account, no deposit shall be required on any additional account at such other service address. 
(b)  Service transfers. A customer who applies for a transfer of an existing service account to a different premise within the city may be required to pay the service initiation fee set forth in subsection (f) of this section. The required deposit on the existing service account must be at least the amount specified in subsection (a); if the deposit is less than the required deposit, the difference must be paid before transfer of service. However, if the customer requesting the transfer has no more than two (2) delinquent payments within the last twelve (12) months, the difference in the current account's deposit and the deposit amount specified in subsection (a) shall not be required on the account transfer. 
(c)  Bulk water and transient meters. Customers requesting bulk water service for a fixed quantity picked up at a city facility shall not be required to make a deposit. Transient meters will be furnished by the city. Short-term water service from a fire hydrant to be used during any construction project within the city limits shall require a deposit of eight hundred dollars ($800.00), and a two hundred thirty dollar ($230.00) installation fee. The deposit described herein will be refunded after all water charges have been paid and the transient meter is returned to the city, except that the city may deduct from the deposit any unpaid usage charges, penalties for late payments, or the cost to repair a damaged meter or fire hydrant or replace a lost or destroyed transient meter. 
(d)  Temporary service. Short-term service of ninety (90) days or less for other than construction purposes, such as maintenance of unoccupied structures, shall not require a deposit to be placed with the city. The customer requiring such service will, however, be required to pay a minimum twenty dollars ($20.00) temporary water and sewer service fee per month, for up to two thousand (2,000) gallons of such service. Any usage exceeding the minimum two thousand (2,000) gallons per month shall be billed for water and sewer services at the current rate. Services will automatically terminate on the ninetieth day if a deposit is not paid for full service. 
(e)  Refunds . Deposits shall be held by the city as long as the customer continues to use water at the premises for which such deposit was made. At the time of final billing the service account the deposit will be applied to the remaining balance and any credit will be refunded. 
(f)  Security/deposits. Letters of credit are acceptable in lieu of cash for payment of deposits as required in this section in appropriate circumstances as determined by the director of finance and administration. 
(g)  Service initiation fee. The city requires a one working day notice to connect service, including temporary service. A service initiation fee is not required if service is requested with a one working day notice. If service, including temporary service, is required on the date of application, a service initiation fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be paid at the time of application. The city will not initiate service if the meter indicates that water is running. An additional service fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) will be charged for each subsequent trip to initiate service. 
( Ord. No. 2017-32, § 1, 12-5-17 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-32 , § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2017, deleted former § 29-36, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2016-17, § 2, 7-5-16. 
Sec. 29-37. - Tapping water mains; connection rates; inspection fee for fire line tap and meter installed by a third party; inspection fee for service line and meter requiring a vault installed by a third party. 
(a)  The uniform charge for tapping the water mains and conveying the water up to and including the curbstop, water meter and box at the property line shall be as set forth in the schedule of prices on water connections as follows: 
(1)  3/4-inch × ?-inch water service, including cost of meter-$600.00. 
(2)  1-inch water service, including cost of meter-$700.00. 
(3)  11/2-inch and larger water service-As set by the utility department for the cost of all materials and labor, plus a fifteen (15) percent administrative fee. A customer may install any required water service that is one and one-half (11/2) inches and larger, in accordance with city specification. Upon connection to the city system, the meter becomes the property of the city. 
(b)  Boring for water taps shall be subject to a fee set by the utility department, which fee shall be calculated to recover the full cost of performing the bore requested. 
(c)  An inspection fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be assessed for each fire line tap and meter installed by a third party and subsequently inspected by city personnel. 
(d)  A tap inspection fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be assessed for each third party provided water tap, service line and meter installation of one and one-half inch or larger tap requiring a vault. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-38. - Reserved. 
Sec. 29-39. - Restoring terminated water service. 
    No plumber or other person shall restore any water service to premises for which the city has terminated water service without consent of the utility department. If it is determined by inspection of the utility department that terminated water service has been restored at a specific location without such consent, the customer in whose name the account appears or the owner of the property, if the account is inactive, shall be assumed to have restored the water service. Any person violating this section shall be subject to the fines and penalties as described in section 1-13 of this Code. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-40. - Permit required; refusal to supply water. 
    The city will refuse to turn on the water for any person making any alterations or extensions of the water pipes on his premises, who shall not have first secured the necessary permit to make such changes. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-41. - Customer's installation. 
(a)  The customer is responsible for installing, providing, repairing, and maintaining all water service facilities located on the customer's side of the meter. 
(b)  To receive city service, the customer must convey to the city any property rights necessary to extend the city's lines or extensions thereof or other equipment necessary or incidental to the supplying of service to the customer, without reimbursement from the city. 
(c)  The customer must maintain the premises so that city's agents have safe and unobstructed access to all portions thereof for the purpose of maintaining, removing, or replacing the city's property, reading meters, inspecting plumbing systems, and backflow methods and assemblies and other apparatus on new and remodeled installation, and all other purposes incident to the supplying of service to the customer. 
(d)  The customer's service connections are to be located at a point readily accessible to the city's service facilities. The service connection point is to be determined by the city, using the most direct route to city facilities, and the point may be relocated if deemed necessary by the city. 
(e)  All installations must conform with city plumbing, building, mechanical, energy conservation, fire, and electric codes, and with any other city ordinance governing the customer's installation. 
(f)  Where and as required by the city's ordinance, backflow prevention assemblies, devices and methods must be installed, maintained and operationally tested by the customer, provided water service is directly or indirectly connected, or interconnected to the city's potable water distribution system. 
(g)  The customer will install and maintain operable a city-appointed water cut off valve at an approved location on the customer's side of the meter. 
(h)  If the customer's plumbing fixtures are lower than the castings onto the city's mains, the customer must install the necessary backflow protection equipment. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-42. - Reserved. 
Sec. 29-43. - Termination of service; customer request. 
    If service is no longer needed at a premise, the applicant or co-applicant must request in writing for the service to be terminated. If no request is made, service will remain active and billing of services will continue. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-44. - Waste or unreasonable use; city's remedies; frozen pipes. 
(a)  Fraudulent representations; unauthorized use; waste; authorized action . In case of fraudulent representations on the part of the applicant or the use of water for purposes not embraced in the application or lease or of willful or unreasonable waste of water, the city shall have the right to forfeit any payment made, turn off the water and recover all damages. 
(b)  Frozen pipes; no deduction. No deduction will be made for the time any service pipe may be frozen. 
(c)  Running water to prevent freezing. Water running to waste or to keep the pipe from freezing is prohibited. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-45. - Credit adjustments; payment extensions. 
(a)  A customer who deems his account to have had an extraordinary increase in consumption may request to the customer service department for a credit adjustment. This request shall be made in writing and will denote the purpose of the request. A credit adjustment will be considered, based on the following guidelines: 
(1)  Documented proof of a repaired leak or unavoidable leaks and explainable consumption which amounts to one hundred fifty (150) percent or more of the normal consumption for that account with normal consumption defined as the consumption of the same account for the same month in the prior year or the average consumption for the account for the past twelve (12) months, whichever is greater. 
(2)  If the customer notifies the customer service department of a higher consumption due to filling a pool, consideration may be given for a credit adjustment calculated on sewer charges using a twelve-month average consumption as normal consumption: 
(3)  If the increase in consumption occurred over several months a credit adjustment will be considered for up to two (2) months with the highest consumption and only after the monthly consumption has returned to the normal consumption. 
(4)  If the customer requesting the credit adjustment does not have at least twelve (12) months of historic consumption, the credit adjustment request will be based on the average consumption available or the historical consumption for the account. 
(5)  If a credit balance is the result of the credit adjustment, no refund will be issued; the credit will remain on the account and will be applied to future utility bills. 
(b)  If a customer has a verifiable hardship due to illness, disability, unemployment, or similar situation, a payment extension may be granted, not to exceed seven (7) days. Such request shall be in writing and will denote all the relevant facts relating to the situation as known by the customer. Upon examining the facts, the city manager or his designee shall render a decision in writing to the customer explaining the city's decision and the terms and conditions of the extension to be given, if any. Except in extreme hardship cases, the payment extension may not be granted on or past the due date of the following month's bill; payment of both bills will be required for extensions on or past the due date of the following month's bill. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-46. - Termination of service-Non-payment of utility bill. 
(a)  Disconnection . Except as provided in subsection (d) of this section, payments on accounts received by the city at its customer service department or at an authorized payment agency after 5:00 p.m. of the fifteenth day after the billing date printed on the bill, as set forth in section 29-49, shall be subject to a charge of ten (10) percent of the unpaid current balance. The city may, in its discretion, render such accounts delinquent and disconnect service for failure to pay all charges, including penalties, by the twenty-fifth day after the billing date. The city may also disconnect service for violation of any provisions in this chapter. 
(b)  Notice . Prior to disconnecting services, the city shall provide written notice to the customer whose account is delinquent. The written notice shall inform the customer of the amount of the delinquent account and the date service will be disconnected if payment is not made. If a customer does not receive a disconnection notice, the customer's obligation to make payment for service rendered is not released or diminished. 
(c)  Appeal . If the customer elects to appeal the scheduled disconnection, the customer service department and finance director are authorized to attempt settlement of the dispute with the customer. If settlement is not reached, the city council shall hear and consider the matter and any recommendations made by the customer service department at such hearing and inform the customer of the city council's consideration and determination by written notice. 
(d)  Administrative penalty . If payment is not received on a delinquent account and the account is placed on the cut-off list and water is due to be disconnected or is disconnected, an administrative penalty will be assessed. Water service shall be terminated for nonpayment by closing the curbstop. If service to a terminated account is restored without approval from the customer service department, the city may pull or lock the meter for the discontinued service. Water service shall not be restored after termination until all amounts due on the account have been paid, including the administrative penalty. Fees will be assessed per the following schedule: 
Administrative penalty-$25.00 
Upon meter removal-$100.00 
Upon locking meter-$100.00 
(e)  Additional required deposit . The deposit amount required before restoring water service to any residential customer whose account with the city has been terminated in accordance with subsection (a) of this section shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) provided that the total of all deposits required under this section and section 29-36(a) shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00); a homeowner will not be required to pay an additional fifty dollar ($50.00) deposit if the account has not been terminated in the previous twelve (12) months. Any commercial customer whose account with the city has been terminated in accordance with subsection (a) of this section will be required to pay the additional fifty dollar ($50.00) deposit per occurrence until the total deposit on the account is equal to an average of three (3) monthly bills. 
(f)  To restore service on disconnect day to locations terminated in accordance with subsection (a) of this section, payment must be received by 4:30 p.m. Any requests outside this guideline will be processed the next day unless an additional charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is paid to cover overtime. 
(g)  Payment by governmental agency . Payment on an account of a state or political subdivision is due not later than the thirtieth day after receipt of the bill in accordance with and subject to the provisions and penalties prescribed in V.T.C.A., Government Code § 2251.001 et seq., and are not subject to penalty provisions as prescribed in this section. However, such accounts are subject to all other fines and fees as prescribed herein. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-47. - Metering service-Required. 
    All services shall be properly metered by a standard water meter, except for fire lines, which shall be metered by a city-approved leak detector meter. All meters shall be the property of the city and shall be kept in repair by the city. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-48. - Same-Not registering; determination of bill. 
    Where meters are found not to register, the rate of the previous month or the same month in the prior year during months with higher seasonal usage will be taken as a basis for the amount of water consumed and payment shall be made accordingly. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-49. - Monthly bills; date of payment. 
(a)  Bills shall be due and payable on the date set by the customer service department and the due date shall be printed on the bill. If a bill is not paid in full by the due date, the account for which the bill was prepared shall become subject to a late charge as prescribed in subsection 29-50(b) and may be declared delinquent and service terminated in accordance with section 29-46, and the customer shall become subject to all the fines, penalties, and fees prescribed therein. If a customer does not receive a bill for service, the customer's obligation to make payment for service rendered is not released or diminished. 
(b)  To verify accuracy of the bill a customer may request to have the meter reread. If it is determined that the meter was misread the bill will be corrected. If it is determined that the meter was read correctly a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) will be charged to the customer. 
(c)  To verify accuracy of the bill a residential customer may request to have the meter tested for a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). If it is determined that the meter is inaccurate, the fee will be credited to the customer's account. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-50. - Metered rates; charge for late payment; senior citizen discount; outside city rates; prorated service; construction water usage; bulk water rates. 
(a)  The city will furnish water through meters, and the following charges will be made by the city per meter for water furnished to consumers: 
(1)  Residential user. Rates for single-family residences shall be as follows: 
a.  The minimum monthly charge for single-family residences shall be the sum of ten dollars and twenty-eight cents ($10.28), for which up to two thousand (2,000) gallons of water may be used. 
b.  For use of over two thousand (2,000) gallons up to ten thousand (10,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per thousand gallons. 
For use of over ten thousand (10,000) gallons up to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of two dollars and seventy cents ($2.70) per thousand gallons. 
For use of over twenty thousand (20,000) gallons up to fifty thousand (50,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of two dollars and eighty cents ($2.80) per thousand gallons. 
For use of over fifty thousand (50,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of two dollars and ninety cents ($2.90) per thousand gallons. 
(2)  Commercial/industrial users, including multiple dwelling units . The minimum monthly charge for commercial/industrial, including multiple dwelling units, for use up to two thousand (2,000) gallons of water shall be based on meter size, as described below. 
Meter Size Minimum Charge per Meter 3/4 inch $10.28 1 inch $30.85 1 1/2 inch $45.00 2 inch $55.00 3 inch $100.00 4 inch $200.00 6 inch $300.00 8 inch $450.00  
For use of over two thousand (2,000) gallons up to ten thousand (10,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per thousand gallons. 
For use of over ten thousand (10,000) gallons up to twenty thousand (20,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of two dollars and seventy cents ($2.70) per thousand gallons. 
For use of over twenty thousand (20,000) gallons up to fifty thousand (50,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of two dollars and eighty cents ($2.80) per thousand gallons. 
For use of over fifty thousand (50,000) gallons, there shall be a charge of two dollars and ninety cents ($2.90) per thousand gallons. 
(3)  Multiple-dwelling units. Rates for multiple-dwelling units shall be as follows: 
a.  The monthly water usage charge for a multiple-dwelling unit that is separately metered shall be calculated by applying the rates established for residential users. 
b.  The monthly water usage charge for a multiple-dwelling unit complex or multiple residences that are master metered shall be calculated in the same manner as commercial/industrial users. 
(4)  Combination residential and commercial/industrial users. Combination residential and commercial/industrial users shall be charged the appropriate commercial/industrial rates. 
(5)  All customers with a separate fire line and meter installed, will be billed a minimum monthly charge of seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) unless there is consumption, and then the appropriate metered rate class charges will apply above the minimum. 
(b)  Charge for late payments. All fees become due upon the city's issuance of a monthly bill and are payable on the date stated on the bill. Payments received after the due date stated on the bill shall be subject to a ten (10) percent charge on the unpaid current balance. On an individual basis, customer accounts that have a twelve-month history of no late fees charged, can request to have a one-time waiver of the charge for late payment. Residential accounts for the principal residence only of persons over the age of sixty-five (65) shall not be subject to the charge for late payments as prescribed in this section. Persons over the age of sixty-five (65) may declare only one (1) principal residence for which he is responsible for payment of the monthly bill. However, such accounts are subject to all other fines and fees as prescribed herein. 
(c)  Persons over the age of sixty-five (65) shall receive a discount of one dollar ($1.00) on single-family residential water service and one dollar ($1.00) on single-family residential sewer service, upon application to the customer service department. 
(d)  All users of city water service outside city limits shall pay one and one-half (11/2) times the amount of the applicable minimum charge as set forth in subsection (a) and one and one-half (11/2) times the amount of all applicable charges as set forth in subsection (a) for water used above the minimum charge. 
(e)  Customers shall be billed minimum charges for the first and last months of service for water and wastewater service on a prorated basis of the actual number of days service was provided. Solid waste charges for the first and last months of service shall be based on the city's actual cost to the contracted solid waste collection company. 
(f)  Construction water usage. Upon receipt of an application for service and the required deposit and installation fee as set forth in section 29-36(c), the city will provide a hydrant meter for the purposes of measuring the construction water usage if available. The meter shall be read in accordance with section 29-49 and water usage shall be billed at the rate of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per month minimum for the first two thousand (2,000) gallons, and four dollars ($4.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons thereafter. The deposit described herein will be refunded after all water charges have been paid and it has been determined that the fire hydrant and hydrant meter have not been damaged. 
(g)  Bulk water usage . The taking of bulk water shall be allowed only from a designated hydrant and shall be during the normal business hours, Monday through Friday, except holidays, unless an application for after-hours delivery is filed by the customer and approved. Bulk water customers will be responsible for paying overtime charges incurred at twenty dollars ($20.00/hour) with a minimum charge of one (1) hour, if applicable, in addition to the rate of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for the first two thousand (2,000) gallons, and four dollars ($4.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons thereafter assessed for the usage of bulk water within the city limits. 
(h)  Wholesale water usage. 
(1)  The purchase of wholesale water shall be allowed in accordance with an agreement with a specific entity approved by the Rosenberg City Council. Wholesale water customers shall be responsible for individual meter reading, billing, collection of monthly payments, termination of water service, and repair/maintenance of the water meters. Secondly, the entity shall be responsible for installation of a water interconnect with the Rosenberg water distribution system at a location approved by the Rosenberg City Council. Wholesale water customers shall be billed at a rate of 82.65 percent of Rosenberg's commercial water rate. 
(2)  For wholesale water customers, monthly payments on water usage shall be made to the City of Rosenberg within thirty (30) days of the date the city prints the monthly bill. Failure to submit payment within thirty (30) days will result in a late fee of ten (10) percent charge on the unpaid current balance. 
(i)  A water subsidence fee (GRP fee) surcharge of two dollars and twenty cents ($2.20) per one thousand (1,000) gallons shall be charged for all water used, unless otherwise provided for. Such water subsidence fee shall be applicable to all water customers including single-family residences, multiple-dwelling units, commercial/industrial users, combination residential and commercial/industrial users, temporary service, construction water usage, bulk water usage and wholesale water usage. 
(j)  Reclaimed/recycled water usage. The purchase of reclaimed/recycled water shall be allowed in accordance with city policies/requirements and with an agreement with a specific customer approved by the city manager. A minimum monthly charge for up to two thousand (2,000) gallons of reclaimed/recycled water shall be based upon meter size, as described below. All reclaimed/recycled water used over two thousand (2,000) gallons will be two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per thousand gallons. 
Meter Size Minimum Monthly Charge 3/4 inch $10.28 1 inch $10.28 2 inch $10.28 3 inch $71.97 4 inch $113.10 6 inch $154.23  
No subsidence fee (GRP fee) shall be charged for reclaimed/recycled water used. 
( Ord. No. 2017-32, § 2, 12-5-17 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2017-32 , § 2, adopted Dec. 5, 2017, deleted former § 29-50, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 2016-17, § 2, 7-5-16. 
Sec. 29-51. - Laying pipes across streets; written consent. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lay or maintain any water pipe across any street or alley within the city without written consent from the utility department. All excavations and other construction in the public right-of-way shall be performed in accordance with all applicable state, federal, and city regulations. Upon completion of any work, the person shall promptly restore the subsurface and surface of the affected public right-of-way to a condition that equals or exceeds its condition prior to such construction. The restoration shall also comply with all applicable city ordinances and regulations. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-52. - City apparatus-Tampering; valves, meters, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to turn on or off the water from any street valve, curbstop, meter connection or box, or in any manner interfere with any street valve covering, fire hydrant, or other apparatus belonging to the city water system, without consent from the utility department. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-53. - Same-Damaging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to damage any property of the city waterworks. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-54. - Street hydrants, fire plugs. 
    No person shall use the water from any street hydrant or fire plug without consent from the utility department. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-55. - Pollution. 
    No person shall befoul, pollute, put in, or allow any offensive matter to enter the city water system. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-56. - Hitching animals to fire hydrants, pipes and fixtures. 
    No person shall hitch or stand any animal to any of the fire hydrants, pipes or fixtures of the city waterworks. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-57. - Fraudulent devices for procuring water; permit required. 
    Any person building or making repairs, alterations or additions to mains or pipes of the city water system, without a written permit from the utility department specifying the particular repairs, alterations or additions to be made, or who may resort to any fraudulent device or arrangement for the purpose of procuring water for himself or others from the mains or from private connections or premises contrary to the rules and regulations of the city shall be subject to the fines and penalties as described in section 1-13. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-57.1. - Unlawful use of or damage to waterworks system. 
    In any case of unlawful use of water service, or customer damage to any property of the city waterworks, the city will bill the customer for previously unbilled utility costs for all water not recorded on the meter, and any wastewater service based thereon, the amount of which shall be calculated in accordance with section 29-48 or estimated by the city from the best available data, and billed at the proper rate schedule. The city may also bill the customer for any other city costs, including personnel costs, incurred in investigating and correcting the unlawful use or damage to city property. The city may also terminate a customer's utility service for any unlawful use of such service. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-58. - Consumer supplying others; extending private line; permit requirements. 
(a)  Supplying others with water. No consumer shall supply water to or allow it to be taken by other persons or families except for use on the premises. 
(b)  Making extensions or traps on individual supply; permit requirements . After water is introduced into any building or upon any premises, no consumer shall make or employ any plumber or other person to make any tap or connection with the works upon his premises for alterations, extensions or attachments without a written permit from the city specifying the particular change to be made and the plumber authorized to make such change. 
(c)  Violations . Any violation of any of the prohibitions contained in this article shall subject the water to be summarily cut off. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-59. - Private water wells. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drill or repair any private water well within the city limits when city water service is available within the public right-of-way or easement adjacent to private property. 
(b)  After a property is connected to city water service, an existing private water well may be used for irrigation purposes. Private water wells being used for irrigation purposes may be repaired as needed. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-59.1. - Connection fees to be paid for connections in the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city and located in the boundaries of a municipal utility district. 
    The municipal utility district shall pay a connection fee of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) to the city for each equivalent single-family connection made to the water and wastewater system; payment shall be made at time of plat approval and before any connection. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
Sec. 29-59.2. - Penalty. 
    Any violations of this division shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be punished in accordance with the provisions as set out in section 1-13(a) of this Code. 
( Ord. No. 2016-17 , § 2, 7-5-16) 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED 

Secs. 29-60-29-75. - Reserved.
